PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF HON. G.M. BRYANT, E.D.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House expresses its deep regret at the death, on Monday, 14 January 1991, of the Honourable Gordon Bryant, member of the House of Representatives for the seat of Wills from 1955 to 1980, Minister for Aboriginal Affairs from 1972 to 1973 and Minister for the Capital Territory from 1973 to 1975, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

Gordon Bryant was born on 3 August 1914 at Lismore, Victoria, and was educated at Frankston High School, Melbourne Teachers College and Melbourne University. Prior to entering Federal Parliament, he was a secondary school teacher with the Victorian Education Department. He served with the Australian Army 46th Infantry Battalion and the Melbourne University Regiment, Citizen Military Forces. In 1955 he was elected to Federal Parliament as the Australian Labor Party member for Wills and for 25 years, until 1980, gave faithful service to his electors and the nation as a member of the House of Representatives.

In an era when the inner suburbs of Melbourne struggled to get a fair share of the nation's resources, he was at all times a hard-working representative of his electors, and I can assure you, Mr Speaker, as the local member, that he was a hard act to follow. He was also a member of the Council of the National Library of Australia for a total of 12 years and President of the Aborigines Advancement League of Victoria from 1957 to 1964.

Gordon Bryant was appointed Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in 1972. In 1973 he took up his second ministerial appointment when he became Minister for the Capital Territory. He also served on several parliamentary committees with the focus on Aboriginal affairs and land rights issues. His concern over the issue of Aboriginal rights was evident not only during his parliamentary career but throughout his life. It was a subject he pursued with energy and conviction. He retired in 1980, but maintained contact with the Parliament through his work as Secretary of the Association of Former Members of the Parliament of Australia.

Gordon was a fighter-a fighter for the people of the electorate of Wills, a fighter for the people of his State and nation, a fighter for the Aboriginal members of the Australian community and a fighter for the Australian Labor Party. He was throughout his life active and independent minded, and he did not shirk a tough issue. He stood up for what he saw as right. On behalf of the Government, I extend our most sincere sympathy to his wife Pat and sons Robin and Linton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I wish to join the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in expressing our deep regret at the death on 14 January of this year of Gordon Bryant. Being a relative newcomer to the Parliament, I did not know Gordon Bryant personally, but those of my colleagues who served with Gordon Bryant in this chamber speak highly of him and describe him as a man who was honourable in every sense of the word.

SPEECH.PARA: Sir William Aston, a previous Speaker in this House, recalls Gordon Bryant as an affable and gentle man who never bore grudges. This is in contrast to his spirited performance in the House as an aggressive debater who would put his case strongly and tenaciously when fighting on a point of principle.

Gordon Bryant gave long and dedicated service to this Parliament, serving the electors of Wills for 25 years. I note from the Hansard of 22 February 1956 that in his maiden speech Gordon Bryant stated that it was his honour to represent the people of Wills, who had for the past 50 years consistently elected to the Parliament men who had kept the Labor Party on the straight and narrow. He then outlined how he envisaged his vision of individual gain being achieved through Labor's socialist philosophy and contrasted it with the support for private enterprise expressed by another new member also speaking for the first time on that day, Malcolm Fraser.

As a backbencher for a long period of time, Gordon Bryant made a substantial contribution to the committee system, serving in total on 12 parliamentary and select committees. As a secondary school teacher prior to his entry to Parliament, he had an enduring interest in education, and throughout his time in Parliament pressed for a broader role for the Federal government in education. He also championed the cause of Aboriginal rights, he was a strong defender of civil liberties and he fought hard against Australia's involvement in the Vietnam war. His staunch defence of the seat of Wills through the late 1970s from the sorties of the then President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions is well documented.

Gordon Bryant was one of a large group of Labor members who spent a very long time in opposition and who went into government in 1972 with all the pent up frustration of opposition and with enthusiasm for change. His long involvement with Aboriginal rights culminated in his appointment in the Whitlam Government as the first Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. His deep concern to improve the condition of Aboriginal people and the difficulties he encountered in carrying through that task have been shared by successive Ministers on both sides of this House.

Speaking to the Fabian Society in July 1973, Gordon Bryant expressed a vision for the future of the Aboriginal people which few could dispute, warning that there were limits to what could be achieved for Aborigines by direct intervention. He said:

We can provide money where lack of it has prevented worthwhile developments. We can increase the pace of housing construction, put more medical staff in the field and build, equip, and staff better schools in Aboriginal communities.

We cannot, however, decide for the Aborigines what they want. And if we supply too often what we think they need, we may be wasting our resources and delaying their real progress. Aborigines must regain autonomy and a sense of control over their own lives and future.

Nearly 18 years have passed in the interim and many billions of taxpayers' dollars spent, yet the sentiments that Gordon Bryant expressed are still relevant-tragically, maybe even more so than when that expression was made.

A strong commitment to improve the well-being and opportunities of Aboriginal people is the motivation behind a more cooperative relationship between the Government and the Opposition. I am sure that Gordon, as a former Minister, would have welcomed this attempt by both sides to move away from politics and to concentrate on the well-being of the Aboriginal people.

Gordon Bryant has been described as a man of literature with a deep sense of history. I am told by my colleagues that Gordon was never lost for words, no matter what the occasion, and that his keen sense of humour was enjoyed by members on both sides of this place. In joining this condolence motion, I have acknowledged that I have relied on the record and on accounts from colleagues and contemporaries. However, I believe the tribute paid to Gordon Bryant by his friend and parliamentary colleague of 25 years, Les Johnson, the former member for Hughes, is the best summation. He said:
Gordon was a big man in every way, genial and gregarious, of friendly disposition and high principles, devoted to his family, community and country.
Opposition members extend their deepest sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALKER.NAME: Mr STAPLES
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this condolence motion because Gordon Bryant lived in Lower Plenty in my electorate for many years. He and his wife Pat established their home on the banks of the Plenty River. What has been said and will be said today sums up much of Gordon's contribution to our community throughout his parliamentary life. However, I had the opportunity to know him and to work with him in the community in my electorate and I know about the service he performed outside the Parliament, particularly in his retirement.

SPEECH.PARA: As we know, he contributed most of his working life, after his wartime service, to the Parliament but he also continued to contribute actively to the community. Most people who knew him or knew of him well respected his commitment to our parliamentary process and system of government, but he firmly believed that our Constitution needed a major overhaul-and he was not the only one with that belief. Much of what he did in our community after his retirement from Parliament was in fact directed to discussing issues relating to our Constitution and our system of government with the ordinary citizen of our country. As Gordon would have it, one of the reasons that so little constitutional reform occurs in this country is that the problems of the Constitution are not discussed or understood as well as they should be by the Australian citizen.

Gordon understood this. He wanted to mobilise understanding and discussion and he did this in a number of ways. He was a key founding member of the Yarra Valley University of the Third Age. Those many hundreds of people who have been actively involved in that organisation over the couple of years since its formation will certainly miss him very much, not only for his wisdom and guidance in the development of the organisation, but also for his commitment to the programs of that organisation-particularly, as I said before, to issues of government and the Constitution. This organisation was really much of what Gordon Bryant was about-it is an organisation which enables people, particularly retired and elderly people, to share their lifelong skills, experiences and interests with others and to demonstrate unequivocally that retirement, old age or frailty should not limit one's ability to learn new skills, transfer old ones, discuss issues and continue to contribute to the community. The Yarra Valley University of the Third Age was part of his commitment to the principle that `you are only as old as you feel' and to his understanding and concern that older people have an underestimated, underutilised role and status in Australian society. To his last days, as well as he was able, he continued to stress that point and do something about it.

Many words have been said about his commitment to eduction, and people can understand that commitment. In fact, his commitment went beyond that of a teacher; it continued through his parliamentary life and, indeed, through his life after parliament. His commitment to universal and continuing education for all people, particularly Aboriginal people, also meant that he worked tirelessly for the La Trobe University; again, contributing to the development of education and life opportunity for the people of the northern suburbs of Melbourne-the people whom he served as a member of parliament and, indeed, as a citizen.

He will be missed by many. His personality was such that when Gordon Bryant walked into the room in a very short time everyone knew that he was there. They knew that because he was a person who made friends easily, accepted people easily and, basically, was prepared to talk, laugh and deal with people as human beings. He will be missed by many, but his contribution to our community in so many ways-inside and outside parliament-will continue to benefit our society. On this occasion, I, along with many people in my electorate and the Labor Party in my electorate, extend support and sympathy to his wife, Pat, his family and all of those people who knew and cared so much for him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party of Australia, I rise to support this condolence motion in respect of Gordon Munro Bryant. I also support the comments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) and others. Amongst all his contributions, Gordon Bryant participated in two parliamentary delegations to Asia, one in 1967 and the other in 1970. He was a genial man with an interest in that region, which I admired. Perhaps this flowed from his service in the armed forces-he rose to the rank of captain-that took him to Borneo and other parts of Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that too often, unfortunately, members on both sides of the House have not had either the opportunity or the resource to go to Asia in a detailed way. Gordon Bryant did so not once but twice. That example is one which we should all take note of because, clearly, we do need to build on our links with Asia in the broadest sense. With his work on those parliamentary delegations and with his other general work and activity, Gordon Bryant gave the Parliament an example of how to build up a relationship between Asia and Australia, which is so important for our economic future.

Gordon Bryant certainly had a sense of humour. He struck me as someone slightly larger than life as I looked at him and met with him on a few occasions as a then member of the New South Wales State Parliament and more recently when I came to the Federal Parliament. I think it would have touched his sense of humour were he able to realise that he has now been accorded a very rare privilege in the annals of this Parliament: namely, that he will be remembered and honoured not on one occasion but, because of the special sitting of the Parliament in January, on no less than two occasions by appropriate periods of silence. That is a nice way to salute a nice person. I extend sympathy and condolences to the family of Gordon Munro Bryant.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in supporting this motion of condolence to Patricia and the family of Gordon Bryant. I do not want to repeat what has been said. But I think it is true to see Gordon Bryant as in many ways very representative of the Labor member of the post-war period of the 1950s and 1960s-a period of opposition but also a period of deep values and commitments which were reflected in Gordon Bryant's time in this Parliament. No one was a more passionate advocate of public enterprise, as his first speech that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) referred to would evidence. He saw himself in contrast to the view of Malcolm Fraser but, nevertheless, as equally committed to the care of the individual.

SPEECH.PARA: Gordon Bryant was a representative of this Parliament and had a great and enduring faith in the sovereignty of the Parliament. Perhaps that was why he, along with so many of his contemporaries, were so injured by the events of 1975. In terms of economic policy, he belonged to the days of a rather grand expansionary Keynesian policy. I can remember in opposition in the period in which we were both here on the economics committee that people tended to be regaled by very long speeches on Gordon's part in terms of how all things were possible. Of course, that is not the case. Certainly at that time people did believe in an economic policy that was Keynesian and expansionary and which tended to include rather than exclude various opportunities.

He was, of course, passionately committed to social justice and was a very fine representative of the northern suburbs of Melbourne. No-one was more willing to represent that area at that time. No-one was more willing to move out of the established Anglo-Saxon areas to work with various migrant groups. The Italian community was always very close to Gordon Bryant and he was always very anxious to ensure that they played a stronger role in terms of politics in this country. His interest in education was lifelong, as was his interest in prison reform which, in respect of his Capital Territory portfolio, went beyond his time in Parliament.

I guess that Gordon is remembered for his interest in Aboriginal affairs. I was thinking about the occasion on which Gordon entered the Ministry, having spent some time moving around the country getting to know various Aboriginal communities. Lionel Bowen was telling me that early on in the period of the Whitlam Government he had to deal with a bill for something like $20,000 for afternoon tea. Apparently when Gordon had been up in the Centre he had said to the various communities, `When we come to office we will have you all in to afternoon tea'. It was probably the largest afternoon tea ever celebrated, but also it was a very important time in regard to the principles of self-determination and giving some real power and influence to Aboriginal communities within this country.

I got to know Gordon as a candidate and then as a member of parliament back in 1977. I was first actively involved with him during the election campaign of 1977. One of our methods of campaigning at that time was to go to factories and address meetings outside. The theory of these meetings was that the workers would down tools when the member or candidate arrived and come out to the front of the factory. There would instantly be a mass meeting. Gordon would have the megaphone ready, he certainly had the rhetoric, and it was going to be a great occasion. I recall being somewhat nervous. I had not had a lot of experience with these kinds of campaign meetings. When Gordon said, `Oh, they will all be out', I was a bit doubtful. I thought there was a bit of a sense that we were not going all that well in 1977. But Gordon said, `No, don't worry, they will be out. But you don't wait till they come out; you get straight into it'.

There we were out in Albert Street, Preston, with traffic going past and enormous noise. Gordon was talking about the only way to restore democracy and socialism to this country, and off he went. At about 12.30 the workers started coming out. I thought, `It's okay, it's okay; it's all going to work'. They went over the road to the pub. Gordon kept going. They came back again. Still Gordon kept going. He was a tremendous campaigner. He was, as has been said, a fighter. He was not someone to be put off by a situation such as that.

I appreciate more than anything the warmth of his friendship for people in the Parliament and people on our side of politics. In many ways he represented a set of views that are not quite the views that one would put now. But he represented values which went to the absolute heart of the Labor Party. It is for those values and his commitment to those values, his achievements both in government and in opposition, that this Parliament and this country owe him a very great debt. I am very pleased to support the motion and to join in offering my best wishes to Patricia and to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —For most of the time that I have been in this Parliament I have had the honour and the privilege of representing the late Gordon Bryant. As we have heard from the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples), he was a constituent of mine. So far as I know there is no credible evidence that he ever actually voted for me; however, this did not deter him from approaching me as his member of parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: As we have already been told, he lived in Lower Plenty. On Saturday mornings, as I pursued my relentless course of electoral duties through the Lower Plenty shopping centre, I would quite often hear a cry coming from the grocery counter or somewhere else, `What are you doing to represent my interests?'. When I would reply that I was trying to get rid of the Government-I should say that this was after 1983--

TALK.START.PARA: —In the circumstances your representation becomes entirely understandable. It was before 1983.

—That is not true. He would say something like, `Good luck to you'. He was one of a particularly interesting group of constituents I had in that part of my electorate, another being Senator Siddons, the leader of the Australian Democrats, the second being Mr Bill Hartley, the correspondent of the Iraqi news agency who would be known to some, who insisted on living in my electorate although I tried to persuade him to move to the electorate of Wills, and the third being Mr Eric Butler, the President of the League of Rights. Having dealt with them, I found Gordon Bryant to be a great relief.

SPEECH.PARA: I am joining in this motion for one particular reason, apart from paying credit to his qualities and activities which have been mentioned already, and that is because he was above all a parliamentarian. He put the long term interests of parliaments above the short term interests of executive governments and other interests, and in days when the parliamentary institution is under challenge from many quarters, it does us well to remember that there are people-and have been, and we hope will be-like Gordon Bryant, who espoused the parliamentary cause so vigorously. That is the principal reason I wish to support this motion with great sincerity.
Gordon Bryant was a good man. He was honest and decent above all. He was a person of the highest quality and the highest principles, and we should mourn his passing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, my future wife and I came to know Gordon and Pat Bryant around 1951 when he first stood as the Australian Labor Party (ALP) candidate for Deakin. He stood in the same seat in 1954, in both cases narrowly losing to Frank Davis. Then in 1954-55 came a political revolution in the affairs of the Victorian branch of the ALP when the Federal Executive intervened to remove supporters of the industrial groups from control. This action was taken at the urging of Dr H. V. Evatt, the Federal leader.

SPEECH.PARA: The Victorian party split, with the `Groupers' crossing the floor to defeat the State Labor Government of John Cain senior, then forming the Anti-Communist Labor Party, later the Democratic Labor Party, which, by directing its second preference votes, kept the Victorian ALP out of office for 27 years until John Cain junior won the 1982 State election. Of the 15 Labor members of parliament who had been returned in 1954, seven joined the anti-communist Labor Party, seven stayed with the ALP, and one, Don McLeod, did not contest Wannon in 1955, and of course Malcolm Fraser won the seat. Redistribution eliminated two ALP seats-Burke and Hoddle-and created one-Scullin.

After the 1955 split Prime Minister Menzies called an early Federal election. Labor's Victorian seats fell from 15 to 10. Four new Labor candidates were selected by the central executive for safe ALP seats held where sitting MPs had defected-Bob Holt in Darebin, Hector McIvor in Gellibrand, Gordon Bryant in Wills, and Jim Cairns in Yarra. Gordon Bryant remained as member for Wills for 25 years and was the last serving of that group who came in after the split.

Many people of my vintage will recall Gordon for his patience and kindness and encouragement to young people. He was always available to speak to groups, to attend meetings, and to encourage people-particularly young people-to express themselves. He had a profound influence on former members such as Race Mathews, David McKenzie and Tony Lamb.

I used to baby-sit his sons Robin and Linton when Gordon and Pat were out attending electorate functions, and it has to be said he was an extremely assiduous attender of functions. I think perhaps only the honourable member for Cook may have attended more functions one way or another than the Hon. Gordon Bryant.

He was a well rounded character, both literally and metaphorically. He had been an army officer in World War II. He remained in the Citizen Military Forces until 1961, and was active in the Returned Services League of Australia. Nevertheless, he was completely unmilitary in style and thinking. This central but endearing contradiction was very evident at his funeral service, where the supporters of military power were lined up on one side of the church and the pacifists were on the other, and Gordon Bryant was the common link between them. He lost a lung in a military training accident in 1940, but it did not seem to inhibit his level of activity, nor did the fact that he was a diabetic for many years. Gordon was, if not a pacifist, then very close to it. He deplored violence of all kinds. He liked to be a reconciler. He would have agreed with William Blake that there is no such thing as an abstract good, that good must be done `in minute particulars'.

He found the idea of cruelty, suffering, death, maiming, wounding, torture-all of those things-intolerable; whether it was the needless sacrifice and suffering of war, the chronic neglect of the Aborigines or the cruelty of torture and execution in penal systems throughout the world. He was very conscious of Pentridge Gaol being an important part of the Wills electorate and it was that, in part, that made him active in the Howard League for Penal Reform and in the Anti-Hanging Council in Victoria.

In politics, despite the rhetoric that he often used in debate, he was essentially a conciliator, maintaining excellent personal relations with members of other parties. Within the ALP, although he was identified for a long time with the ruling group in the Victorian executive, he hated what he used to call `administrative violence' and he was always very concerned that dissenters such as me and from time to time the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) would be `donged'. He was always anxious to do what he could to make sure that the `dongings' did not take place. So I am very grateful to him for that.

I wanted to conclude by saying something about Gordon's important role with the Parliamentary Library and in particular with the oral history work for the library. He was very anxious to push for work to be done by the library to mark Australia's bicentenary because he wanted to disseminate knowledge of the Federal Parliament. I agree entirely with the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. BROWN) that he was essentially a parliament man.

As a result of his encouragement and that of the late Senator John Knight and Brenda McAvoy of the Parliamentary Library, and with advice from a group of Canberra academics, the bicentenary publications project was brought into being and given the task of supervising a range of books about the Australian Parliament, and Gordon became a foundation member of the Bicentenary Publications Projects Advisory Board from 1981.

He advocated producing biographical material on Federal parliamentarians and then promoted the oral history project. He then took a very active role in the project, and participated as one of the three interviewers who met and assessed applicants for the position of interviewers. He conducted four interviews himself of former colleagues and gave his own interview, which amounted to 26 hours in length. Perhaps it was only part heard, but it is regarded as one of the best interviews in the project. He approached many former colleagues to encourage them to be recorded, and much of the success of the project was due to his participation and encouragement. The oral history project was another lasting memorial to the historical awareness, the unbounded enthusiasm and the imagination of Gordon Bryant. He was also a visiting fellow in political science at La Trobe University, where he was a lively and stimulating presence.

I cannot resist mentioning that he had his own way of fighting back against a system which he thought was unjust. In those freewheeling days of the Whitlam Ministry, which many will recall, there were a lot of people who-it was alleged-were inclined to drink and smoke during Cabinet meetings. From my recollection of what things were like, this does not happen so much now. Members of the Cabinet had to contribute $40 per month. Gordon was a teetotaller, and he did not smoke either. He felt that this was an outrageous form of imposing a tax to encourage other people's vice.

On the other hand, Gordon had no particular objection to eating, which is perhaps something that we share. Gordon's fight-back capacity was to order meat pies, which he would lavishly cover with Australia's national drink, and consume them. He felt that in this way he was getting back a share of his own contribution. He was even known to slip the odd pie out of Cabinet for afters in what used to be irreverently known as a `person-bag'.

Gordon has left an enduring mark on all those who knew him. I was proud to have him as a friend and mentor and with other members, I join in this condolence motion to express my profound feeling to Pat Bryant and Robin and Linton.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock Mr P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was my great privilege to know Gordon Bryant and to witness his performance as a Minister. From the comments of the honourable member who spoke before me, one would appreciate that Gordon would never be categorised as an economic rationalist, but he certainly made a very significant contribution in his two areas of ministerial responsibility. The time at which I particularly came to know him well was when the Fraser Government came to office and he became a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal Affairs which I chaired.

SPEECH.PARA: I can very much identify with those comments that have been made today about his conviction and the compassionate interest that he had in the plight of our Aboriginal people. I identify very much with those comments about the interest he took in younger people and their education.

I would say that I fitted that last category because one of the first references that the Committee had when I was its Chair related to the alcohol problems of Aboriginals. Along with Bill Wentworth, Les Johnson, Peter Drummond and Sam Calder, Gordon Bryant and I went to the Northern Territory for the purpose of undertaking that particular reference. As we travelled in the HS748 aircraft from here to the Northern Territory, we passed a town in South Australia called Leigh Creek. As we landed, Gordon pointed out that this town was lavished with many of the facilities that most of us take for granted in the centres in which we live-all the infrastructure which is so important to our lifestyles. He said, `Look at the swimming pools, the city halls, the roads and the telephones'. He pointed them all out to me and then he said, `When we get to Bathurst Island and you see a community of much the same size, have a look at it and see whether much the same infrastructure is in place for those people who are living in much the same sort of an environment and you will have some better appreciation of the needs and aspirations of Aboriginal people and why something should be done about it'. That was a lesson for me and it is one that I am glad to be able to recall and share today.
It was a great privilege to know Gordon Bryant. He made a very significant contribution and I am pleased to be able to join in this condolence motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes The Hon G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want first to sympathise with Gordon's family. I knew Gordon Bryant for a long time and served with him here for some 13 years. Gordon was a person who believed that the establishment, particularly the Treasury, was there to prevent things being done and to protect the establishment. He practised that in every way that he possibly could. When the phone rang and Gordon was on the end of it, his first remark would be, `Comrade, what have you done for democracy today?'. He was an effervescent character and he was always doing things.

SPEECH.PARA: Gordon Bryant represented people more than most and rarely made excuses for why things could not be done. He had a reputation for administration which was not enviable and also not altogether fair. The Whitlam Government came to office after a long period in opposition and, in an effort to correct what had been up until then an area of gross neglect, more funds were allocated to the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio than the processes of government through the Public Service methods could handle. Gordon short-circuited that process to his own personal disadvantage at a later time when he was told by committees of this Parliament and the Auditor-General that he had used methods which were inappropriate. It never worried Gordon. What did worry Gordon was that he was denied the opportunity to defend himself, even though subsequently he was proven right.

In his electorate Gordon believed in educating people about the political processes and because he did not see any real future in the Melbourne Herald-Sun group as anything other than protectors of the establishment he was very active in running the Coburg Citizen. He was a pamphleteer-one of the last, I suppose, in the political process in Australia; we have now gone to letters. He was dedicated to that process and put in many, many hours of work. As has already been said, he would talk to everyone he could talk to. If he entered a room, he certainly was known very quickly because he made it known who he was, what he was and then asked for people's opinions. I am not sure whether he listened to them but he certainly told them his.

On one occasion just after I came to the Parliament, he attended an Inter-Parliamentary Union conference. He had made friends with a number of the delegates, including some from Mongolia and Afghanistan, and had promised to visit both of those countries. He did so on his way home. In the late 1960s he drove a car from England, through the Continent to Japan. He was met by an honour guard in Afghanistan. Although he was two days late, the colonel with the guard was still there to meet him. He eventually went by ferry from Japan to Ulan Bator to visit the Mongolians. I was at a conference some time later when delegates from Mongolia asked after Gordon Bryant.

He did make an impression. But I suppose one of the things that one can say about Gordon Bryant is that he never stopped trying during his whole life for those people he believed he represented and the causes that he supported. He was a debater in this Parliament, not a contributor. I can recall the first session at which Norm Foster and Al Grassby were in this place. They were both noted contributors who spoke on every possible occasion. I think Al Grassby had spoken 39 times in the autumn session of the first Parliament of which he was a member. Gordon Bryant had contributed more. He knew every way that there was of raising a matter in the Parliament.

On another occasion, he nearly got a couple of then conservative Ministers-but it would not have made any difference; the Labor establishment would have done the same thing-thrown out of the Ministry because they voted for 10 o'clock closing. He got a Standing Orders motion to a tie to have the Parliament get up at 10 o'clock each night. Five of Billy McMahon's Ministers voted for the motion and they all appeared in his office shortly afterwards.

I suppose it is the nature of the man but Gordon Bryant told a story of going along to a branch meeting in Coburg, and I should say that he represented an area with an enormous history in Labor politics. It was one of the few areas which have consistently refused to accept whatever was cast on them. It sent Maurice Blackburn, and his wife as an independent, to this Parliament and elected Charlie Mutton for almost a lifetime as an independent member for Coburg.

Gordon Bryant used to attend branch meetings almost as an act of faith-and he did not have the New South Wales preselection system to drive him on. But on one occasion he said, `Well, the system really is unfair. Here are Jack Walton and I sitting at the front of the branch, as we always do, and Jack Galbally has turned up for the first time probably in five years and they cheer him'. But I think Gordon was a person who contributed much. He was a parliamentary performer. He believed in the process.

He took part in the defence of his country, and he opposed the Vietnam war. He was wounded as a civilian soldier, but got himself fit to join the Australian Imperial Force and served abroad. Before he joined the Services, he was actually blown up in an accident with a hand grenade, which would have rendered most people unable to contribute.

He is honoured by all of those who knew him. I suppose that it is the nature of the man that there is no-one I know of on either side of politics who has a bad word for him, even though there are those who believe that his administrative policies were something less than they would have expected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dobie The Hon J.D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on Gordon Bryant almost at his command. Gordon Bryant was all the things that everybody has said today: honourable, a family man-everything that is proper and right. I think what most speakers have forgotten to mention is that he was also a controversial man, and that he thoroughly enjoyed being controversial.

SPEECH.PARA: As people have said, he was a great parliamentarian. But in the 24 years since I first came in here, he is the only person I have known who, when ordered out of the Parliament, refused to leave. Mr Speaker, for your future guidance, he would not leave because he said that he did not believe that he had done what the Speaker of the day said he had done. The only way that they could get him out was to close the Parliament. It resumed half an hour later.

Gordon Bryant and I knew each other reasonably well. I always used to criticise him for not having left the chamber. One day, not so very long ago, he said, `Don, I want you to promise me that, if there is ever an obituary for me in the Parliament and you are there, you will raise this issue, firstly to show that I had a spirit of independence and secondly to show that my regard for Parliament was so high and so deep that, when such nonsense was performed in putting me out, I believe that future parliaments should know about it'. And so I do just that today.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had better tell Tuckey about that.

—As the honourable member for Menzies has said, we should tell other people, but we have a different Speaker today. The second thing I want to raise relates to what the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) was saying about Gordon Bryant's Parliamentary Library interests. It is all true. Gordon was almost fanatical about things connected with the Library. I never sat on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on the Library with him, but our friendship started because of our constant discussion of books-discussion which, of course, I still enjoy with the honourable member for Lalor.

SPEECH.PARA: Gordon Bryant was in great trouble because the Library Committee in those days had control of both the National Library and the Parliamentary Library. The National Library had the opportunity of buying a rare, internationally famous collection of Portuguese works. Gordon was absolutely enthusiastic and, as some speakers have said, that meant a lot. The Library finished up buying the collection because he believed that if a library or nation was to be famous or sound it should have broad vision. He said that with one of our neighbours speaking Portuguese-namely, East Timor-it was important that our National Library should have these major Portuguese works. I just mention those two points because they have not been raised before.

Everybody talks about his sense of humour. I remember him for that, but I also remember him for his sense of fun. In this Parliament, he was the man of the grand gesture. He did not make a speech with his hands in his pockets, as I do now. He demonstrated; he was full-blooded about everything he said. I think it is a shame that we do not have more people like Gordon around today, and I regret to say that we are not likely to have them in future years.
I apologise to Mrs Bryant and to the boys for not having been able to pay my last tributes to him but, as I stand here today, they will know that I am paying them to him now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tickner The Hon R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not going to make a contribution to this condolence motion but was prompted to do so by the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). The comments of the Leader of the Opposition reflected in part on Gordon Bryant's role in promoting the Aboriginal affairs policies in this Parliament and throughout Australia. I would not have spoken had I not had the opportunity to meet and work with Gordon Bryant, not in the Parliament but some considerable time after he had left the Parliament, because even though he was no longer here he still maintained that commitment to Aboriginal affairs and in the mid-1980s was a very active campaigner, continuing to attend this Parliament and other places in support of the Aboriginal cause.

SPEECH.PARA: I was able to attend his funeral, as others have referred to. The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), at Gordon Bryant's funeral, commented that there was almost a demarcation in the funeral with, on the one side, returned personnel and, on the other side, quite radical people of the peace movement, yet all those people had come together to honour Gordon Bryant on that occasion.

However, there is one matter that has not been referred to in any substance in the course of this condolence motion but ought to be referred to, and that concerns the role of Gordon in championing the cause of the 1967 referendum. The Leader of the Opposition, to his great credit, made reference to Gordon Bryant's moves and support for the right of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to have a real say in matters affecting their future. Of course, it should be recorded that was it not for Gordon Bryant and, indeed, many others-but, in particular, I think it is important to recognise Gordon Bryant-in pushing for that 1967 referendum, so much that has happened since that time in this Federal Parliament simply could not have occurred. The fact is that the establishment of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission is based on that Federal power conferred on the Commonwealth in 1967.

It should also be recorded that Gordon Bryant was a conciliator and worked tirelessly in the period leading up to that referendum to build bridges with the Opposition and, indeed, secured the support of numerous members of the Opposition, including Billy Wentworth, who actively supported that cause. In showing us the way forward, he left an enduring contribution to the Parliament and the country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to join in this condolence motion as one who had a relationship with Gordon Bryant which went back to the late 1940s. In the early 1950s he and I were part of a minority group within the Australian Labor Party which was such a minority that it did not even deserve a title. It could not ascribe to ever being a faction, but in 1955 we saw this small group, which in many ways represented, as Gordon himself did, the views and aspirations of working people, become a majority and Gordon Bryant came into the Federal Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that he became a parliamentarian did not change in any way his basic philosophy, beliefs or attitude to his function in his own Party. He was always a man who espoused radical causes. As my colleague the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) said, he was more than happy to encourage younger people to adopt those positions and often used his great weight and mental agility to protect us when perhaps we were more enthusiastic than we otherwise should have been.

I remember Gordon Bryant in many ways. I remember him first of all for his continued and passionate advocacy on behalf of the Aboriginal people. When I was Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, and after Gordon Bryant had left the Parliament, there were two former Ministers for Aboriginal affairs who people could often run into in the most remote parts of Australia; one was Billy Wentworth and the other was Gordon Bryant. They never lost their devotion or their commitment.

On one occasion during the Vietnam war when I did not expect to meet Gordon Bryant, I met him in a remote village in North Laos when we were visiting Mong tribesmen. He had come there by himself; I was there as part of a small delegation. The tribesmen had prepared what could be described only as a mysterious alcoholic brew, which was served in a great pot with one straw. As Gordon was the elder of the group, it would be his task to take the first sip. I thought that this would be something of a difficulty for Gordon, who was all his life a teetotaller. I reminded him of his long period of abstinence, and all he could say was, `Comrade, if I die instantly, I do not expect you to drink it'.

Gordon Bryant was a man of great compassion. When I came into the Parliament it was my great privilege to sit next to him. If there was one thing as certain as day follows night, it was that when the Leader of the House would do as Leaders of the House are wont to do from time to time-that is, move the guillotine-Gordon Bryant would be on his feet. Those who are in opposition and still feel some injustice about those matters-which most of us on this side of the House have suffered more than current members of the Opposition have-could do far worse than read Gordon Bryant's speeches on those occasions when he defended the Parliament as an institution, and not for the sake of it, but because he genuinely believed that this was the place where views had to be expressed and where arguments had to be fought out. He thought that any kind of injunction which restrained that was brewed in hell and was the work of the devil.

Gordon Bryant has left his mark upon the Labor Party and upon this institution. As a Minister, he was deeply involved in the discussions about the siting of the new Parliament House and the way in which the building would be formed. In a sense we all owe him a debt. I am only sorry that I could not be present at his funeral, because at that stage I was very deep in Arnhem Land doing things which would have been very close to Gordon's heart. He will be missed by the people who knew him and loved him in the Labor Party and he will be missed by his colleagues on all sides of the Parliament. I extend my deepest regrets and sympathies to Pat and his sons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to add a couple of observations to this condolence motion. I chuckled to myself when the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in moving the motion, made the observation that he found Gordon a difficult act to follow as the member for Wills. When I was first elected, the electorates of Burke and Wills adjoined each other. In one of the very early phone calls I got, I was asked to ring Gordon Bryant. When a new member of parliament is rung by one of his heroes from the past who wants to talk to him, that new member immediately responds. So I rang Gordon, and he said, `You are the new young bloke for Burke?'. I said yes, and he said, `Well, I am the old fellow from Wills. You can call me the ghost who walks, because Bob will be pretty busy so I am still looking after the electorate and I would like you to help me out a bit with it'. We developed a bit of a relationship. Every time Bob took a position or did something Gordon thought might have gone in another direction, I would get a phone call from the ghost who walks.

SPEECH.PARA: I too would like to make an observation on his funeral. I was quite taken by the fact that at a State funeral there was such a range of people, from the Governor-General, former Speakers of the Parliament and the Prime Minister's wife through to very ordinary people from his former constituency of Coburg. It was an extraordinary experience to see that range of people turn out to pay their last respects to Gordon and particularly to see his former service colleagues pay him the tribute that was owing.

I was taken by the story that one of the State members of parliament, Giovanni Sgro, told at the funeral as an illustration of just how Gordon Bryant had his electorate of Wills under control-he was known as the people's man. One very busy Saturday morning when the tram was slowly crawling down Sydney Road, Coburg, the tram driver stopped the tram, got out, stopped all of the traffic and insisted that Gordon Bryant cross the road in front of everyone and, apparently, he did that without protest.

My other reason for briefly commenting today is that during the period of the last Parliament the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs conducted an inquiry into the ways in which we might foster the active involvement of retired people in the community and I think the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services (Mr Staples) is in the process of responding to that at the moment. Gordon, through his activities with the Yarra Valley University of the Third Age, followed that inquiry everywhere and rang me constantly to find out how it was going. In doing so, he demonstrated his continuing interest in the affairs of the Parliament and the things that we might be doing to better the lot of people in all sorts of situations.
I would like to add my thoughts to this motion and join with the Parliament in passing my condolences to Pat and to Gordon's family.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable members standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER
