Ted Robertson died on 7 January 1991. He represented the Northern Territory from 1975 to 1987. During this period he was a very active member of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, served on the branch executive for a considerable period and represented the Parliament in this capacity, both in Australia and overseas.

INTERJECT.PARA: Norman Parkes, who died on 29 January 1991, was Clerk of the House of Representatives from 1971 to 1976. It may interest honourable members to know that his father was also the Clerk of the House. Mr Parkes was a respected officer who served the Parliament with distinction for 42 years. After Norm Parkes's death I received a letter from former Speaker, Jim Cope, which I would like to read to the House. It says:

Having served as a Temporary Chairman of Committees for several years and later for two years as Speaker during the period of Norman Parkes as Clerk of the House of Representatives, I received splendid advice, assistance and cooperation from Norman; as a result, a good and lasting friendship developed between us. His sad and untimely passing came as a great shock to me and I would like to be associated with any motion of regret which might be passed in the House of Representatives.
As a mark of respect to the memory of the deceased, I invite honourable members to rise in their places.
Honourable members having stood in their places-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That:

(1) the House authorises live broadcast and rebroadcast of House of Representatives proceedings, excluding debate on a motion for the adjournment of the House on television for a trial period from 12 February 1991; and
(2) access to the proceedings of the House of Representatives for the televising of proceedings is subject to an undertaking to observe, and to comply with, the following conditions:
(a) Televising may occur and recordings may be made only from channel 1 on the House monitoring system.
(b) Televising shall be used only for the purposes of fair and accurate reports of proceedings, and shall not be used for:
(i) political party advertising or election campaigns;
(ii) satire or ridicule;
(iii) commercial sponsorship or commercial advertising; or
(iv) television station advertisements or promotion.
(c) Reports of proceedings shall be such as to provide a balanced presentation of differing views.

(d) Remarks in respect of which a Member claims misrepresentation or otherwise seeks withdrawal, and which are subsequently ordered to be withdrawn, or are voluntarily withdrawn, are not to be rebroadcast.

(e) If the Speaker orders that a remark be deleted from Hansard, either at the time the remark was made or at a later time, the remark, the Speaker's direction and the proceedings relating to the matter, are not to be rebroadcast.
(f) Debate on a motion for the adjournment of the House shall not be broadcast.
(g) Points of order are not to be rebroadcast.
(h) Footage must be broadcast at normal speed without use of a freeze frame. Split screen shots are not to be used. Only synchronised sound and vision shall be rebroadcast.
(i) Non compliance with the guidelines listed above will incur the following penalties for the stations involved:
(i) first breach-access to the broadcast service withdrawn for three sitting days;
(ii) second breach-access to the broadcast service withdrawn for six sitting days; or
(iii) such other penalty as is agreed by the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings.
(j) The instructions of the Speaker of the House of Representatives or the Speaker's delegates in respect of the broadcasting which are not inconsistent with these conditions, shall be observed.

Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to a couple of matters related to this motion. The first is that it is provisional-it relates to this block of sittings. This is a trial period: we will see how these terms and conditions work out and the Parliament will have an opportunity to determine an attitude to that in the Budget sittings.

By and large, these regulations laid down in the motion are in line with those established earlier by the Senate to govern its proceedings. However, there are some differences. This motion contains penalties for breaches in the rebroadcast area. It also contains more detail on how the issue of misrepresentation and subsequent withdrawal should be handled in rebroadcast. Otherwise, as I said, these propositions are much in line with those previously carried by the Senate, which have governed its proceedings to this point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fife The Hon W.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the decision by the Government to televise the proceedings of the House of Representatives. Our only concern, of course, is that it has taken so long for the Government to take this decision and to move the motion that has just been moved by the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley). On this issue, like so many issues, the Government has been moving at a snail's pace. When this building was opened in May 1988 it was complete with the technical facilities required to televise Parliament. From a technical point of view, we could have televised the House of Representatives and the Senate very soon after, if not from the time, the building was completed.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that on the first sitting day of this Parliament on 8 May of last year, in his comments on your election, Mr Speaker, the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) urged the Government to work towards raising the standards of Parliament. He subsequently urged the Government to allow the televising of the House of Representatives. At that time the Leader of the Opposition said that he believed that this would go a long way towards improving the standards of this chamber and improving the public's perception of politicians and the political process in Australia. As we all know, our standing in the community is not as high as it should be. There is a sense of disillusionment in the community about politicians, about what they promise and about what they deliver.

It must be said, Mr Speaker, that the quality of debate in this chamber, which at times includes personal vilification and language, if used in a pub, would incite a brawl. This has added, of course, to the public's sense of disenchantment with politics. By televising Parliament and opening the procedures of this chamber to television viewers around Australia, I believe that we will be imposing a discipline upon ourselves, and in particular upon the Government, to raise our standards, address the urgent issues which confront our nation and show the people who voted for us that we can responsibly represent their interests.

I hope that the passage of the motion that is before the House will result in answers to questions being more relevant than they have been in the past. I believe that there is already evidence that this House will sit for longer periods than in the past. I suspect and I hope that the guillotine will be used more sparingly than it has been used in the past.

During the course of the past year there have been several occasions on which the Leader of the Opposition has raised with the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) the desirability of allowing the televising of Parliament. A motion moved in this House at the end of the previous autumn session was opposed by the Government. For some reason the Government has been slow in the extreme in accepting our proposals. In fact, it was only last Friday, with almost indecent haste, that the Leader of the Opposition was advised that the House of Representatives would be open to television from today.

That said, the Opposition welcomes the Government's decision. This, I believe, will go down as a significant day in the history of the Australian Parliament. I acknowledge the comments made by the Leader of the House that this is for a trial period. Our side of the House, along with the Government, will want to review the operation of the procedures and the guidelines that are contained in this motion. It has already been brought to my attention that the procedures that are proposed are more restrictive than those that apply in the House of Commons. For example, in the House of Commons the cameras are allowed to pan around the chamber during Question Time. This, of course, makes it more interesting for the viewers. The Opposition welcomes this belated motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call on the Leader of the House (Mr Beazley) to explain to the Parliament why the exclusions include points of order. Mr Speaker, with due respect, paragraphs (d) and (e) of the exclusions quite clearly give you the opportunity to exclude any abuse of the point of order privilege. On the other hand, we have just spoken for one hour about a man who is held in hugely high regard, Gordon Bryant, for his defence of the parliamentary institution. Surely the point of order is fundamental to the parliamentary debate and, consequently, the parliamentary institution-particularly when the government of the day is abusing the processes of the Parliament and can be brought to order only by a point of order. Surely the content of that point of order should be made available to the general public.

—I want to make just a couple of brief comments. I am pleased to support the principle of this motion. Having come from a local government body that has allowed open access to television for the last 10 years without any problems whatsoever, I am surprised that the Government has found it necessary to add so many conditions. As it is a trial period, the Government could have given totally open access. In fact, some of the conditions, particularly the one concerning satire or ridicule, are certainly not within the control of the media. In fact, if we enforce that condition we cannot have television.
—Just before I put the question, I advise the honourable member for Hume that wide-angled shots of the chamber will be allowed during both divisions and Question Time.

—The resolution just passed represents a step along the road to parliamentary reform. As honourable members on both sides of the House have mentioned, a set of guidelines will be provided to the media and to members. I hope that those guidelines outlined in the resolution will assist in ensuring a responsible approach by the media to the televising of Parliament.

—Mr Speaker, as a matter of courtesy, I inform the House that His Excellency the Governor-General on Friday, 1 February 1991 appointed the Hon. Neal Blewett Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. Dr Blewett is now responsible for development assistance issues, as well as trade negotiations.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Last Sunday on television the Prime Minister admitted that he and the Treasurer sometimes expressed things differently. I can understand that; but I ask the Prime Minister: did he or did he not deliberately engineer the recession?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we deliberately did was face the fact that we had a position where, in these precise terms, expenditure in the Australian economy was increasing by 10 per cent, with production increasing by 5 per cent. If that had been allowed to go on we would have had a totally unsustainable position in terms of inflation and our current account and foreign debt situation. So, responsibly, we took those decisions within the framework of an existing tight fiscal and wages policy to tighten monetary policy to meet those requirements.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have pointed out, we acknowledge that in the process many people around this country have suffered pain, and we regret that fact. It is the fact that we will come out of this recession in this year, and as an Australian economy we will come out of it much stronger because we have now beaten down inflation to a point where the underlying rate, as disclosed by the official statistics, is at the lowest figure it has been since those records have been kept. We have already achieved a 28 per cent improvement in the first six months of this year in our current account deficit, compared with the previous year. The current account deficit, as against the Budget forecast of $18 billion, is running at $8.1 billion for the first six months.

Those decisions were not ones we gladly took. We knew that there would be pain, but we would have been much more irresponsible, in the judgment of the Australian electorate as time went on, if we had not been prepared to take those necessary decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also for the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the progress of the military operations in the Gulf? Can he also inform the House of the situation of our three naval ships? Most importantly, could he inform the House of the prospects for future peace?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not unduly take up the time of the House, Mr Speaker, but I am sure that all honourable members would like to hear a brief report on the matters raised in the question by the honourable member.
— Make a statement.

—There is no point in making a statement every day, or every second day. I give the House the assurance that the time of the House for other questions will not be taken up. I believe the people of Australia would want to hear, briefly, a report on these matters.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Speaker, allied forces have achieved significant results while suffering few casualties. Iraq's chemical, biological and nuclear production facilities have been severely damaged, and their capacities in this area have been set back very many years; the Scud missile capability has been significantly reduced; Iraq's air force has surrendered the skies; the Iraqi navy has been largely destroyed; and the military and strategic infrastructure of Iraq has been severely damaged. The air strikes, as honourable members would know, I think, are now concentrating on Iraq's ground forces in and around Kuwait. I will not add to the speculation about the timing of a ground offensive, but President Bush has made it clear publicly and privately to me that nothing will rush him into a ground war. The allies will move if and when it suits them. They control the tempo of the war.

Australia's ships have been continually involved in operations in the Gulf. Success has been replaced by Westralia, which is now replenishing allied ships in the Gulf. Sydney and Brisbane have spent most of their time with the Midway carrier group, but each has also undertaken other escort duties with ships from a number of allied navies. Our ships have not been directly attacked and have sustained no damage or casualties, but I remind the House that mines and air launched missiles remain a serious hazard.

Let me finally go to the question of the post-war prospect and say that the war, of course, can end at any time-whenever Saddam Hussein decides to leave Kuwait. Otherwise it will end when his armies are driven out and regional security is restored, as authorised by the United Nations resolutions. It is important to know that the allies are now looking ahead to make sure that when the war ends we can work together to establish a new framework for peace in the Middle East, encompassing not only the Gulf region but the important issues of the security of Israel, the rights and interests of the Palestinian people and, not least importantly, to try to get peace into that tragic country of Lebanon. Australia will play whatever role is appropriate in these efforts.
In recent days President Bush and Prime Minister Major have called me and have indicated their commitment to addressing these issues determinedly and constructively.

I would close by saying that I am sure all honourable members will join me in wishing our sailors in the Gulf well, and in hoping that when their work is finished we can all together help to make the total Middle East region a better and safer place in which to live.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is to the Prime Minister, and it is a follow-up question to the previous question where, if I understood the Prime Minister correctly, he said that he did not deliberately set out to engineer a recession, yet the Treasurer has said on the record that he did deliberately set out to engineer a recession-`This is a recession we had to have'-so why does the Prime Minister not sack him?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest that the Leader of the Opposition should take the trouble, if he cannot hear, to read what I had to say. He will see there that what I have had to say in answer to his first question is totally consistent with the things that I and the Treasurer have said in terms of the responsibility that this Government had to undertake to meet the challenges confronting us.

ANSWER.PARA: I would suggest that when he does his reading he might also wonder whether he still adheres to what he had to say about the timing of decision-making when he criticised the Treasurer and myself and the Reserve Bank in January of last year, when we began the process of easing monetary policy. It was the beginning of six successive reductions which have brought down interest rates. On that occasion, he said:
The Treasurer, his Government, indeed the Reserve Bank, should hang their heads in shame.

The clear position of the Leader of the Opposition is that this Government has erred in easing monetary policy as early and as quickly as we have done. Rather than trying to find some position between the Treasurer and myself, he should start to analyse his own inadequate decision and ask himself whether he still believes that this Government began to ease monetary policy too early last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories inform the House on how the Government is responding to the major oil spill in the Persian Gulf?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Iraq's action is a deliberate act of environmental vandalism, is clearly against customary international law and has been condemned by the Prime Minister and other Ministers. I point out for the information of the House that the oil spill is equivalent to about 11 million barrels of oil. From the northernmost point it extends 300 kilometres in length and it comprises six separate oil slicks of varying sizes.

ANSWER.PARA: Australia is party to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development environment Ministers' statement of 30 January this year, which condemned the release of oil and confirmed the readiness of OECD countries to assist states in the region in combating the oil spill. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has offered to provide the Government of Saudi Arabia with booms, skimmers and beach cleaning units for use in the Gulf.

Saudi Arabia has requested the services of two Australian marine environment experts to advise on the protection of dugongs and sea turtles. I am pleased to announce that my Department is providing funds for two scientists, Mr Tony Preen and Dr Tony Chiffings, to travel to the Gulf to assist in the international effort to clear the oil spill.

I believe there is a need for Australia to consider how best it can further assist to combat the environmental problems in the region caused by the war. Recently, I wrote to the Prime Minister on this matter, and officials are currently preparing advice to Ministers on options for the Australian response, and I shall keep the House informed of progress.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Prime Minister to a question asked in the other place this afternoon by my colleague the shadow Minister for defence, Senator Durack, of the Minister for Defence, Senator Ray, about the report in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning by Greg Austin, which alleged that Australia had increased its commitment in the Gulf by sending up to 10 military intelligence specialists to Saudi Arabia. I refer the Prime Minister specifically to Senator Ray's answer when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I am not going to make an announcement every time there is a minor change to the numbers in the Gulf.
I ask the Prime Minister whether he stands by the statement of Senator Ray; whether this is consistent with his undertaking to consult and his undertaking to keep the people of Australia informed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable gentleman for his question, and let me cover this matter in its entirety. We have referred frequently to the presence in the Gulf of Australian Defence Force (ADF) personnel serving on exchange with forces of the United States and the United Kingdom, and I will go to those references. For example, I referred to them specifically in my statement on 17 January. I quote what I had then to say:

ANSWER.PARA: Our thoughts go to these ships' crews, to the medical teams serving on the hospital ships, to the logistic support team in the region, and to the Australians serving on exchange with other allied forces in the Gulf.

The number of such people fluctuates-today the figure is 28. Some of these people are involved in the planning function, which includes intelligence. I announced that the ADF would become involved in such activities in my statement to the Parliament on 4 December. Let me remind honourable members of what I had to say on that occasion:

The Government will now authorise the Australian Defence Force (ADF) to deploy ships of our task force from the Gulf of Oman into the Persian Gulf to exercise and operate with allied naval forces in preparation for that role.
The ADF will also now participate in allied military planning.
Senator Ray has also discussed this publicly. I will refer to what he had to say at one of his press conferences:

We have people involved in the planning process, both in Riyadh and in the Naval Command. Now I'm not going to go into any more detail on that, but they do get access to all information, are actively involved and they will bring back some very valuable lessons.

So there we have those three statements-two by myself and one by the Minister. The deployment of exchange personnel, as I think you, Mr Speaker, will appreciate, is a long established element of our Gulf commitment. It is not an escalation of any sort.

From the beginning, I have valued the support of the Opposition generally and of the Leader of the Opposition, in particular, for the Government's position in this matter. However, if the Opposition begins to criticise the Government in any respect, it ought to get a more substantial basis for its criticism than anything that is reported in the Sydney Morning Herald because that is a very unworthy and unsound basis of support.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would the Minister for Employment, Education and Training advise the House what action is being taken on the citizenship visits program?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have referred to the citizenship visits program in the House on earlier occasions. It was designed to encourage schoolchildren to visit the national Parliament and other national institutions. We have just taken a decision to televise the proceedings of the Parliament. I have not always been entirely convinced about the reasons for that decision, but, nevertheless, we have now decided to do it and, at the very least, it will transmit our disembodied images into the living rooms of Australia. I might say, though, that there is nothing quite like being here. The reason for this program is to ensure that young Australians at school can have the opportunity to visit the national Parliament, not just to see the proceedings within the chamber, but also to learn more about the operations of the Parliament.

ANSWER.PARA: This project was started as a pilot program funded under the projects of national significance program. As a result of the pilot program, the matter was reviewed and a decision was taken to make the program permanent. The decision to make the program permanent was based on its very great success. Within the brief life of the pilot, more than 6,500 schoolchildren visited the Parliament. Probably almost all of those children would not have visited had this program not been in existence. They visited here at an average cost of just under $100 each.

At present, the program is funded by my Department and administered by the Serjeant-at-Arms. From the beginning of next year it will be funded entirely from the appropriations to the Parliament. Until the end of this financial year, it will continue to be funded through my portfolio.

School visits to the Parliament are no new thing, but we discovered that almost all of those schoolchildren visiting Parliament came from nearby schools in Victoria, New South Wales and, of course, the ACT. In the six months preceding the commencement of the citizenship visits program, fewer than 500 children from the States of Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia and Tasmania and from the Northern Territory had visited the Parliament. In the time that the program was operating, that figure increased to about 6,000 children.

The program provides a subsidy of $50 for each student travelling between 1,000 and 2,000 kilometres, $100 for those travelling between 2,000 and 3,000 kilometres, and $200 for those travelling beyond 3,000 kilometres-with a special provision of those from Tasmania receiving a subsidy of $100. I think it is important to realise that not only will this provide the opportunity for these schoolchildren from other States to visit the national Parliament and see its proceedings but also it will provide them with an opportunity to learn more about the workings of democracy itself. Through the education unit of the Parliament, they will be introduced to the way in which the electoral system works and a number of the other provisions of our democratic process.

If we are going to maintain the kind of enthusiasm that exists in this country for parliamentary democracy at a time when we see representative parliaments, representative democracy, becoming more and more fashionable around the world, it is important for us to encourage an adherence to those views by young people within our own community. There is no substitute, I think, for encouraging young people to come to Parliament to see how it works and, therefore, to develop a respect not only for this institution but also for the democratic process which this institution serves.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Is the Minister aware of promises made by spokesmen for the Australian Labor Party Government in both Houses when introducing the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Bill that controversial developments with significant environmental effects would be examined in a public inquiry before any decision was made? Does the Minister agree that the proposed third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport is controversial and has significant environmental effects? Will the Minister direct that a full public inquiry be held and, if not, why not?
—No wonder you gave him the call.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: THE ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Was there any bias in the calling of that honourable member?
—I thought it was a very good question.

—The draft environmental impact statement was released for public review on 20 September 1990 and written submissions on the draft EIS were accepted until 3 January 1991. The EIS and supporting documents are now widely available in Sydney and in country areas of New South Wales and in each State and Territory.

ANSWER.PARA: There have been almost 1,900 individual submissions, some of which are very substantial. These have been received and are now being examined by my Department. Copies of all of the submissions have been passed on to the Federal Airports Corporation, which will prepare and submit to my Department a final EIS which takes into account all of the submissions that have been received. My Department will then prepare an independent assessment report on the final EIS to assist me in providing my advice to the Government before final decisions are made.

So the third runway proposal, as one can see from that process, has been subject to intensive examination and the public has had ample opportunity to consider the proposal and to make its views known. A public inquiry would be very expensive and time consuming and I am, therefore, not persuaded that an inquiry would add materially to our understanding of the issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. I ask: can he explain to the House what safety nets the Government has put in place to protect families on low incomes and families affected by unemployment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —During times of economic slowdown or periods in which there is increasing--

—One does not expect from the Opposition the question of unemployment or the social protection of people who are unemployed to be taken seriously. To answer the question, the approach of the Government is that of an integrated one, achieving our goals of security, protection and fairness for low income families affected by relatively high unemployment.

ANSWER.PARA: In 1989 the Commonwealth Government renegotiated, for example, increased funding of public housing and home purchase assistance for low income families through the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. The number of home purchase loans increased from about 11,500 eight years ago to a planned 40,000 this year. About 30 per cent of all first home buyers are getting help to buy their homes through this program.

The Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement has seen a major expansion of public rental housing stock, from 270,000 in 1984 to 360,000 this year. The Government has also substantially increased rent assistance for families with children which are renting privately, recognising that housing costs can be a disproportionately high cost for those families. Rent assistance for families with three or more children has risen over the last seven years from $10 to $40 a week. In real terms, it has increased by 140 per cent. For families with one or two children, it has risen from $10 to $35, or by 109 per cent, and it will be indexed from March this year. Families eligible for a family allowance supplement are also eligible for rent assistance.

More than half a million families with some 1.2 million children are being helped to meet the costs of bringing up their children through the family allowance supplement and payments for children through the pension and benefits system. The value of payments for children under 13 has been set at 15 per cent of the married rate of pension, currently $26.50 a week, and for children aged 13 to 15 at 20 per cent of the married rate of pension, currently $38.65 a week. This will maintain the real value of those payments. For families of the unemployed, there has been that setting of the benchmark of 15 per cent of the married pension rate for younger children and 20 per cent for older children. In addition, the family allowance is now set at a higher rate and indexed. The total payment for an unemployed family with two children under 13 which rents privately is $331.20 a week. This is a rise in real income of 24 per cent since 1983. This compares with the declining value of unemployment payments to families from 1975 to 1983.

The reason I am making this serious point is that in the period 1975 to 1983 we saw the real level of assistance to families of the unemployed decline, whereas during the period of this Government, in which we have had some uncharacteristic rises in unemployment, the safety net has been strengthened so that the real level of payments, particularly for those families most in need, has not only substantially increased but has increased in proportion with the needs of those families. For example, families with older children or renting families receive the bulk of the assistance under our approach. Family payments for low income families have contributed to increasing the real income levels of the poorest 10 per cent of two parent families by 12 per cent and of sole parent families by 15 per cent.

This Government's approach, as I suggested at the beginning, is an integrated approach. It is not simply a question of housing; it is not simply a question of income support for families. We have also shown that commitment in terms of health, with Medicare, which is a very important part of the safety net. One does not have a poverty trap in terms of health insurance, as one has in the United States, but one has safety net protection and, in terms of the universality of Medicare, a guarantee of continuing assistance in health for people as they return to the work force.

It is not simply one element, but the overall approach, the integrated approach, that means that, at a time in which many Australian families are suffering from unemployment, the Government is providing an approach which is comprehensive, which is fair, which provides an effective safety net and which guarantees that at the first opportunity there is a maximum incentive for those disadvantaged families to return to the work force when jobs become available.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Treasurer. He told John Laws yesterday that the State Bank of South Australia and other State banks are not federally supervised, yet the Premier of South Australia says that his State Bank is subject to prudential supervision by the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Managing Director of the State Bank says that reports are provided to the Reserve Bank monthly, quarterly and annually. Moreover, the Reserve Bank says that it supervises all State banks. Would the Treasurer tell us who is correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have said in the House on a number of occasions that the Reserve Bank informally supervises State banks. It has for as long as I have been aware of that practice. But the fact of the matter is that the Reserve Bank has limited powers, because the powers it enjoys now arise from its power under the Reserve Bank Act under the Constitution and it has no power to put in auditors or do other things which it could do with a bank registered under the Reserve Bank Act. That is the position.

ANSWER.PARA: But the most important point in all this is that a bank is only as good as the business it takes on, and no Reserve Bank supervision can change the fact that if a bank embarks upon commercial lending which is unwise, unsound or untimely, as the case may be, regardless of the liquidity ratios being observed-and that is what the Reserve Bank would be interested in-there can be in the end losses impacting upon bank loans. That is what we have seen, I think, with the State Bank of South Australia. We have certainly seen that with the State Bank of Victoria and its subsidiary, Tricontinental Corporation Ltd. So the owner, the shareholder, must keep some supervision over those banks.

The State Premier of South Australia, Mr Bannon, made it clear that the State Premier and Treasurer there has no power under the Act. He can consult and the board can consult with him, but he has now power of direction. The point of that was an agreed position between the Government and the Opposition in South Australia that it was desirable to remove from the political process the management of the bank, given the fact that there had been adverse publicity in some other States about political management of financial assets. But I think the truth of the position is that there always has to be, in the end, responsibilities in ownership and supervision by owners.

In the case of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, the Commonwealth Bank of Australia is obliged to keep me informed of banking policies. In addition, the Managing Director of the bank is obliged to keep the Secretary of the Treasury informed of day-to-day occurrences or changes in what might otherwise be day-to-day occurrences in the bank's lending or management policies-not on a daily basis, obviously, but something which is unusual. Of course, the Secretary of the Treasury sits on the board and, may I say, the board of the Commonwealth Bank is one of the strongest in the country in terms of its representation, the people represented on the board, and it is in that way that the Commonwealth Government of Australia-in this case this Government-exercises its ownership responsibilities with the Commonwealth Bank of Australia.

In the case of State banks, one can never get away from the fact that owners will always have to manage the assets that they have employed, and the notion that one can blindly turn these over to a board without guidelines or banking policy and without some reference at timely intervals to the Government or the owner is, I think, basically a nonsense. I think that this episode demonstrates that.
There are very few governments in this country that manage their financial affairs more soundly and tightly than the Labor Government of South Australia under Premier Bannon.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Opposition members may laugh and jeer, but it has very low debt to State gross product-I think the lowest of the Australian States.
—What about the $900m for the State Bank?
—The honourable member for Mayo!

—It has been running its recurrent budgets; the outlays in real terms have been in the negative now for a number of years. The South Australian State finances are better than most Australian States-as good as the best or better. The fact that a virtually independent board has inadequately supervised the assets of the State Bank and produced these losses is something which Premier Bannon has taken responsibility for, but which we all know he could not have known about, given the arrangements which obtained.

—My question is to the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. With your indulgence, Mr Speaker, can I begin by congratulating the Prime Minister on this very appropriate ministerial rearrangement and the Minister, on behalf of the millions of people who contribute to overseas aid organisations, on his appointment. He has our best wishes.
—The honourable member for Fraser might get to the question.

—Is the Minister aware of criticisms by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid that the Government's response to the needs of the victims of the Gulf crisis has been inadequate and that the funds provided have been at the expense of other impoverished people, especially victims of famine and war in Africa? What steps has the Government taken to ensure adequate emergency assistance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Blewett The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of claims that the Government has been slow to respond to victims of the Gulf crisis and that the assistance that has been provided has been provided by diverting aid from emergency programs elsewhere. I say at the outset that both those claims are incorrect. The Government has responded positively to the humanitarian emergency needs of the Gulf crisis and our contributions to date to emergency programs now total $5m, including $0.5m that I announced this weekend in relation to an increased grant to the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestinian refugees. The Australian effort is appropriate relative to that of other donors and in the light of the current needs of the United Nations, the Red Cross and other relief agencies.

ANSWER.PARA: We should also note that the exodus from Iraq and Kuwait that was expected following the outbreak of hostilities has not occurred in the numbers anticipated. We will need to monitor both those developments and the needs of the international agencies involved in relief work. The Government has several options available for providing additional relief funds should they be needed for the Gulf crisis without diverting aid from other famine emergency programs, and I include amongst those the seeking, if it were necessary, of Budget supplementation for the aid vote.

It is important to recognise the very unpredictable nature of international emergencies and that the level of need of different areas in the world changes constantly so that we have to keep a very flexible approach in relation to our emergency funds.
In answer to the last point made by the honourable member for Fraser, so far this financial year Australia has contributed $9m in assistance to Ethiopia which is facing severe--

TALK.START.PARA: —You have the worst aid record since Australia became a donor.

—It is a very interesting comment coming from the former Opposition leader who, at the last election, suggested that the aid budget should be cut by a further $100m. I point out again, as I was pointing out when I was interrupted by that rather irrelevant comment--
—Irrelevant!
—The honourable member for Kooyong will cease interjecting.

—Australia has contributed some $9m this year in assistance to Ethiopia, which is facing severe famine affecting four million people in that country. That situation also will be kept under review so that emergency assistance funds can be used as effectively and efficiently as possible according to the current needs.

—What knowledge of the financial circumstances of the State Bank of South Australia did the Treasurer have through either the Reserve Bank of Australia or any other source prior to the statement made by Mr Bannon last weekend?
—Mr Bannon informed me a couple of days earlier. That was the first I knew of the issue at all.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TIMOR GAP ZONE OF COOPERATION TREATY

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation Treaty, can the Minister for Resources inform the House what the implications are to Australia of the Treaty which came into force last Saturday, 9 February?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for the Northern Territory, who has shown a considerable interest in this important issue. Last Saturday the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and I met with our respective Indonesian counterparts, Their Excellencies Ali Alatas and Ginandjar Kartasasmita, to attend the landmark meeting of the Timor Gap Zone of Cooperation Treaty Ministerial Council.

ANSWER.PARA: By any assessment, the Treaty is a major development in relations between Australia and Indonesia. The coming into force of the Treaty marks the opportunity for a bilateral program with Indonesia to develop petroleum resources in the Timor Gap area. In this regard, it is worthy of note that this is a world first in international relations whereby two countries have actually shared a resource rather than simply dividing the resource into two components. To that extent, I think it will have implications far beyond its significant implications for our respective countries. The issues have been very complex, but we have now in place a substantive regime to promote the exploration and development of petroleum resources in area A of the zone of cooperation. Now that the Treaty is in force, I propose to release exploration acreage in area B in May this year.

The coming into force of the Treaty marks the end of a protracted period of negotiations-some 12 years-between Australia and Indonesia and is a landmark achievement in putting in place an innovative and comprehensive set of joint arrangements for developments in disputed offshore areas. In order to best protect the environment, the Treaty has ensured that there will be no relaxation of contracted strict environmental obligations unless given specific ministerial consideration, a matter that was raised in this House last year.

The joint development with Indonesia offers potentially increased oil security for Australia. It also offers the prospect of employment and participation by Australians in substantial oil development opportunities, in which Darwin and the Northern Territory will play an important role. I stress again that, by any measure, this is a matter of utmost significance between our two countries. I believe and the Government believes that it will be an enduring development in relations between our respective countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Treasurer. In the 1990-91 Budget Speech, his last Budget Speech, the Treasurer said:

QUESTION.PARA: This year inflation will fall further, the current account deficit will markedly improve and employment will pick up.
He said that this would happen `without the misery and despair of high unemployment and a savage recession'. What went wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On two of the counts, inflation and the current account deficit, nothing went wrong. The current account deficit is down by 30 per cent. Or has the honourable member not heard? The inflation rate is travelling down now to its lowest level for a long time and will probably continue to decline to the point where it last was two decades ago. Or has the honourable member not heard that, either?

ANSWER.PARA: Unemployment has not risen to the levels the honourable member describes me as having indicated. It is true that the economy has been in recession and that the economy had slowed down before that; but that has not to date produced horrific levels of unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell that to the unemployed.

—Unemployment is rising; it is over 8 per cent. When those opposite were in government it went from 6.5 to 10.6 per cent in about nine months. Let me remind them that, had we had the same participation rate today as we had when those opposite were last in office, the unemployment rate would be 2.8 per cent. If we are comparing apples with apples, that is the place to begin. The fact of the matter is that we have a higher participation rate because, happily for those in the Australian work force, under this Government people can go out and apply for jobs with a reasonable expectation of getting one-which under those opposite, of course, was a joke.
—Go to Geelong.
— Order! The Leader of the National Party!

—With 1 1/4 million jobs, we have three times the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average. I think in the whole of the seven-year period that those opposite were last in government, the best they could clock up was about a quarter of a million. We have outpaced them by a factor of four or five to one. That is why the participation rate is high, particularly amongst women. The participation rate amongst Australian women is now the highest ever, and that has also been true of the work force in general.

ANSWER.PARA: If the honourable member wishes to compare unemployment, he can compare it by using the published rate, which is 8.1 per cent; but he also should have some regard for the fact that, on the participation rates which obtain now, as distinct from those which obtained in 1982 and 1983, unemployment would be 2.8 per cent. In some States, such as Victoria during 1988 and into 1989, we had virtually over-full employment; hence the shake-out has been more solid.

If the honourable member is asking us what went wrong with the strategy of reducing the current account deficit, the answer is that nothing went wrong. Reducing inflation is on course for 6 per cent by year's end in June, as we forecast in the Budget in August. Next time the honourable member asks that question, he should at least think about some of the elements of it before he gets up and puts it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Land Transport may recall that last December I asked him a question about the peculiar stamp-issuing habits of Australia Post. On that occasion he assured me that Australia Post was going to review its policy, update it and comply with the requests that I had made. Have there been any further developments in regard to that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the question because I was going to seek an opportunity to bring the House up to date with developments that have taken place in connection with this matter. The question to which the honourable member for Kalgoorlie referred was asked on 20 December last year. It concerned the policy of Australia Post on the issue of commemorative stamps. The essence of my reply to the honourable member on that occasion was that Australia Post had reconsidered its policy not to issue commemorative stamps recognising the anniversaries of political parties in Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: Following some informal discussions between myself and Australia Post, I was advised of its decision of 18 December 1990, when it agreed that `the current stamp and stationery issue policy be amended by removing from the subject specifically excluded . . . anniversaries of major political parties'. I was aware that that decision paved the way for Australia Post to issue a commemorative stamp this year in recognition of the centenary of the founding of the Australian Labor Party and the issue of a commemorative stamp in 1996 to commemorative the fiftieth anniversary of the Liberal Party of Australia. I was not advised that the meeting also noted that, if the reaction of the Opposition was unfavourable, the matter would be taken back to the board.

On 8 January this year, I returned a call to Mr Maurice Williams, the chairman of the board of Australia Post, who asked that I seek an indication of the attitude of the Opposition to Australia Post's proposal that these significant anniversaries of the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia be recognised by the issue of a commemorative stamp. In the absence of the shadow Minister responsible for Australia Post, the honourable member for Menzies, I contacted the Leader of the Opposition. I spoke to him direct and followed up with a letter explaining the position and indicating that the board of Australia Post would like to be able to issue stamps to commemorate the founding of the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party of Australia, which I also described as major events in the history of Australian democracy. I added, however, that in order to avoid undesirable political controversy, the board would appreciate an indication of our bipartisan acceptance of such recognition. Unfortunately, that bipartisan acceptance has not been provided. I received a letter on 22 January 1991 from the Leader of the Opposition which said:
Thank you for your letter of 15 January 1991 about the issue by Australia Post of stamps commemorating significant events in the history of political parties.
I cannot offer my support for your proposal.
I do not believe it is appropriate that commemorative stamps be used to publicise political parties.

Quite frankly, I was stunned by that response, as I am sure the vast majority of members on both sides of the Parliament will be. The policy of Australia Post has quite clearly been to commemorate major developments in and achievements of Australia's rich and diverse social, cultural and political background. To preclude the two major political parties in Australia, with the outstanding contribution they both have made to the development of Australian democracy, is absurd in the extreme.

However, in light of this quite foolish response from the Opposition, Australia Post has now reversed its earlier decision in order to ensure that its commendable policy for commemorating major events would not become the subject of partisan political controversy. I am disappointed with that decision by Australia Post, but I accept absolutely its right to make the decision. I believe that the Board of Australia Post would have been more than justified-while acknowledging the attitude adopted by the Opposition-in repudiating that attitude and persisting with its earlier decision to commemorate the founding of both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party.

When one examines the types of organisations and events, all of them worthy, which have been recognised by the issue of commemorative stamps, this decision by the Board of Australia Post which it must feel was forced on it by this absurd response from the Opposition, is made to look even more ridiculous. Both the Labor Party and the Liberal Party are major institutional elements of the great fabric of democratic structures and arrangements which exist within Australia. To have endorsed the bipartisan recognition of both of those parties would have been an expression of our political and social maturity. The position adopted by the Liberal Party, which has denied that recognition, is petulant, foolish and ridiculous and it does it no credit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to ask you a question concerning the televising of the proceedings in the House of Representatives. Today, of course, is the first occasion upon which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) has had the opportunity to televise live proceedings in this chamber and, in particular, Question Time. Of course, the special sitting relating to the Gulf issue was televised live. Could you advise the House whether the ABC is televising live the proceedings in the House of Representatives today and also what arrangements you and the President of the Senate have been able to make with the ABC in relation to the future televising of the House of Representatives and the Senate? I ask that question in the context of the arrangements that currently exist for radio broadcasts when the Senate and the House of Representatives are being broadcast on alternate days.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Hume for his question. Prior to Question Time, a number of honourable members raised with me the fact that they understood that the ABC was not going to televise live Question Time in the House of Representatives today but that it was going to do so at 11.55 this evening. All of those honourable members who spoke to me were amazed that on the day when the House was going to agree to permit the televising of its proceedings the ABC should wait until the middle of the night to put Question Time to air. Televising the House's proceedings is an historic decision and some less charitable souls might say that the judgment of the ABC on this occasion is, itself, historically consistent. I personally find the decision rather extraordinary. The ABC has known since last week that the House would be televised today. On a number of occasions the Managing Director of the ABC has expressed his interest in having Question Time televised and has said that he thought it would be of benefit to the nation and to the ABC.

INTERJECT.PARA: I guess we are trying to do our bit to ensure that the audience reach of the national broadcaster is increased, but it obviously does not seem to have appreciated our efforts. I understand that discussions are taking place with the ABC about an alternate arrangement for televising Question Time in the House of Representatives and the Senate and when the outcome of those are known I will advise the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to you, Mr Speaker. In view of the fact that, depending on the time of the year, up to 100 per cent of the air, both hot and cold, in Parliament House is recycled, and following the decision in the Federal Court of Australia last week that statements by the tobacco industry were misleading in respect of the issue of the ill effects of passive smoking, what action will you and your colleague, the President of the Senate, now take to extend the ban on smoking, which applies in some areas of the Parliament House, to the whole complex?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of a recent judgment relating to the effects of passive smoking and the legal liabilities which could arise as a result. I also understand that that judgment is subject to review. I have asked officers of the Parliament to obtain a copy of the judgment and advise the President and me of its implications. Parliament House, in many ways, is a unique building in that we work here for a lot longer than do people in ordinary employment. Honourable members are no doubt mindful of those long hours and the stressful circumstances under which we work. However, the President and I have taken a number of measures in regard to smoking in Parliament House. Smoking is not permitted in the enclosed public areas of the building. Many of the staff areas in the parliamentary departments and the cafeteria have been designated non-smoking areas. No restrictions as yet apply to members of parliament smoking in their offices or in the Members' Dining Room.

INTERJECT.PARA: Even before the recent judgment, the President and I had referred the issue of smoking in Parliament House to an advisory group of members of parliament. They will no doubt take the judgment into account and will advise us of any measures that are thought necessary as well as our capacity to enforce the regulations on the different occupants of the building. When that committee reports to the President and me, we will make some decisions. We will also be awaiting the outcome of the appeal against the judges' decision that passive smoking did have some carcinogenic effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The Minister may proceed.

—My attention has been drawn to an article which appeared in the Bulletin of 22 January where, with regard to the so-called luxury car tax, Mr Angus McKenzie quotes me as saying, `This is a small price to pay for such a patriotic duty'.

SPEECH.PARA: I have never met Mr McKenzie. I have never spoken to him directly or on the telephone. I have no recollection of saying what he says I said and what he says I said does not accord with my views.
