DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's incompetent handling of the crisis in the wool industry and rural industries generally which has undermined confidence and will result in severe financial hardship, if not ruin, for farmers across Australia.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my awesome responsibility to inject some chilling reality into the proceedings of this Parliament. The need to do that is more than exemplified by the answer of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in Question Time which showed that clearly he is now hopelessly out of touch with what is happening at the coal face, particularly with regard to the unemployed in such places as Geelong, Victoria generally, and rural and regional Australia-indeed, almost all parts of Australia. It is time that we brought the message to Canberra to sheet home to the Government, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) that there is economic agony right across Australia; that the true situation is that the economic clock stands at two minutes to midnight and that small, medium and large businesses, farmers, related service industries and many others face financial ruin this year as a consequence of the economic recession which was, to quote the Treasurer, `the recession we had to have'.

SPEECH.PARA: Rather than rely on anecdotal evidence, of which there is plenty-as all honourable members know only too well as they go back to their electorates between parliamentary sittings and attend economic crisis meetings and inspect the massive flood damage in Queensland, which will add several notches to the extent of the economic recession, indeed the economic depression, existing in parts of Australia-I want to turn to some chilling statistics so that the reality will be sheeted home with regard to our rural industries and the economy more generally. Those statistics show, for example, that for the quarter October to December 1990 there was an increase of 56.8 per cent in the number of bankruptcies compared with the same period in 1989-the same quarter 12 months before.

Let us take that a step further and look at the outlook for the farm sector arising to a large extent from many of the broadly based policies of this Government as well as, I admit, international factors and many other factors. But primarily the fundamental cause of the problem rests with this Federal Government. As my colleague, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), points out, wheat industry operation surpluses will be down 68 per cent this year and there will be a further 37 per cent reduction on top of that next year. The operating surplus in the wool industry will be down 82 per cent this year and a further 139 per cent next year. These are crushing figures with a very human dimension to them in terms of the operation of so many properties, small businesses and family farms across Australia.

In the citrus industry the real gross unit value has declined 26 per cent this year, with a very uncertain future ahead. In the sugar industry, the average return from sugar sales will be down 4.4 per cent with a further 11.4 per cent decline next year. The beef industry, one of our brighter prospects, will be down 14 per cent this financial year and has once again an uncertain future with more recent action by Taiwan. There is some hope with the overall liberalisation that Taiwan states it is going to proceed with and Japan is going to proceed with on 1 July. On an overall basis, net farm cash income will fall around 40 per cent-these are the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics projections-with a further significant decline projected for next year.

The Liberal and National parties come here this afternoon on the first matter of public importance to be televised to present a very strong case as to why the Government has got it wrong. I will deal with some broad based aspects of this. My colleague the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) will deal with some more specific aspects, particularly in relation to the impact of income equalisation deposits and other matters.

Therefore, on a general basis, let me tell the House that charge No.1 in terms of the conduct of this Government is its interest rate policy, its wrong overall monetary and fiscal political settings, which has resulted in interest rates being too high for too long and, even at their current levels, still twice the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average of so many of our competitors. Charge No. 2 is that we still have a regulated labour market in this country greatly adding to the cost burden of so many industries in an unfair way whilst the pace of deregulation has been forced in other areas. Charge No. 3 is that this Government has failed to act in real terms in dealing with the matter of protection, in facing up to the sacred cow of the motor vehicle industry and other industries, whereas we have found a better way. We have stated very clearly where our policy direction is heading in that regard. As a result, farmers and, indeed, many people right across Australia, will pay on average $4,000 less for every vehicle they purchase as a consequence of the lowering of protection to zero or negligible levels by the year 2000.

Charge No. 4 is that the Minister and the Government have perpetrated a taxation system in this country which has gutted the viability of so many industries, so many rural industries and so many businesses, large and small. For example, we still have the imposition of sales tax at $1 billion to $2 billion on our export industries. We have a level of fuel taxation which would be reduced under our alternative tax reform approach involving a comprehensive goods and services tax. Fuel taxation would be reduced for business and farming and sales tax would be abolished for transport freight and transport equipment. Of course, that would in turn also pave a much better way forward in respect of income tax levels in this country. The goods and services tax package has been detailed elsewhere. It represents the better way forward, the alternative, as indeed is our approach to deregulating the labour market, reforming levels of protection, especially associated with the motor vehicle industry, and taxation reform.

It is time to turn more specifically to this Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, this tarnished product whom I once recommended, sought and perhaps suggested should take over as Treasurer from the disastrous Treasurer. I have now realised the error of my ways and believe that the sooner both Treasurer Keating and Minister Kerin depart their portfolios the better it will be for all Australians.

On the matter of rural industries, the Minister has failed to perform where performance counts most. Indeed, he has locked in the Prime Minister to his inadequate performance. When the honourable member for Gwydir (Mr Anderson) asked the Prime Minister a very careful question without notice in December last, the Prime Minister replied:

I adhere to the statements of my Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. As I have had cause to say before, he is the best Minister for primary industry in the history of this country . . . I have total confidence in the Minister in all respects.

Well, I say that rural Australia does not share those comments of the Prime Minister. Woolgrowers across Australia do not share the confidence of the Prime Minister. Minister Kerin has failed but the cost of his failure will be borne by the backbone of our nation. I am, of course, referring to those in rural and regional Australia, especially but not only our woolgrowers. In all that happened yesterday, the saddest reflection on Minister Kerin and the Government generally is that part of his statement which says:
Everything the Government has done and everything I have said over the past 18 months has been directed to the benefit of the wool industry.
Let us examine some of those quotes. On 31 May Minister Kerin said:
My clear message to the market is that 700 cents is immutable. The next time the floor price is changed it will be upward.
Quote No. 2:
The Government's commitment to the 700c/kg floor is rock solid.
Quote No. 3:
Let me make it quite clear that the inquiry-
the Vines inquiry-
will not affect the reserve price.

That statement has been demonstratively proved wrong by some of the utterances at the Minister's press conference yesterday. The Minister's actions may have been directed to the benefit of the wool industry but the performance, the effect and the outcome have been an unmitigated disaster as represented by the economic agony created right across Australia. There is no point the Minister pleading his good intentions-this episode will go down in the annals of economic history as the result of many poor decisions and actions. His part in the whole episode will go down in history as an example par excellence of incompetent ministerial intervention.

The wool industry has been in absolute turmoil for almost a year. I can say without any exaggeration that the primary industry Minister has, no matter what his intentions, continually exacerbated the problem by making promises which could not be met. Where is the Minister's credibility now? I would suggest: in a heap. Where is the Government's credibility now with rural Australia? I can tell honourable members that it is in smouldering ruins. The saddest thing of all is that our nation's reputation around the world has been seriously tarnished as a consequence of all that has happened.

Enough of the Minister. We then have the help of that great lark, that backbencher, the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). What was his contribution? It was some letter writing to Europe at an inopportune time, along with that lateral thinking approach which sometimes produces some real gems but at other times produces some real disasters. In terms of the wool industry, the Liberal and National parties have faced up to these issues in a very responsible way. Our core wool position is clear cut: it is that we have in fact supported the reserve price scheme on each and every day of its operation. It ceased to operate nearly a fortnight ago as we speak today.

What we are all charged with doing now is finding out quickly the very best way forward in the interests of developing the best onward plans for the wool industry, the woolgrower and the nation as a whole. In that regard, let us be quite clear cut. The honourable member for Barker will cover other aspects. I want to say something about quotas. I say particularly to woolgrowers right across Australia: you were led up a garden path on the matter of wool quotas by the Minister, by other elements in the industry and by a lack of analysis of the impact of wool quotas. We had the courage on this side of the House to declare very firmly our hand against quotas.

As the Deputy Leader of the National Party pointed out, quotas have wrecked the peanut industry in Queensland and done much to disrupt the wheat industry across Australia. Firstly, quotas are an administrative nightmare, especially when taking a fair dinkum approach to defining a qualifying period. Secondly, quotas create legal problems on transfer. The woolgrower can sell his property, go to the Gold Coast, take his quota with him and leave the new purchaser of the land without any access to a wool quota. Thirdly, quotas distort market signals, especially when applied across the board, so that more popular wool which is selling well will be quoted down along with other wools. Fourthly, of course, quotas by their very existence will create a very costly secondary stockpile on the farms. I could go on, suffice to say that the coalition rejected quotas last year, we reject quotas now, and we will reject quotas in the future.

We are pleased to see that the Minister, in the small print of his statement yesterday, finally got it right in terms of this particular matter when he said that the Australian Wool Corporation's proposed marketing quota scheme will not proceed. That is an interesting development. At least we had the courage to take that message to country Australia, to explain our position on that and to have on the record the correct position in regard to the fundamental interests of woolgrowers.

These are crisis times for many people outside the capital cities, as well as for many people inside the capital cities. This matter of public importance is directed at those people in rural industries; those people battling to survive in a situation where the economic clock is at two minutes to midnight. I say that there is a better way. There is a better alternative which will provide a firm basis for getting on with developing a strong wool industry. I say also that we should not become too negative about what has been a great industry, contributing massively to the economic development of Australia and the standard of living of all Australians.

In this regard it is not only a case of doing what is best for woolgrowers from this point on and recognising the reality of the situation, but it is also a case of getting on the front foot with regard to the positive marketing and selling of wool after this long period of turmoil so that we can rebuild wool markets around the world, and do it quickly.

Clearly, we have reached a stage where Minister Kerin has outlived his usefulness in the portfolio of Primary Industries and Energy and where Treasurer Keating has totally outlived his usefulness in the Treasury portfolio. Both should depart those portfolios-and the sooner the better for the sake of all Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr KERIN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Farrer and Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) started his speech by making quite a few references to general economic issues. As usual, the Leader of the National Party grabbed the baton at the wrong end. He seems to persist in swallowing the rhetoric of some of the more extremist representatives of farm organisations and parroting it back. This preoccupation by the Opposition with blaming rather than contributing to the development of constructive solutions to the serious difficulties besetting a number of rural industries in Australia is one of the main reasons the National Party has difficulty in convincing the rural population that it understands the root causes of its concern, let alone that it is capable of addressing those problems in a rational manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable gentleman instanced his Party's policies and, for example, suggested that there should be a further loosening of interest rates. At this stage that would be quite disastrous. We would get a second round effect of more inflation and ever higher interest rates. Interest rates have actually dropped by 6 per cent. We are in consultation with the banks at present. One bank's farm portfolio has about half of its borrowers on bills. If we look at the 90-day bill market we see that the rate is between 11 per cent and 12 per cent. Interest rates will not be the problem they once were. Of course, by definition, lower interest rates are far better than higher interest rates. With a deregulated market economy and the private sector borrowing for property speculation, the weapons available to a Treasurer in this country are somewhat limited.

The next point concerned the honourable member's favourite idea of moving to a deregulated labour market. Again I say to honourable members opposite that it is my very clear and deep belief that if we were to move to a deregulated labour market we would have not only massive exploitation but also, because we are not dealing with a proper market for labour, a wages blow-out in some areas and very low wages in other areas. Perhaps that is what honourable members opposite are on about.

The Leader of the National Party of Australia then moved to his third point, which concerned nil protection. I do not adhere to nil protection. I do not think we can make that stick with the dairy, tobacco, dried vine fruits or most of the horticultural industries. Now that we are getting average levels down, we do have to concentrate on those industries that diverge from the average, such as passenger motor vehicles, textiles, clothing and footwear and the dairy industry, but I think we also ought to look at some of the ways these assistance levels are measured in some of those areas.

The honourable member's fourth point concerned taxation, including a goods and services tax. In this regard the Government has taken a very strong stand. I think that the honourable member would concede that that too will cause all sorts of problems in rural Australia; for example, taxes on country school parents and citizens associations.

The honourable member's silence in the last year in regard to a number of serious issues facing rural Australia has been notable. By and large the Opposition has been supportive of the Government's actions on wool. I understand very clearly what the honourable member is saying today. As I said at the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics National Agricultural and Resource Outlook Conference, Australia's primary and resource industries remain hostage to familiar uncertainties: we are unable to control the weather; and we will continue to be dependent on overseas commodity markets, often distorted by politically expedient government intervention. The present combination of world events is the cause of a generally weaker outlook for Australia's rural industries. The sooner the honourable member recognises this, the sooner he will be able to focus on the real issues.

There is no question that in the short to medium term many of our rural industries are facing a severe test. However, the honourable member for Farrer's laying this solely at the Government's feet and implying that it is all a domestic question is really an indication of the lack of understanding that he is well known for in rural Australia. Individual farmers and their families are experiencing real difficulties.

I turn now to the wool industry and the series of unprecedented events that led to the decisions I announced yesterday. The Government has taken action in response to the following unprecedented series of events. I refer to the continuing deterioration of the wool market, most of which was unforeseen; the rapidly growing stockpile of wool held by the Australian Wool Corporation-a stockpile currently of nearly 5 million bales, nearly a full normal year's production; the burgeoning borrowings of the AWC, now close to $3 billion; and the ever increasing wool levy necessary for growers to pay for the interest on the debt-25 per cent this year, projected to be 35 per cent in 1991-92.

The first time the Chairman of the Wool Corporation contacted me on this issue was in November 1989, my staff having earlier drawn my attention to the situation. At that time we had a 4 per cent levy on wool and we had accumulated over the years a reserve of something like $1.8 billion. Through early 1990 the suggestions were that as the market deteriorated there be a 10 per cent tax, a 15 per cent tax and then a 25 per cent tax. I brought in a 20 per cent tax and the industry went for an 18 per cent tax. Now that we have a 25 per cent tax, the suggestion is that we have a 35 per cent tax.

It seems that at some stage, when we have moved from a 4 per cent tax to a 35 per cent tax and when the industry and the Wool Corporation are asking that we put on a marketing quota of 700 million kilograms-that is a little more than seven-tenths of present production-and that is combined with the level of taxation needed, we are really looking at a return on average of about 341c. At that stage one really has to make a fundamental re-evaluation. I am glad the honourable member said what he said about quotas because I had to say to the Wool Corporation that we simply cannot go on with unlimited borrowings; at some stage we must evaluate the situation of the industry. I also told the Wool Corporation Board quite clearly that I did not think I could deliver a quota scheme through the Parliament.

The events of yesterday really have been lying there for a long time in terms of dealing with the fundamentals and first principles. As the honourable gentleman has said, there is opposition by a large number of growers to the quota scheme, and that was an integral part of the Australian Wool Corporation strategy. The doubtful outlook for wool markets in the near term, especially in the Soviet Union and China, and the apparent lack of recognition, at least publicly, by the wool industry itself, and its leaders, of the enormity of the situation all resulted in the need for the Government to take actions to ensure that this vital industry does not bankrupt itself completely.

The measures announced are directed, over the next few years, to lead to the recovery of the Australian wool industry, and, whilst painful for all concerned in the short term, in the medium term the recovery plan will enable the Australian wool industry to compete effectively for markets. The measures provide for confidence and stability to be returned to wool markets, which have, in recent times, been suffering under the uncertainty created by the public recognition that the debt level of the AWC is not sustainable.

We have been taking actions to address the problem since the world market for wool began to collapse in November 1989, and over that time we have introduced a wide range of measures. They have been implemented by the Government and the Australian Wool Corporation to try to restore confidence in the market, and to put the wool industry on the road to recovery. Dropping the floor price last year, the loan guarantees, the Vines committee inquiry, the establishment of the interim Wool Policy Council, my call for a business plan and then for a strategic plan from the Australian Wool Corporation, the wool mission, the $400m USSR credit facility-all of these are examples of the actions we have been taking throughout this difficult period. But, despite the adoption of this range of measures, the situation has continued to deteriorate, largely as a result of continuing speculation that the scheme was unsustainable, and the other influences such as the crisis in the USSR and the Gulf war.

The Opposition wishes to focus on the integrity question. What the Government has tried to do-and of course, I do not have time to go through it all-through a series of actions through 1989 and 1990, month by month, is to stick with the wool industry, trying to see whether we could be convinced that industry was facing reality, or whether we could really see any way out of it other than where we got to yesterday. It has been a terrific problem for the industry to grapple with.

On first principles we all know that markets eventually set price, that buffer stock schemes always fail, and that if you try to control price without controlling supply you will eventually get substitution. There is a lot of fibre substitution going on. Cotton has expanded its share. Now at least we have a chance for wool to expand its share. The other first principle that was in the back of our minds, of course, is that we were doing exactly what the United States of America did with wheat in the early 1980s, holding up the world price of wheat while other people sold it, and that eventually resulted in the Americans having to use a lot of taxpayers' funds to sell the wheat through the export enhancement program. What we are doing is exactly what the Europeans do with dairy and a range of other products.

This industry is far too important to look just at first principles. One really has to try to work through it with this industry, because we have in place a scheme that has really been working successfully for about 17 years. Most of the things which have caused this crisis were unanticipated, and unanticipatable. There were three things we could anticipate. The first was that, when the dollar was floated in Australia, the reserve price scheme should have been adapted to a floating exchange rate. This was pointed out at the time. Papers were prepared, but this was ignored by the board of the Corporation. Secondly, we could have anticipated that there would be a reaction to the high prices through 1987 and 1988. There was not much one could do about that, but it should have been taken into account enough, so that when the price was set at $8.70 it could have been anticipated that this would induce or stimulate the record production we now have. Of course, the Wool Corporation at the time was told this, but again it was ignored, and in fact the person bearing the news was more or less shot. The rest was unanticipatable, and the reason I dropped the floor price was that I could not be convinced that we could trade through, even with the level of tax we were putting in place, and the level of borrowings. Again, the reasons for doing that, first of all, were so that we could get the price of wool somewhat near to its traditional level with cotton and polyester-that is, one can have wool at two or three times the price there and because of its qualities and particular values one can gain markets at that level, but once it gets to five or six times the prices of cotton and polyester, one cannot hold market share for very long.

The second reason I did it was so that the wool industry did not borrow lots and lots of money to buy its own wool to put in the stockpile so that it would appreciate in value and store expensively. Already we have deadweight losses in the scheme of $1.8 billion. That is the growers' money that has been put in. It is just a question of calculating how long before it is sold, and how much other deadweight loss is there. There are calculations at present of $1.3 billion deadweight loss additionally. The third reason was that setting the price at $8.70 really meant that it was an inducement to continue production. The really big intellectual disagreement I had with the Wool Corporation and the wool growers at that time was their view that if we set the levy at 25 per cent, or 20 per cent, that would be enough to bring production down. We said no, and I am afraid we have been right. We will still have the second highest production of wool in this year. It is only down about 6 million kilograms on the previous year.

So we put all those things in place, and we tried to stick with the industry. As the situation deteriorated, as the Wool Corporation brought in various business plans, in the first business plan its worst case scenario became an optimistic one, so more legislation was required in this Parliament. The buy-in rate in November of last year by the Corporation for the year at that stage was 64 per cent-that is, the Corporation was buying 64 per cent of the wool put on the market. For the week in November before I headed off on that mission it was 62 per cent, so going overseas was very much a time to explain to our customers exactly what was happening, what the law was all about in terms of the Wool Marketing Act, and to try to stimulate the trade in the Soviet Union. We went through the buyer countries explaining the situation. I pointed out that legally, of course, the 700c price was fixed by legislation. But one really cannot fool the buyers. They were doing their own calculations. It is not as though I was on a mission trying to con our buyers. We managed to get $87.5m from the Soviet Union that it owed for wool, and there are still negotiations going on. We have not been able to get some additional money; we are still trying to gain that. We still hope that the Russians will come to Australia to buy. But the situation got worse in January, and we had to take the action we did.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLachlan Mr I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) in this matter of public importance describing the Government's incompetent handling of this rather disastrous issue.

SPEECH.PARA: Rural Australia has had two major problems to deal with for the majority of the 1980s-international problems, as we all know, created by $30 billion of export and internal subsidies thrown at the American and European farmers; given to each group-and more and more subsidies every day. Those things we work at, and sometimes we win and sometimes we lose. As well as that, we have had an internal domestic, Australian made problem, cut mainly from Italian cloth, but designed and made up in Australia by our morbid economic engineer, by our national undertaker-a designer recession, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) called it; and the Leader of the National Party has described the disastrous results that that has had for rural industry and Australians generally.

I would just like to add to what he said: those high interest rates and the consequent over-high value of the Australian dollar have been around with us for six years, and not just recently. We do not have to go much further than the South Australian economist who, just before Christmas, described those interest rates as a wave which carries on until it finally breaks- and it has certainly taken a great number of Australians with it at its breaking.

I want to return to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), who has just left the table and the chamber. I have worked with this Minister for a number of years in various capacities, and he is described as ostensibly plausible, ostensibly economically literate and mainly personable. Over time he has worked through various industries-the dairy industry problems, the beef industry, the dried vine fruits industry and many others. Some of these industries have been somewhat successful, some of them have had fair results and some are still to be tested. He is thought by many to be a rational man who is approachable and thoughtful.

In all of that period in the 1980s that I have just described he has supported, however, the Government economic line of slow rates of reform, high interest rates and a high dollar. However, in 1987 he made a disastrous mistake-he changed the rules for the wool industry and took away the checks and balances that had been in place for between 13 and 15 years, whilst maintaining the Government's taxing powers and the Australian Wool Corporation's ability to borrow on behalf of wool growers. That has turned out to be probably the most disastrous policy mistake in Australian rural history.

The wool industry in this country is now faced with a minimum of $2.8 billion of external debt-this may well go to $3.5 billion-a debt servicing cost of the order of half a billion dollars a year; 4.8 million bales of wool in the sheds; and 1.5 to 2 million bales of annual oversupply. He presided over the design of some legislation three years ago which has brought about the temporary, I would say, demise of the wool industry and certainly the demise of some people in it. It has certainly brought about the demise of a conservative reserve price plan, which, as I said, ran for nearly a decade and a half until this Minister, three years ago, changed the legislation and took away the protective mechanisms which had been agreed and had worked well until that time. That was the moment of impending disaster.

We had then, of course, a move to an aggressive reserve price, and the Corporation began buying in wool and 870c became the reserve price, which finally turned out to be unsustainable, as did, sadly, the 700c. Some will blame the scheme itself. Twenty years ago people said, `Forty, 50 years ago such schemes would fail', but 20 years ago some who are still about prophesied that this scheme would fail. Some will say that putting the price to 870c made it fail; some will say that dropping the floor precipitated its demise; some will say it was high interest rates; some will say it was all sorts of other things. But one can be sure that we will all blame someone else.

This industry is now faced with too much wool, too much debt, too much annual supply-nearly 2 million bales in current terms-and a reserve price scheme which has been cancelled by the Government and the Wool Corporation and which has sunk deeper than Captain Cook's cannon. For future wool growers, that is, those who have the courage to stay in the industry, it will be saddled with half a billion dollars of annual debt.

I do not wish to dwell upon the details of what should happen in regard to resurrecting this disastrous mess into the future, but I will say several things which I think are very important. In this country 15 or 16 years ago we designed something called an income equalisation deposit (IED) scheme. It was designed to recognise the highs and lows of agricultural income in this country and one was able to deposit one's money-the excess rewards of good wool years or wheat years or whatever they were-with the Government at reasonably low interest rates and redeem that money in times of hardship.

When this Government got into power it removed those IEDs and poured scorn and vitriol on those who supported them. I was in the position of trying to somehow persuade this Government and this Minister to bring that scheme back. It was finally brought back in one form or another on 1 July 1990, just after the two biggest wool years in postwar history, apart from 1951. I think it was brought back at that time on purpose so that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would not have to hand back the tens if not hundreds of millions of dollars that he would not have today if that scheme was still in existence. So I put it to the House that the $300m which the taxpayer is reputedly going to hand out to the wool industry will simply not be coming from the taxpayer at all. It would simply have been, had the IED scheme been in existence, some of the wool growers' money coming back.

Blame for this debacle will fly anywhere, and I will come to that in a second. However, I want to assure the Minister of one thing: the Government can pass on or it can say that it can pass on the $2.8m or the $3.5m of wool debt which will accrue, built by the Corporation on behalf of today's growers, to a necessarily lesser number of growers who will be growing wool, if they have the courage, in four or five years' time. But it could not possibly be equitable. It could not possibly be equitable to pass on to next year's growers or the year after's growers a debt built today. So it is nonsense for the Government to say it is going to charge the people who are in the industry in four or five years' time an increasing levy to finance the debts that have been built up today.

So we all know when we look at that situation that who will be standing to pick up the deficit, if there is one, will be the government of the day, and we know that that will not be this Government. It is naive to think that the wool growers of tomorrow will be picking up an increasing cost met by fewer and fewer of them. Blame for this debacle will be all around the place-it is on the Country Hour today. One can hear Government members pouring out blame on everybody else but themselves. The Government can blame all of us, and everybody who did not stand up and voice his disapproval when the Government loosened this scheme three years ago, when it took away the checks and balances. But blame is cheap and responsibility is deep, and responsibility overrides all in these matters. Blame attached to the captains of the Melbourne and the Voyager in that tragedy of years ago and many others, but the Minister bore the responsibility. We all bear the blame, but this Minister and this Government bear the responsibility, and for that I have to say they will never be forgiven.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe Mr N.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a rather curious phenomenon here of two leading Opposition spokesmen delivering what I counted to be 30 minutes of criticism of the Government's decision yesterday to suspend the reserve support scheme. Not once in that 30 minutes did either of those Opposition speakers say that they would have done anything different. Not once did they come forward with any alternative proposal, and not once in the whole 30 minutes did we ever get anywhere near anything specific except where the honourable member for Farrer (Mr Tim Fischer) told us that if they had their chance we would be seeing a $4,000 reduction in motor vehicle prices when they introduce their approach to tariff reduction.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to come back to that because what we have just seen here today, at least to their credit, were a spokesman for the Liberal Party of Australia and a spokesman for the National Party of Australia. The last time we tackled the floor price issue, we had the barney within their parties, where the National Party did not want any change at all and in the end the Liberal Party shadow Cabinet supported the Government's decision to lower the floor price from 870c to 700c. At least here the two parties have come forward, but they have not produced anything or said anything. All they have done is spread blame somewhere.

I suppose that late in the piece the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) did say that perhaps they should have protested more at some stage. But I do not think the honourable member did himself much credit in his little contribution here today. As a member of the Prime Minister's country task force, I sat across the table from him on many occasions during the past six years when the honourable member was president of the National Farmers Federation (NFF). We have talked about income equalisation deposits (IED) and income averaging schemes. Although he knows about it, the honourable member for Barker said absolutely nothing in his contribution today about the tax rorting that was going on with IEDs that led to the changes.

When the NFF brought forward its proposals and asked for revisions, he quite willingly conceded that there were grounds for changing the Government's decisions and that there was room for other tax averaging measures. He was right then and he does not do himself any credit when he comes here now and says that these things should not have occurred.

There was another inconsistency that we heard absolutely nothing about in the honourable member's contribution today. In the lead up to the Government's taking the decision yesterday to suspend the scheme, we heard quite a lot from representatives of wool growers in various forums protesting vigorously about the proposed abolition-or suspension, as it turned out. We did not hear a thing from any of those people about the national wage case decision last week authorising a national wage 6 per cent flow on to shearers when the industry was in a position to pay. They march up to the national wage case saying that they want the free market to determine wages in the industry; they want the free market to determine that the prices are not there at the moment, therefore the wages cannot be there. But when it comes to the floor price they do not want a free market. Either they want the Government to leave the floor price in place or they are prepared to wander surreptitiously into this Parliament and go on with all this populist cant; that is what it amounts to-populist cant.

TALK.START.PARA: —We gave you a decision on quotas. Where do you stand on quotas?

—Not once in his speech did the honourable member for Farrer say that the Opposition would have done anything different. Neither did the honourable member for Barker. It is all very well to talk about quotas. No-one was going to embrace quotas; even the Opposition was able to recognise that that was not on.

SPEECH.PARA: Members opposite do support the changes that have taken place. They supported the lowering of the floor price from 870c to 730c because they recognised the realities of the international game of bluff that was going on with our wool stockpile and they now recognise as well as anyone else the reality that the Government-whatever government-cannot simply sit by and sustain the increasing liability.

The Government deserves credit, not populist cant, for saying to the industry, `We gave a guarantee on the floor price and we will honour that guarantee.' One way or another the producer will receive the floor price for wool that has been purchased by the Corporation and for wool that is now in the stockpile. But that cannot go on for ever in a world which has simply ceased to demand that wool, so the future price for wool will be market determined.

I saw a very interesting presentation by a spokeswoman from one of the organisations in the industry who made a valid case that there could be a substantial drop in the price for wool. When one took account of the levy that did not apply and the costs of holding deferred stock that did not apply, there could almost be a drop of another 50 per cent in the price and the producer would still be no worse off than if the existing situation were to prevail.

I say to the Opposition that this is a very carefully crafted motion. The motion does not say that those opposite oppose the decision to suspend the reserve price support scheme; rather it relates to the general incompetence in handling issues. However, every step along the way that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) has taken has been one that the Opposition has supported. It is just populist cant to come here and run any other line.

In the brief time available to me, I want to refer to a couple of issues that now face us and that I believe are a reality for all wool growers. About six months ago, I was talking to one of my close friends, a producer of high grade wools, and some of his colleagues. I said to them, `There are a lot of ways we can go. Where do you fellows think we should go? How do you think we should deal with the situation?'. They said, `No-one has any answers. Unless the world starts buying our wool again, all we can do is hope for the best.' That is about the strength of it. Unless the world starts buying our wool again, we simply have to deal with the situation we have. Members of the National Party of Australia who wander around Australia talking to one grower after another, getting a different view from each one and then come into Parliament and put forward these populist views, ought to remember that the world situation is different and that the reality is that Australia faces a number of international circumstances which have been the prime causes for the situation that has developed in the wool market.

I am actually quite disappointed in this motion. I would not mind in the least if those opposite had come in here and spoken on a motion opposing the Government's decision. For those opposite to come in here and surreptitiously put on a performance resembling opposition, while knowing very well that they endorse the decision and would have done the same thing, I think borders on deceit. That is my approach to it.

The tariff proposals which I have just tabled relate to proposed alterations to the Customs Tariff Act 1987. Customs tariff proposal No. 1 (1991) will operate on and from 13 February 1991. It proposes to insert in section 26 of the principal Act two tariff subheadings which cover mixed spirituous beverages made from ethyl alcohol, wine and fruit juice. This action will allow the application of the biannual consumer price index factor adjustments to the revenue rates of duty for these goods.

Customs tariff proposal No. 2 (1991) operates on and from 1 March 1991 and contains a series of alterations made in the context of the post-1988 assistance arrangements for textiles, clothing and footwear (TCF) industries based on the premium tender rates for the 1991 quota period.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August 1990, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before the House the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990 which seeks to implement the protocol additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, relating to the protection of victims of international armed conflict which, for ease of reference, I shall refer to as `the protocol'. The coalition opposes the Bill and the ratification of the protocol.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make it clear, as would be obvious, that we support and encourage the expansion of international humanitarian law and that we regard the aims of the protocol as being laudable ones. Indeed, the convention that eventually led to the finalisation of this protocol was in existence when I was Foreign Minister and we had fine hopes that we could achieve a realistic outcome.

The reality of this legislation, however, is that it may place too many impediments in the way of our armed forces and may, indeed, endanger them. To implement the protocol could subject the Australian Defence Force to such restrictions in time of war that it would not be able to operate to its full effectiveness and the lives of the service personnel concerned would be put at greater risk than they otherwise would be.

It is with some reluctance that I have to announce on behalf of the Opposition that we are opposed to this legislation. I really did strive to see whether there was a way through in order that we could join with the Government. This legislation has a history. It has been before the Parliament before. The previous Attorney-General-after the then shadow Attorney-General, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown), indicated that we would be opposing the legislation-withdrew it because he did not wish it to go through without bipartisan support. It was my view-and I conveyed this to the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy)-that we could consider supporting the legislation if in fact the Government would be prepared to express reservations, and I will develop this slightly later on. That seemed to me to be the most sensible way through.

Glory be, in my own time as Foreign Minister we would ratify treaties and express reservations where there were concerns. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), in a letter to the President some years ago, expressed his concerns with elements of this protocol. Had the Government been prepared to express reservations, we would have been prepared to consider supporting the legislation. But no, it wanted the protocol as it is and, as a consequence, we have been forced to oppose a measure that has quite laudable aims but which, in practice-as I will explain-in our view, could endanger our own forces.
It was Dwight Eisenhower, a former President of the United States, who said when reflecting on his time as a General that:
Nothing is easy in war. Mistakes are always paid for in casualties . . .
The provisions of the protocol, if implemented and respected according to the letter, would certainly make the gruesome task of war even more difficult.

The dramatic developments which are unfolding in the Middle East no doubt illustrate that the objective of the protocol, the protection of civilians during times of armed conflict, is one for which we have to continually strive. Those developments also show that when one party to a conflict openly flouts time honoured conventions and principles, it is necessary for the other party to reconsider its own approach to the conflict. It is my view that the protocol, if it were made applicable to the present conflict, would place very severe and most unrealistic limitations upon the allied forces.
Sir John Monash, at the time of the First World War, wrote that:

War is not a business in which one can take any pride or pleasure, or even pretend to. Its horror, its ghastly inefficiency, its unspeakable cruelty and misery has always appalled me, but there is nothing to do but to set one's teeth and stick it out as long as one can.
The conduct of armed conflict could only be rendered more inefficient, to use Sir John's words, by the protocol and, in so doing, would have the undesirable effect of prolonging such conflict.

Traditionally, the law relating to war or armed conflict made a distinction between the right to wage war and the rights and duties which operate once war is started. This distinction is reflected in the Latin maxim jus ad bellum-that is, the theory of a just war-and jus in bello-that is, the doctrine on the rules of warfare and the humanitarian rules that apply within war. The theory of a just war, socalled, notwithstanding the talk we have heard of a `jihad' or an Islamic holy war, has been supplanted by the principles embodied in the United Nations Charter, notably article 2.4 which contains a prohibition on the use of force in the conduct of international relations. However, that prohibition is subject to the provisions of article 51 which recognise the inherent right of nations to resort to individual or collective self-defence as an interim measure until the United Nations Security Council has taken measures to maintain international peace and security. Set out in chapter VII of the United Nations Charter is a regime under which the Security Council can act in order to endorse the use of force by member states.

There is already in existence at the international level, as honourable members would appreciate, a great body of law that applies in times of armed conflict. If we look at some of the recent developments in the Gulf crisis, we can see how that law operates. I will take only a few examples. The treatment of captured allied military personnel by the Iraqi regime contravenes the provisions of the Third Geneva Convention-the convention relative to the treatment of prisoners of war. Again, the treatment by Iraqi military forces of Kuwaiti civilians shows a flagrant disregard by Iraq of the provisions of the Fourth Geneva Convention-the convention relative to the protection of civilian persons in times of war.

Although Iraq is a signatory to the four Geneva conventions, it has displayed a contemptuous attitude to their provisions and we can have very little confidence in expecting Iraq to abide by universally accepted standards for the conduct of armed conflict and the treatment of civilian peoples. The aerial bombardment of civilian targets by Iraq in both Israel and Saudi Arabia constitutes a clear breach of the universally accepted rule that bombardment expressly directed against a civilian population is prohibited. This principle formed the basis of the Hague draft rules of 1923 on aerial bombardment which, although not fully or finally implemented, have been regarded in both doctrine and in practice as constituting binding customary international law. The draft rules of 1923 sought to elaborate upon article 25 of the Hague Regulations of 1907 which prohibits attacks against undefended civilian objects `by whatever means'-a phrase which clearly encompasses attacks from the air.

The examples that I have referred to show that the existing state of international law dealing with the conduct of war is very well developed. Unfortunately, the protocol does not advance the case for humanitarian law. There are, of course, many provisions of the protocol that are worthy of support. That is why I have indicated that provided the Government was prepared to express reservations, we would go along with it. That again, as I mentioned earlier, was rejected. But many of these provisions are already contained in the Fourth Geneva Convention to which I have referred, so protection in these and other similar areas is already provided for.

The provisions of the protocol which do cause us concern and which lead us to the conclusion that the protocol should not be ratified include-and I will go through a number of them briefly-article 1.4, which provides that the protocol shall apply to certain types of wars of liberation; articles 20, 51.6, 52.1, 54.4, 55.2 and 56.4, which contain a blanket prohibition against the right of reprisal; article 35.2, which forbids the use of weaponry that may cause `superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering'; article 56.1, which prohibits attacks against dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations; article 44.3, dealing with the way in which certain combatants should distinguish themselves from the civilian population; articles 48, 49.1 and 49.2, prescribing the distinction between military and civilian objectives; articles 52 and 57, which prohibit attacks that may cause `incidental loss of civilian life'; and article 82, which obliges nations to ensure that legal advisers are available `at all times' to advise military commanders of their obligations under the protocol.

A most cursory reading and brief presentation of those articles would indicate to honourable members just how difficult this could be for commanders and for many engaged, though regretfully, in a time of war. One of the most controversial aspects of the protocol is its scope of application in that international armed conflict is defined to include some forms of internal conflict involving wars of national liberation. Unlike the provisions of article 1.1 of the second protocol, it is not necessary that there be in existence a certain level of intensity of conflict for protocol I to become operative.

Article 1.4 of protocol I provides that the provisions of the protocol apply to international armed conflicts as defined in common article 2 of the Geneva Conventions, and to `armed conflicts in which peoples are fighting against colonial domination and alien occupation and against racist regimes in the exercise of their right of self-determination'. The most troublesome aspect of this provision is the words `alien occupation', appearing in article 1.4, as they introduce extraordinarily great uncertainty.

We have taken this stance assuming that the Government is being fair dinkum about the implementation of these protocols and that it will adhere to them. If it does, honourable members will find by the examples that I have referred to that our own men and women in the field would be severely constrained.

Those words that I have just referred to, `alien occupation', unlike the phrases `colonial domination' or `racist regimes', have no settled meaning at all in international law. A good example is how one would classify the situation that existed in Cambodia vis-a-vis the Phnom Penh Government backed by Vietnam? Would the civil war waged by the Khmers and other elements be viewed as a fight against `alien occupation'? This is obviously only but one of many examples of civil wars involving so-called puppet regimes that are scattered across the globe.

So it is clear that the scope of the protocol is extremely wide. Its application to wars of liberation was an issue not only of great concern to us, but also of very great concern to our major ally, the United States. In elevating armed conflicts of this sort to an international status, the protocol, inadvertently in my view, revives the notion of a just war, or jus ad bellum, that I was referring to earlier. The classification by the protocol of certain conflicts as being equivalent to armed conflicts between nation states when they are just not, very much depends upon what could be subjective elements. So too do the complementary provisions in the protocol dealing with guerilla warfare-particularly article 44.3, which sets out problematic distinctions between regular combatants, civilians and non-regular or guerilla combatants-compound the problem and blur the traditional distinction between international and civil wars.

Now I turn to the prohibition against reprisals, which can be found in the various articles that I mentioned earlier. In considering this, it should be borne in mind that if one party to a conflict causes a fundamental breach of the protocol the other party is still bound to conduct its operations in conformity with the provisions of the protocol. The wide prohibition against reprisals conflicts funda- mentally with the right of self-defence that is recognised in article 51 of the United Nations Charter. I am trying to refer to matters of international law in this debate rather than to the argument about the Gulf, which has been outlined frequently in this House in the past.

But fundamental to our argument about these forces acting under the aegis of a UN Security Council resolution is our argument that there is a right of collective self-defence vested in nations under the Charter of the UN. That is one of the factors that I thought the Government would have sought to indicate a reservation about in terms of the restriction on reprisals. In international conflicts, it must be fairly obvious that often the threat of reprisal-just the mere threat of reprisal-is the most effective and sometimes the only means of bringing an end to breaches of international law.

The Cold War in many ways guaranteed a fair degree of stability by the sheer fear that if the Soviet Union, for example, launched an attack on the United States, there would be reprisals. One of the major reasons for the stability was the peace that was brought about through the security of one being armed against the other and the fear of some reprisal being launched.

I would infinitely prefer a set of circumstances where we were not forever engaged in a cold war and where in fact we were working for not a unilateral but a gradual and mutual elimination of weapons of war. But we have to face reality. We are involved in an international conflict at the present moment. All I am doing is pointing to the fact that the threat of a reprisal will frequently bring to an end a breach of international law on the part of another country. Indeed, Frederick Manning in his novel The Middle Parts of Fortune-albeit that it was a novel-rather aptly wrote:
War is waged by men; not beasts, or by gods. It is a peculiar human activity. To call it a crime against mankind is to miss out at least half its significance; it is also the punishment of a crime.

Fundamental to the function of armed conflict as a means of punishing violations of international law is in fact the right of reprisal, a right which can be exercised only in very limited circumstances and which is subject always to the principle of proportionality. The Attorney-General and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), who are at the table, must understand that. They know from speeches that I have made before that I am not in favour of just turning my back on the protocols to Geneva Conventions. One strives to find one's way through.

That is why I said that, if we could only have a set of circumstances where we could be in agreement on exercising reservations, which is not totally unknown-this Government has already ratified agreements during its period in office when it has expressed reservations-we would have had the bipartisan support that previously was expressed as the desire. No-one on this side gets any pleasure through opposing the protocol. We are simply doing it because we feel that the Government could be placing in jeopardy those who are directed to serve by dint of the decision of the Government in armed conflict.

Fundamental to the function of armed conflict as a means of punishing violations of international law is the right of reprisal, and reprisal is forbidden under this protocol. It is a right which can only be exercised, as I think I indicated, in very limited circumstances, and I mentioned the principle of proportionality.

At the time of the negotiations for the protocol, the Australian delegation entertained reservations. This is what was interesting. When there were negotiations involving the determination of this protocol, as I understand it, the Australian delegation entertained reservations concerning the extent of this prohibition against reprisals. I quote what the Australian delegation said:

. . . a reprisal is a sanction to deter further violations of the law. It is not an act of vengeance. The availability of this sanction may persuade an adversary not to commit violations of the law in the first place.

Those are not my words but the words of the Australian delegation negotiating this very protocol. Saddam Hussein has, on several occasions, sent out clear signals that he has no qualms about using chemical or biological weapons. This, of course, would be in contravention of many international instruments, including the Geneva protocol of 1925. The United States has maintained that it must reserve its right to resort to such weapons in defence. It does not want to use them and will do all it can to avoid doing so. But this reservation acts as a deterrent and must cause Saddam Hussein to think twice about unleashing weapons of mass destruction and slaughter, the effects of which on human beings are known.

The Attorney is one of the most reasonable members of this current Government, but on this issue he has shown a more closed mind than on most. He is a man for whom I have the greatest respect, but he and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) seem to have taken the view that any reservations to the protocol would be incompatible with its objects and, therefore, would not be permissible under article 19(c) of the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties.

With the greatest respect to the Attorney, I disagree. In practice, and having regard to the provisions of article 21 of the Vienna Convention, the effectiveness and legitimacy of such reservations very much depends upon the attitude taken by non-reserving states. If they remain silent, the reservation takes effect and the legal effect of the treaty on the reserving party is thereby modified. Alternatively, if they object to the reservation but not to the treaty coming into force, the effect is the same. Of the nations which have ratified the protocol, many have lodged reservations in order to address their concerns with the ambiguities found in the text of the protocol. We would not be Robinson Crusoe, we would not be on our own; many, as is always the case, have expressed reservations.

The present Government proposes that, should ratification take place, a declaration of understanding be lodged dealing with certain aspects of, as I understand it, articles 5, 44, 51, 52 and 57. These are the articles that the Government itself has admitted it has concerns with, so it is going to lodge a declaration of understanding. But a declaration of understanding is not a reservation. It just does not have the same meaning in international law. It is only an interpretative instrument and does not alter at all at the international level Australia's obligations under the protocol. We on this side of the House take the view that, given what the Prime Minister himself has acknowledged as the `ambiguities and operational complexities' of the protocol, what is needed are reservations to address the uncertainties that are created by the protocol in order to protect Australia's defence interests. Such reservations need to be very wide and must, amongst other things, preserve our right of self-defence.

I turn to consider the way in which the protocol attempts to make distinctions between civilian objects and military objects with a view to extending the protection afforded to the civilian population during armed conflict. The Attorney-General, in his second reading speech, noted that in times of war:
. . . such distinctions can become blurred and indistinct, and ultimately may even cease to exist in conditions of total war.
The effect of section 1 of part IV of the protocol-which contains the relevant provisions for the making of these distinctions-is to undermine the practicalities of doing so.

Article 48, which is referred to as the `basic rule', obliges nations `at all times' to `distinguish between the civilian population and combatants and between civilian objects and military objects' and to direct military operations `only against military objectives'. I emphasise the word `only'. Article 49 defines attacks to mean `acts of violence against the adversary, whether in offence or in defence'. So we see that this `basic rule' has a very wide ambit of operation.
Article 51.4 prohibits what are called `indiscriminate attacks' which include, by reason of Article 51.5(b), attacks:

. . . which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, injury to civilians, damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.

I emphasise the words `may'-that is, not shall or likely-`incidental', not significant or substantial, and `concrete and direct'. Similar language is used in article 57.2(a) (iii) which obliges nations to refrain from planning or deciding upon attacks which may have these effects. To compound the problem, paragraph (b) of article 57.2 provides that an attack shall be cancelled or suspended if, during the conduct of the attack, it becomes apparent that the attack `may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life'.

These provisions attempt to codify the well established principle of proportionality by which nations are obliged to not conduct military operations which cause unwarranted damage to civilian objects-something with which we would all agree. The real problem that arises with protocol I is the manner in which it attempts to reformulate this principle. The language adopted goes beyond a simple codification of the principle.

The provisions of article 56-which prohibits attacks on dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations or other installations containing dangerous forces-provides another illustration of the difficulties that the protocol would pose for our defence forces. In paragraph 1 of article 56, it is said that this prohibition applies `even where these objects are military objectives'. Under paragraph 2, the protection is removed if the normal function, as it is put, of the installation is to provide regular, significant and direct support for military operations.

Much of the allied bombing effort in the present conflict has been directed towards disarming Iraq's nuclear and chemical capabilities by attacking the very type of installations upon which article 56 seeks to bestow immunity. In making the hard decisions that are needed, I would hope that military commanders are not bogged down with legal niceties as to what the `normal function' of such an installation is, or whether or not there are three orange circles on such installations. We have heard much about sophisticated weaponry, precision bombing and smart missiles, but I think that, notwithstanding these technologies, article 56 is simply impossible in realistic military terms to comply with.

Section 1 of part III of the protocol deals with the methods and means of warfare. I intended to take the House through article 35 and the concerns I have there. There are particular concerns here in regard to the English translation and the French translation which leads to different words being used and various textual arguments introducing a very different subjective element in terms of suffering, the way injuries are addressed in that particular area. But as I draw to a conclusion in time I am simply unable to do that.

The reality of my remarks is that we, having participated in government at the outset of the deliberations on this protocol, wanted to achieve a sensible outcome. I understand the Government's desire to implement the protocol. I do not quite understand why it will not go along with expressing reservations rather than lodging the declaration of understanding, which it is now going to do, because both the Prime Minister's letter to President Reagan, as he then was, which leaked into this House some years ago with a reservation and the expressed concerns and the preparedness to lodge a declaration indicates to me that there are concerns in the minds of many in the Government over this issue. So make it neater, make it correct at international law and protect our own servicemen by expressing reservations. Were the Government to do that, we would give the Government support. But without that, we oppose the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BILNEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure, as always, to follow the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) in a debate of this kind. I imagine few people in this House have followed the processes of development of international law, particularly as regards the Geneva conventions, as closely as has the honourable member who has just spoken; if anyone were to come close, it would be the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Wilson), who I notice is to speak later in this debate on the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The premise on which the major hesitations of the honourable member for Kooyong were based is that the fact that we are not entering formal reservations to a number of provisions of the protocols would result in placing in jeopardy those who are directed to serve in conflict. That would be a substantial and reasonable objection if it were true. It is something that I propose to go to in some detail a little later in my speech.

As the honourable member for Kooyong listed the various provisions of the protocols in relation to which he felt the Government ought to enter reservations, I could not help feeling that they would constitute not so much a reservation as an emasculation of the protocols as a sensible contribution to the development of international law. In relation to the proposition that not entering reservations would place in jeopardy those who are directed to serve in conflict, I think that the best judges are those who are the practitioners. That is something to which I propose to return later in my remarks.

As my colleague the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has indicated, the purpose of the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990 is to ratify additional protocols which reaffirm and refine the laws of international armed conflict. Those protocols are in the main a restatement or codification of existing practice, which are designed primarily to strengthen the protection accorded prisoners of war and non-combatants. Their intention is to lessen the horror of war and restrict it to targets of military significance.

The development of these protocols has a long history, as honourable members know. During the course of that development, the Government has examined the protocols to ensure that they meet our national interests. In doing so, great weight has been given to their effect on Australia's capacity to conduct military operations both on our own and in partnership with our allies. I need to emphasise that the Government's conclusion, which I stress is based well and truly on advice from the chief of the Australian Defence Force (ADF), is that our national interest is best served by ratifying the protocols. Defence has concluded after a long and careful examination that it will be able to operate effectively within the constraints imposed by the Geneva protocols.

The critical provisions as they relate to defence are contained in articles 35 to 58 of protocol I. These articles work to limit the rights of parties to wage war by prohibiting weapons and methods which cause injury or suffering which is unnecessary to the achievement of a military objective. They prohibit attacks on a civilian population unless that population is taking a direct part in hostilities. They also seek to protect civilian sites, especially those of cultural and religious significance, and to preclude reprisals against the civil population.

These provisions of the protocols clearly impose obligations on commanders in the field. Those commanders must ensure that their objectives are military rather than civilian and that the means and methods of warfare which they employ minimise the incidental loss of civilian life. They must also protect civilians directly by endeavouring to remove them from proximity to military targets and not to locate such facilities in or near densely populated areas. As previous speakers have pointed out, the topicality and relevance of those provisions to the conduct of the conflict in the Gulf at present could not be greater. Certainly the tactics of Saddam Hussein in wilfully seeking to act in such a way as to frustrate those objectives are to be deplored.

It is in that connection I mention that wilful breaches of the provisions I have mentioned are characterised as war crimes. Under the terms of this Bill, we, along with other signatories and those who ratify, are obliged and empowered to punish such breaches under the domestic law of this country. It is the opinion of the Government that observance of these principles is necessary not only for the humanitarian conduct of armed conflict, but also for the success of military operations, paradoxical though that may seem. Enormous destruction of lives and civilian infrastructure can harden resolve in war and can undermine peace or the possibility of peace once hostilities cease. By the same token, it is true that it is impossible to conduct a war without some civilian casualties. These provisions seek to minimise such casualties and limit civil damage. The principal obligation on nations and commanders involved in armed conflict is to exercise judgment prudently and in good faith within the spirit of the conventions and protocols, based on information which is reasonably available to them in the field. But such responsibility is not new for senior military personnel.

Grave breaches of protocols cannot occur by accident; they require deliberate rejection of available evidence and wilfulness in commission of acts in breach of the protocols. That being so, and given the training, the experience and the professionalism of commanding officers in the Australian Defence Force, the Government simply does not believe that observance of the protocols will inhibit Australia's military personnel from prosecuting warfare as they have in the past.

The obligations and commitments required by the protocols are consistent with both Australia's defence policies and social values. However, some concern has been expressed that Australia's ability to conduct combined operations with our major allies might be compromised in a situation where we have ratified the protocols, but the ally has not. The ADF is structured, trained and equipped primarily to defend Australian sovereignty, and that, rather than inter-operability, must remain the organising principle of our defence efforts. Inter-operability with our allies in command and control, communications, doctrine, tactics and procedures remains an important goal, but it must always be a goal within the context of national defence requirements and policies.

Any lingering concerns that might have been held over our ability to inter-operate with our allies in the context of observing these protocols have been largely dispelled in recent weeks by the successful integration into the multinational Gulf force of our ships and personnel operating in the Gulf conflict. That ability to inter-operate builds on numerous exercises which we have conducted in the past with the allies that are part of the coalition forces in the Gulf, and that is something that will not be prejudiced in any way by our ratification of the protocols which are implied in this Bill.

So far 88 states have ratified both Geneva protocols, including the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) countries of Denmark, Norway, Italy, Iceland, Canada, Greece and Spain. Both the United Kingdom and the Federal Republic of Germany have signed the protocols, but have yet to ratify them. The United States and its NATO allies are currently involved in a continuing examination of the protocols to identify common ground in their interpretation. Australia is involved in this process, particularly in discussions with the UK, US, Canadian and New Zealand military officers over the development of military manuals which reflect the laws of armed conflict.

I want to make two points in conclusion. Firstly, Australia's ratification of the protocols will reaffirm our commitment to limiting the scope of war to military objectives and will strengthen the protection afforded to civilians and prisoners of war. It will do so at little cost to the ability of the ADF to operate effectively as an armed force and it therefore deserves the support not just of all honourable members or all Australians, but of all those who want to see greater `civilisation' of this process.

Secondly, I want to repeat what I said earlier: the conclusion that we have come to, as reflected in my remarks, is based squarely on advice from our defence advisers, the Chief of the Defence Force and those in the headquarters of the ADF. That advice is that our national interest is best served by ratifying these protocols and that there is no question that we will be able to continue to operate effectively within the constraints which these protocols impose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been pondering for some time why the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill has been brought on for debate as the first item in this session of the Parliament when it has had a fairly leisurely course through the Parliament. It is brought on now at a time when the war in the Persian Gulf is the subject of great interest giving rise to very strong feelings. It seems to me, on reflection, that this is, in substance, the Australian Labor Party's bromide-this is the opportunity for the Labor Party to say, `We are in favour of nice wars where nobody gets killed. We are in favour of wars where our military contribution is one where there is no real, immediate danger to a lot of people; where the war can be conducted and our objectives can be achieved but really our ships are not in immediate danger'.

SPEECH.PARA: In fact, there seems to be an underlying current running through all of the Government's public statements about the war that this is one where we can get by without too much difficulty. Not only is that so, but also we are now in a situation where the left wing of the parliamentary Labor Party has passed a resolution saying, as I understand it, that it thinks the whole thing should be called off. It is asking for a cease-fire. Over the last few days it has been a mystery to me not only as to how the Government can allow that sort of assertion to go unchallenged, but also as to how the press can omit to discuss the very substantial consequences that must arise from that left-wing resolution being passed.
