One of the ways out that the Government has adopted is to promote this piece of legislation, yet again, at this time to show that it is in favour of one of the nice things, the sort of war it believes can be conducted-namely, a war where civilians are protected. This, of course, is a nonsense argument and we know that civilians unfortunately are the casualties of war. None of us wants to see that situation continue and we have to have a sensible but practical approach to the problem of civilian casualties in war-one which will protect civilians as far as possible; one which is consistent with international law but one which, at the same time, does not excessively restrict the ability, flexibility and effectiveness of our armed forces.

I want to say a few things about the protocol, partly by questioning the way in which the Australian Government believes it will operate and, indeed, by way of asking what various clauses in the protocol actually mean. By way of an introduction, I make these preliminary points. Firstly, a number of provisions in the protocol are quite unexceptionable. All the desirable provisions relating to journalists and prisoners and the general provisions designed to protect the sick, wounded and injured are such that one would not, if one were a reasonable person, have any exception to them whatsoever. Indeed, they would be applied, and will be applied, by us and by other civilised countries with which we like to associate whether or not this protocol becomes part of the law. The United States will not deliberately and intentionally inflict casualties on civilians in this war. Nor will we. The United States does not have to subscribe to this protocol to bring about that result. Most of those provisions will be applied in practice by countries such as the United States, Great Britain and Australia even if this protocol never becomes law. That is the first thing that must be said about it.

The second thing that must be said is that some of the provisions of the protocol, as I interpret them, will severely restrict the effectiveness of our fighting forces and, indeed, may put them at risk. While there is any shadow of doubt as to whether that will happen, we should not proceed with this legislation and implement the protocol. We should not do that until we are absolutely satisfied-and we, on this side of the House are not satisfied yet-that the protocols will not excessively and unreasonably limit the effectiveness of our armed forces.

We want to be satisfied that the application of the protocol will not put our armed forces in excessive danger which they would not be subjected to if we were not bound by the protocol. At present that is not a situation we can say has been achieved. Indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was of this view himself at one stage when, in his letter to former President Reagan, he said that there were a number of `ambiguities and operational complexities'. We are not satisfied that that problem has yet been resolved. If it has been, we want a clear explanation of how it has been resolved. Until we are satisfied about that I, for one, am prepared to apply what the Prime Minister said in his letter-that is, that there are `ambiguities and operational complexities' in the terms of the protocol. We are not satisfied at the moment and we need to be satisfied before we will support this Bill.

By way of further explanation and illustration of this matter, I will make three additional points. For the purpose of this exercise I want to assume that, in the context of the present conflict in the Persian Gulf, Iraq, the United States of America and, for that matter, Australia have adopted the protocol and are applying it. We know that that is not the case, but the only sensible way of testing how this protocol will work in practice is by assuming that belligerent parties are in fact bound by it. So let us proceed on the assumption that in fact Iraq, the United States and Australia have adopted the protocol and are bound by it. If that is the case, how, in the present conflict, will article 52, paragraphs 2 and 3 be applied? Article 52, paragraph 2 says:
Attacks shall be limited strictly to military objectives.
There is more in the clause than that, of course, but that is the opening, and substantial, proposition contained in it.

The question then arises: what happens if there is doubt as to whether the target that it is proposed to attack is in fact a military or a civilian objective? In answering that question one has to remember that the obligation under the protocol-and I repeat it-is that attacks shall be limited, not generally to military objectives, but `strictly'. We must make the additional point before proceeding that if one enters into international agreements of this sort they must be complied with literally and strictly. It is pointless and quite dishonest to enter into them-to agree that one will be bound by them-and then to say, `We will play it pretty loosely at the edges and no-one will expect us to implement the terms of the convention strictly'. That is not a principle that Australia should comply with and if we are going to enter into this protocol and be bound by it we must adhere to its terms.

Bearing that in mind, the first troublesome part is the provision that says that attacks shall be limited strictly to military objectives. Having laid that foundation, I ask the question: what happens if there is doubt as to whether in the heat of battle and the immediacy of the situation we have to decide whether our target is a military objective or a civilian objective? That exact same question has arisen in this current conflict. We know that Iraq has sought to protect some of its military installations and its military equipment by masquerading them as civilian objectives and civilian structures. It puts the artillery piece into a mosque; it puts the Scud launcher into a mosque or into a school or a civilian area, like a closely settled suburb. Then, of course, it would say, if it were bound by this convention presumably, that that is still a school, it is still a house, it is still a mosque and surely it is a civilian target.

That is the query that arises if we are going to be honest and are going to apply this convention strictly, honestly and properly. The protocol gives us the answer to that question; it gives us the answer to that quandary. I believe that it is that answer which creates the very danger, as things stand at the moment, of adhering to the protocol. The answer is contained in paragraph 3. It says:

In case of doubt whether an object which is normally dedicated to civilian purposes, such as a place of worship, a house or other dwelling or a school, is being used to make an effective contribution to military action, it shall be presumed not to be so used.

In other words, the protocol itself gives us the answer that if in doubt we are not allowed to assume that it is part of the military infrastructure and, therefore, under paragraph 2 we are strictly not allowed to attack it. In other words, if we want to apply this protocol honestly, we would be in a situation where the civilian structure could not be attacked.

If we apply it again to the situation in the Persian Gulf war, Iraq would be free to continue to launch Scud missiles-against civilian targets in Israel and Saudi Arabia, I might add-from sites that are masquerading as civilian structures. Surely that is quite absurd and utterly ludicrous. Not only is it ludicrous but also if the United States, bound by this convention, were on the other side of that situation, it would be putting its own military forces at risk. It would be imposing excessive limitations, restrictions and inflexibility on its own armed forces and would not be able to do the job that it is there to do. That seems on the surface, in the absence of any explanation from the Government, to be one reason by itself as to why we need further elucidation on the terms of this protocol before we can honestly and genuinely support it.
The second provision that gives me concern is article 56. Paragraph 1 states:
Works or installations containing dangerous forces, namely dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generation stations, shall not be made the object of attack.
We ask the question: in all circumstances? We are given the answer, `Yes, virtually in all circumstances'. The same paragraph goes on to say:
. . . even where these objects are military objectives . . .
Even where those objects are military objectives, we may not attack dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations. We may ask: in all circumstances? Well, we are given a clue to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Keep reading.

—The honourable member says that I should read on. What it does not say, of course, is, `if such an attack will cause the release of dangerous substances or dangerous forces'. Rather it says, `if such an attack may result in that'. That is not just a legalism or a hairsplitting exercise. I again come to the point that if we are going to enter into the protocol we must do it in the spirit that we are going to comply with the terms of it. That provision is telling us that we may not attack those installations even where they are military objectives-so we are limited in our military exercise from the very outset-if the result of it is that we may cause the release of dangerous forces and consequent severe losses among the civilian population.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the question and hope we will get an answer from the Government: is that not an excessive and unnecessary restriction on one's military flexibility such that one is being excessively hampered in achieving one's military objective?-which is presumably an honourable one, otherwise I hope we would not be there the first place. Is that not the case? I believe that we are entitled to an answer from the Government. Article 56 goes on to say:
Other military objectives located at or in the vicinity of these works or installations-
they being the dams, dykes or nuclear generating stations-
shall not be made the object of attack if such attack may cause the release of dangerous forces . . . and consequent severe losses among the civilian population.

So we cannot even attack military objectives which are located at or nearby those installations, not only in those cases where if we do it, it is definitely going to cause severe loss to the civilian population, but if it may. We would maintain on the present understanding we have that that is an unfair and severe restriction on one's military capability such that one is not achieving one's military objective, which is supposed to be an honourable one anyway, and such that in addition to that one is putting one's own military personnel at risk. That is something that we are not prepared to do in the absence of a rational and sensible explanation from the Government. It would mean, again to apply it to the present conflict, that bound by this protocol the United States would have to say, `We're sorry, we can't attack that Scud missile launcher which is launching missiles onto civilian targets in Israel because the Scud missile launcher is parked on a dam or parked near a dam. If we hit the missile launcher we might hit the dam'.

There is no need for the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) to cover himself in such despair because the Government is promoting the protocol that says that if that may be the consequence we are not allowed to attack the dam and we are not allowed to attack the other military objective either which, in the example I have given, is the Scud missile launcher. Surely that is devoid of commonsense. In the absence of further rational explanation that persuades us, we will not support it.

The third thing I want to say is that the Prime Minister and Senator Robert Ray in their press interviews over the last few days have spoken, in my view sensibly, about civilian casualties in this war. The other day Senator Ray said:

What I said, and I didn't say they were avoiding civilian targets, I said they were not targeting civilians. A slight subtlety of difference that you might be able to pick up there is oil refineries quite clearly are military targets whether civilians work there or not. I have no belief that they should be isolated in some way. I mean these things are difficult. They're not in plain black and white. The attacks on oil tankers going down roads seem almost against civilians but the fact is that almost certainly the Iraqi's are putting their scud missile launchers in between those to try to disguise them. They are, and we should never underestimate, reasonably sophisticated military strategists in some areas, especially in deception.

Both the Prime Minister and Senator Ray have said consistently in line with proper and legitimate military practice principles that of course we avoid civilian casualties if we can, but there will be civilian casualties when our enemy seeks to hide his military objectives amongst civilian structures and amongst civilians. I maintain that the Prime Minister and Senator Ray were absolutely right in what they said. But I maintain that what they said would be wrong under this protocol. Before this debate concludes, I ask the Government: is it not the case that under the protocol what the Prime Minister has described could not occur?

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you may know, I spent a considerable time before I entered this House teaching international relations in various universities. A key component of international relations is the study of war. One of the most common observations about the study of war in international relations is that the regulations of peace are contained in a slim volume, and the regulations of war are contained in a thick volume. This is no paradox. It is precisely during war that the regulation of conflict and the conduct of international relations are most broken down. It is at that time that they are in most need of buttressing. Hence, most commentators believe it appropriate that most attention be paid to regulating international affairs when they are at their most barbaric and anarchic, that is, during war.

SPEECH.PARA: The regulation of warfare has concerned jurists since Grotius, the modern founder of international law. In essence, these regulations recognise the legitimate use of war as an instrument of state policy but seek to control both its outbreak and its conduct with reference to just means for its pursuit and prosecution. In this century various international conventions have been formulated to regulate the prosecution of war, most famously the various Geneva conventions-particularly those of 1925 and 1949.

These conventions are not just empty shells. They have produced a wide range of regulatory activities, including the almost universal avoidance of the use of poison gas-with the notable exception of Iraq-since the First World War, and the successful prosecution of Japanese war criminals for waging aggressive war and of Germans for waging crimes against humanity.

The 1949 Geneva Convention has been in place during a period of general peace and absence of world war. Nonetheless, about 160 local wars have been waged during those 40-odd years, and during those wars between 25 million and 30 million people have been killed. These wars have ranged in character from anti-colonial rebellions through civil wars and revolutions to classic set piece interstate wars of the kind that Iran and Iraq fought for eight years.

In some respects these limited wars are more easy to regulate by the actions of the members of the international community, most of whom are not involved in these limited wars. I believe that the framing of regulatory regimes for such limited wars is a most urgent task for the international community and should be continually developed.

I believe it is within this context that the additions to the 1949 Geneva Convention that are brought here today for ratification should be most urgently attended to. They involve protocol I, relating to the protection of the victims of international armed conflicts, and the accompanying protocol II, which relates to non-international conflicts. I appreciate that any such additions to the regulation of war cannot be unconditionally accepted without examination since they may provide legal discrimination in favour of some class or character of parties to conflict as against others and thereby afford unintentional military advantage to one side or another.

These particular protocols relate to prisoners of war and to civilians in particular-two categories of persons who are of great interest to all of us at a time when bombing of areas inhabited by civilians is being undertaken by both sides in the Gulf war and when prisoners of war are also being taken and held by both sides. If we look back to the 160-odd limited wars I referred to previously, we will see that civilians and prisoners of war have suffered often during these conflicts.

These particulars protocols were developed over a long period at the initiation of the International Red Cross. The final text of the protocols resulted from a number of sessions held in Geneva in the mid-1970s, concluding in 1977. It should be noted that many nations, including our own in 1978-when the present Opposition was in power-signed the protocols. Over 90 states have now ratified Protocol I, and 87 states have ratified Protocol II. We recommend that Australia join this very large number of states which seem to have suffered no outbreak of the Black Death as a result of ratifying them.

Such ratification will not cost anything for Australia financially. Essentially it extends the legal regulatory regime with respect to war. In particular, it calls for required punishment for those who barbarously ill-treat prisoners of war or refugees and for those who indiscriminately attack and impose undue and excessive loss of life on civilian populations. The relevance of both issues to the present war in the Gulf should be apparent.

Australians might in turn ask why ratification of these urgent protocols has taken so long to come before the House. The essential reason relates to the reluctance of the United States Government during the Reagan years, for reasons I will return to, to adhere to these protocols and this Australian Government's hope that the United States could be persuaded to change its mind in this respect and that we could then go in with our great and powerful friend.

In 1989, following the election of Reagan's successor, President Bush, it became clear that the United States' view would be maintained and that substantially the same position would be adopted by President Bush. The Bill was therefore first introduced into this House in 1989. The election last year interrupted its passage. This Government is now determined to go ahead with the ratification, the United States' position notwithstanding.

We had hoped that this ratification could be afforded bipartisan support, particularly in view of the Opposition's previous support for these protocols, and particularly in view of the shadow Minister concerned being the initial Australian signatory to the protocols. I genuinely regret, and with no crocodile tears here, that the Opposition has been unwilling or unable by its own lights to take this course. I respect much of the reasoning put forward by that side in the debate so far. But I think this is another issue on which this Government is going to have to disagree with its great and powerful friend and its otherwise firm ally, the United States, and get on with ratification and the improvement of the regulatory regime as it concerns the conduct of war, particularly in respect of innocent civilians and prisoners taken during the war.

The United States' rejection of protocol I was expressed clearly in the then President's letter to the United States Senate in January 1987. Essentially it revolved around the contention that the new rules applying to struggles for self-determination `elevates the international legal status of self-described national liberation groups that make a practice of terrorism'. This Government does not believe that this is the case but views the protocol as applying to, as laid out in article 1.4, `peoples fighting against colonial domination and alien occupation as enshrined in the Charter of the United Nations'.

This application, then, is quite specific and is limited to these kinds of struggles. It applies to both sides of the conflict when such struggles break out. In other words, we believe that it cannot be applied to terrorist organisations, properly defined, for reasons I will return to. I suppose that it might be conceded in a political way that the attitude of the Australian Labor Party and the Republican United States administrations of the last 12 years have somewhat differed from time to time in regard to the nature of national liberation movements and terrorist organisations.

I do not want to subscribe to the rather facile dictum, `One person's freedom fighter is another person's terrorist'. But I do appreciate that the political considerations often make it very difficult to lay down clear legal guidelines for what comprises a terrorist organisation, which often sees itself of course as having political and, therefore, strategic and international legal objectives. Historical differences between the US Republican Administration and this Government over, for example, the African National Congress in South Africa make this clear.

It seems to me that this protocol, in the clause to which I have referred and elsewhere, seeks to take steps to distinguish between terrorist and political liberation organisations. This is not easy but it clearly distinguishes between someone who is fighting for political democracy in a repressive situation, involving racist repression for example, and a fanatic who blows up airlines in his spare time for either cash or fun.

The second American objection in that letter was that the protocol would grant competent status to `irregular forces even if they do not satisfy the traditional requirements to distinguish themselves from the civilian population'. Again, we believe this interpretation to be erroneous, particularly since protocol I is applicable only to international armed conflicts.

Finally, the United States voiced some military reservations which were, I must concede-for a non-legal mind such as my own-rather difficult to follow but which appeared to relate to the fear of enhancing the international status of terrorist organisations. We should note that the American objections do not reflect majority international opinion, but are nonetheless cause for consideration by close allies such as Australia, and I concede this point readily to the Opposition. If it were the case that our ratification of these protocols, and the United States' rejection, significantly inhibited joint military actions with the United States, or inhibited what the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) has referred to as inter-operability, then our Government would have cause for pause, and I again readily concede that-not necessarily for rejection, but of cause for pause.

In fact, we have been conducting recent exercises in conjunction with American forces, notably the Kangaroo exercises, under protocol standards, and the United States forces have had no difficulty in complying with our activities. In any case, it should be noted, as the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel himself pointed out, that more than half of these countries that are operational in the Gulf War United Nations sponsored program to liberate Kuwait from the Iraqi occupation forces have in fact already ratified these protocols and appear to have no difficulty operating alongside United States forces. As the Minister has pointed out, our own forces have already advised him of the fact that it would involve them in no significant hindrances.

The list of countries-which I have not the time here to itemise-which have both ratified these protocols and are operating in conjunction with American forces is hardly surprising because the Americans themselves are in fact operating under the conditions laid down by these protocols without ratifying them, because they have other objections, to which I have already referred, bearing on the kind of force, the kind of political organisation that these protocols would recognise. In so far as the Gulf operations are concerned, the Americans are scrupulously adhering to the protocol determinations.

The protocols are designed to protect civilian populations to the extent consistent with the pursuit of legitimate military objectives. This makes the aerial bombardment of civilian targets alone illegal. Iraq has been attacking precisely such targets, in Israel and in Saudi Arabia in particular, whereas the coalition forces have only attacked military targets. If civilian facilities are used to aid military objectives-that is, by hiding tanks or artillery or Scud missiles in the way that the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. BROWN) itemised-the status of those civilian targets changes. The status of civilian forces becomes quite different and they come under the aegis of military operations.

This is why the nature of the bombing raids undertaken in the Gulf by the different sides is so important, and it is so important that the coalition bombing of military targets be demonstrated as coming within both international law in general and these protocols in particular. B52 bombing of the Iraqi forces occupying Kuwait and adjacent areas is completely legal. Similarly, the precision bombing of military targets-say, Scud missile launchers in civilian areas, say, Baghdad or Basra-is similarly legal. Collateral damage to civilian centres around such military targets remains legal while they are just that-that is, collateral-and their scope comprises a proportionate level relative to the military purpose for which they are employed. The video evidence of the accuracy of the smart bomb raids are necessary proof of legality, and even if we look at the Iraqi claims of the level of civilian casualties incurred in these bombings, it can be seen that this is quite insufficient to go anywhere near demonstrating an illegality in nature of the smart bomb precision bombing which has been undertaken.

In complete contrast to this, Iraq has undertaken indiscriminate bombing of civilian areas quite unrelated to the military conflict and with no military purpose-involving Saudi Arabia-and of cities of a state that is not even a party to the conflict-that is, Israel. In addition, it has used prisoners of war for propaganda purposes, and not only tortured them, but exhibited them on international television to show that it has tortured them. It has also used weapons that have long been declared illegal, including poison gas. It has sought to attack civilian populations by destroying their natural environment and water supply by pumping the world record size oil slick down the Gulf. Finally, it has explicitly stated its intention to use international terrorist organisations to inflict maximum damage on civilian targets totally unrelated and in no collateral way connected with the military conflict itself in the Gulf area.

In all these respects Iraq is waging a war illegally, and we regret that the United States has not brought its great weight to bear behind protocol I in order to enhance the authority of protocol I in order to further enhance the illegality of Iraq's actions. The United States has nothing to lose in this respect since it is scrupulously adhering to the legality of its pursuit and conduct of war.

The protocols require that military leadership assess whether any collateral civilian damage is thereby incurred, and whether it is proportionate to the military advantage to be won. I take the shadow Attorney-General's point that this may sometimes inconvenience military commanders in the field. My response to that, I am sorry to say, is one of being slightly aghast. The whole purpose of the regulatory regime when it is applied to war is to constrain the pursuit of war by unlimited means. It is precisely to ask military commanders to take into cognisance the level of civilisation that we have achieved, the unfortunate level of destructive capability that is achieved simultaneously, and the need to restrict military destructive capabilities in accordance with our prevailing civilisation norms. To the extent that this is inconvenient to military commanders, we may regret it, but I feel that this is a step on the road to progress and the establishment of a more just means of pursuit and prosecution of warfare. I note with great affection that the military in Australia has expressed its satisfaction with our adherence to these protocols, a further step towards the civilisation to which we all aspire.

It would be unrealistic to ignore the fact that we are debating these protocols at a time when Australia is in effect at war, and at war together with a major ally, the United States, which has reservations about these protocols. That is unfortunate, but as I have been at pains to demonstrate-and as the Government is sure is the case-this will not inhibit our joint operations with the United States now or in the future.

The second Opposition speaker had some other objections to make towards the ratification of these protocols, the central one of which I took to be around the nature of article 52. He raised some other articles, but let me just concentrate on article 52 as the central representation of the point he was making. The point was that this inhibits our capability of self-defence and the military defence of our nation by confusing the nature of civilian and military targets, and enabling a rogue state such as Iraq to hide military targets behind a civilian fence, which then makes them unattackable, and puts us at a physical disadvantage. If this were the case, I would have my own reservations about these protocols as a person who has taught at Duntroon Military College, as it was then known, and at the Joint Services Staff College at Weston Creek-and my good wishes to all those officers who are still there. But article 52 does nothing of the kind. Article 52 defines civilian objects by reference to military objectives, and what it says, for example, is this: should a house, normally a civilian dwelling, be destroyed simply because it is there? The answer is no. But if it provides shelter for military action such as by hiding a command post, a bunker, a tank, or even an observation post, or a Scud missile, then it changes in character and ceases to be solely a civilian facility, and now has a military character and becomes subject to the kind of military operations that other military facilities would be subject to.

Finally, let me summarise where I believe we are at. Protocol I further inhibits the use of force in war by placing additional limits on states' legal behaviour with respect to civilians, refugees and prisoners of war. The United States has objected to the extension of the rules to include entities it fears may include terrorist organisations. We on the Government side of the House disagree with this interpretation. We also note that in almost all other respects the United States in fact goes out of its way to comply with the code of military conduct embodied in these protocols. As a result, inter-operability- or joint actions involving US and Australian forces-has not been and will not be inhibited by these protocols. The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has gone to great lengths to explain this point.

Finally, it is precisely the rogue-style states which we are likely to get in conflict with, like Iraq, which are most in need of regulation by such Geneva conventions and their protocols; and if a new international order is to replace the Cold War of the last four decades, it is precisely such regimes that must be regulated by the international community coming up with more and more strictly enforceable rules concerning the conduct of conflict by such rogue states. We may have certain reservations about the precise nature of these protocols, but the fact is they are a step down the road of civilising the international community, and they deserve our support. It is against this background of the desirability of expanding these rules governing the conduct of conflict and war in the international community that I urge members to support this Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with considerable sadness that I rise to oppose the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990. Anybody who has been close to a war situation is revolted by what he has experienced. Therefore, the broad thrust of this Bill, its desire to bring more relief to the suffering of innocent civilians in times of war, is to be commended.

SPEECH.PARA: There are, of course, several honourable members of this House who have extensive and distinguished active military service. It seems to be the practice of this place to state one's credentials up front. My own experience was 24 years service in the Royal Air Force. My exposure to active service included time in Singapore and Malaysia prior to those countries achieving their independence and during the Malaysian emergency, and three years in Cyprus during part of that country's inter-communal and often anti-British strife.

Of course, there are many Australians outside of this place who have a very distinguished and more extensive service record than I do. So I do not set myself up as an expert. However, having had some exposure, I felt that it was incumbent upon somebody in this place to speak on behalf of those who actually have to go out into the field and fight on behalf of their fellow countrymen.

Regrettably, there are too many lawyers and other armchair experts who sit in offices and deal in hypothetical situations. In short, I wish to talk about the realities of operating in an actual war situation. I have great sympathy for the views expressed by honourable members who support the Bill. However, I echo the sentiments of the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) when he says, in effect, that good intentions can sometimes be more dangerous than sound, practical application.

In my view, honourable members should be aware that there are large parts of this Bill that are just impractical. It would be grossly unfair to inflict such limitations on our own armed forces. My principal objections are: the total impracticality of applying much of what is being proposed in a war situation; the likely inadvertent breach by Australian servicemen of this convention when operating alongside friendly forces whose country may not have ratified the convention-we are not talking about inter-operability; we are talking about a question of law-and, finally, the incredible lack of everyday, practical, commonsense provisions of the Bill, whereby the hands of Australian forces in the field, and of their commanders in particular, will be tied in a totally unacceptable way.

I should like to look at some of the particular provisions of the Bill. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) dealt somewhat graphically with article 52 and with article 56, so I will not repeat all of that. However, I should like to move to article 57. Paragraph 2(A) (III) says that those who plan or decide upon an attack shall refrain from deciding to launch any attack which may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life or injury to civilians or damage to civilian objects, or a combination thereof, which would be excessive in relation to the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated.

It goes on to say that an attack should be cancelled or suspended if it becomes apparent that the objective is not a military one, or is subject to special protection, or the attack may be expected to cause incidental loss of civilian life, et cetera. It then goes on to say:
Effective advance warning shall be given of attacks which may affect the civilian population, unless circumstances do not permit.

What this means, when assessing whether it would be lawful to attack ammunition depots and defence research and development establishments, seems very clear to me. I believe it would probably always be unlawful under this convention because those who are seeking to prove it is lawful will always, of course, have the onus cast upon them. The only way it can be done would be to prove that a dangerous substance had not escaped and no civilians in the area could possibly be affected. If such an installation was located in the middle of the Sahara Desert, that might be possible. But in a country with a large population, or a high population density, that would be almost impossible. The Australian Department of Defence joint working party stated:
Merchant seamen are civilians and as a merchant ship is prima facie at least a civilian object, the article does impose some restraints on the conduct of naval operations.

I would suggest that that is a masterpiece of understatement. It is obvious that the effect of the protocol will be to make it unlawful to attack the means of production, storage and distribution of war materials, and this will change fundamentally the way that modern war is waged. Presumably that is the object of the exercise.

Unfortunately, the other side may not be equally gentlemanly. What this is saying to our Australian armed forces-should the Government ratify this convention-is that if there are civilians within a bull's roar of a legitimate military target, which our forces may well not even know about at the time, they cannot attack that legitimate military target. This is because subsequently they may be found to have breached the over-narrow definition of the convention. Article 59 states:
It is prohibited for the parties to the conflict to attack, by any means whatsoever, non defended localities.

Such a non-defended locality should fulfil the following conditions: all combatants as well as mobile weapons and mobile military equipment must have been evacuated; no hostile use shall be made of fixed military installations or establishments; no acts of hostility shall be committed by the authorities or by the population; and no activities in support of military operations shall be undertaken.

I ask these questions: who is to know what is there? Who is to know what is non-defended? Who is to know that the other side is playing the gentleman's game and being honest? I suggest that this makes absolute nonsense of the whole strategy of war which this country, God forbid, needs from time to time to wage.

I make the point that war is not an attractive thing, as we are seeing in the Gulf conflict today. But for hundreds of years wars have been fought out often without the civilian population back home being aware of the reality, the brutality and the suffering. Television has meant that wars are now replayed every night in our lounge rooms courtesy of Cable News Network (CNN). People are naturally and properly horrified by what they are now seeing. However, I believe that the fact that it is now common knowledge in the lounge rooms does not change the actuality of the battle front. The reality of war is that no-one can go into any active service situation using half measures. If someone is going to fight, he must fight to win, otherwise he should not waste his time or the lives of his troops, because all he will do is cause more suffering and prolong the agony for all concerned on both sides.
Let me move to article 82-legal advisers in the armed forces-and I quote:

They shall ensure that legal advisers are available, when necessary, to advise military commanders at the appropriate level, on the application of the conventions of this protocol and on the appropriate instruction to be given to the armed forces on the subject.

A commander's responsibilities, may I remind the House, extend to troops ordinarily under his command, also to troops under his operational control for a particular operation and for a limited period of time, and even sometimes to civilians or other persons under his control. Legal advisers, the convention proposes, must be made available to the commanders in time of armed conflict to advise on the application of the conventions and the protocol.

In practice, I believe that commanders will experience great difficulty with the protocol because it fails to list or describe their duties and responsibilities in any practical way. They will find it essential to seek legal advice on operational plans, and on operations during execution both to ensure that there is no overt breach of the protocol and as a desirable precaution in preparation for the inevitable post-mortems.

The viability of this process of consultation, for example, during the heat of battle or when communications are poor is, I would suggest, open to question. The number of legal advisers is limited, and it is unlikely that they can be made available during battle conditions to all levels of commanders who may require assistance.

As a young man of 19 years I was in Singapore in a local insurgency situation. We sometimes went out on riot duty. When we did this, we formed a riot square-a body of men with armed troops on the front and down the side and across the back to protect us from people shooting and throwing things and all the rest of it. In the middle we had a `tape man' who ran out a couple of hundred yards in front of the riot square and rolled a tape across the road and then nipped back smartly. Then two `banner men' with large poles unfurled a banner in multiple languages that said to the people who were shooting and firing at us, `Don't cross the tape, or we will fire'. The truth of the matter is that if we did not have any magistrate along and the commander was able to take action at a reasonably early stage, we minimised any casualties. If we had a legal man along, the tendency was that we would wait and we would wait and we would wait. That, of course, meant that the local crowd would get more and more agitated. They would get more and more bold in what they were doing and then, ultimately, their violence would become much worse. Then when the magistrate finally gave the commander permission to take some action, a far greater degree of force was required to restore order, and this usually resulted in far more casualties being incurred on both sides.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just before the dinner break, I related an example from my own experience in Singapore of having a magistrate in tow. Invariably when that magistrate was present, his delaying and his hesitation resulted in the need for a greater use of force than in a normal situation.

SPEECH.PARA: To continue where I broke off, I point out that some years later I was also involved in a subsequent experience as an officer in Cyprus during civil unrest and community disturbances. I was in command of troops who had been issued with live ammunition that they were not allowed to load. When threatened by an intruder or rioter they had to formally challenge three times before they were even allowed to put that ammunition `up the spout', as the local phrase was; in other words, to load. The view amongst most of the troops was that the only time one would actually be allowed to defend oneself was after one had been shot.

There were occasions when servicemen were court-martialled for having used live ammunition without giving the required number of warnings, even when there had been no casualties. They had acted out of a pure sense of self-preservation. In reality if you impose unreasonable conditions on commanders and troops in the field they are likely to ignore them because they are in peril of their lives. Afterwards, of course, all sorts of alleged activities change in the cold light of day with the benefit of hindsight, with the benefit of self-justification or for the benefit of political purposes. If it is a matter of recognition of troops, for example, arm bands can be added to a body to prove that they were separately identified, or removed from a body to prove that they were not separately identified.

Who is to say-especially when reporting after the event-that action taken in the heat of the moment was right or wrong or reasonable or not reasonable? I suggest to the House that we will be tying the hands of our forces if we send them off into any active service situation under the proposed rules.

The drafters of the protocol have attempted to widen its application. In their attempts to satisfy the goal of giving increased protection to the civilian population and at the same time to stop future military infringements on human liberties, the protocol has tended to raise more questions than it has been able to resolve successfully. This places great burdens on the field commander whose job it will be to interpret, apply and justify his actions in accordance with the protocol guidelines in the day-to-day operational setting.

From article 57(2) it can be seen that the protection of civilians is of paramount importance. In affording this increased security the drafters of the protocol, intentionally or not, have made more complex the job of those whose responsibility it will be to implement and abide by the document. The previous speaker alluded to this and said that if it were more difficult for them, unfortunately, that had to be. I believe that the wording employed allows wide and, at times, varying interpretations of the inferred standard. This is just not acceptable for commanders in the field. What is meant, for example, by the phrase `have done everything feasible'? What are `all feasible precautions'? What is `excessive'?

Finally, I would like to make the point that it is all well and good to say that a majority of nations of the world have subscribed to this convention, but the reality is that most of the leading nations of the world-those who actually have to keep the peace-have not subscribed and they have not done so for some very good reasons. As I started by saying, the intent of this Bill is excellent and it is with genuine regret that I feel compelled to speak against it. However, above all, we must look after the interests, well-being and rights of our own forces.

This Bill is out of touch with the realities of a war situation. It does not protect Australian soldiers when operating alongside friendly forces who are not signatories to the protocol. It assumes the other side will play by the rules and that, I can assure you, does not happen in war. It ties our own forces' hands in an active service situation and, therefore, will break down in practice on the field of battle.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not in the CDF's view.
—I would beg to differ with him and I think a lot of his men would as well. With great regret, I urge the House to reject the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr Mr D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a tragic irony it is today that we stand debating the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill, a measure almost universally approved by the international community, at a time when this nation's forces are engaged in armed conflict alongside allied powers the majority of which are not yet signatories to this convention. It is a tragedy because there might be some properly expressed interests by the Iraqis on this particular issue-the question of civilian injury. Almost every other argument that is advanced by the Iraqis, in my view, is palpably implausible, monstrously in error and generally hypocritical. However, in relation to the question of civilian casualties, I think we have an issue of substance to deal with.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very important that we are today discussing our accession to a protocol which would deal with our responsibility internationally in this area. It is also an irony that the Opposition is speaking against the accession to this protocol against a background of Australia being one of the initial sponsors under the then leadership of Prime Minister Fraser. The honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), the then foreign Minister, was a prominent sponsor of this very protocol which now comes before the House. This protocol did not emerge from a body in which Australia played no part and had no participation. It emerged from a dialogue between nations in which the then Australian foreign Minister, now shadow Attorney-General and formerly Leader of the Opposition, was Australia's voice in sponsoring and endorsing this particular measure. It is also against a background where Australia's own armed forces, in advice to this Government, say that none of the spurious arguments raised by the Opposition have merit. The advice formally tendered to our Government in relation to this matter is that nothing in this protocol binds the hands of the Australian armed forces in any manner which is prejudicial to the conduct of their proper role in the defence of this country, or in terms of the carriage of their responsibilities with allied forces. Indeed, the terms of engagement which have been set by this Government in the Gulf crisis recognise and in practice support already compliance with the terms of this protocol. So the Australian forces engaged in hostilities at the moment are already bound by the terms of engagement to the formal requirements of this protocol.

What is it in the Geneva convention that can possibly raise the ire of any person who has any commitment whatsoever to basic humanitarianism and an understanding of our responsibilities to our fellow men, even at times when we are in armed conflict with them? If one turns to the key elements of the Geneva convention-the first protocol-there are two major provisions which define what are called grave breaches. Under clause 5 of the Bill, grave breaches are the provisions which become justiciable, which can come before an Australian court, as war crimes in this country.

What can become war crimes? Firstly, if one turns to section 11, it is a war crime to inflict on any person in the care of hostile forces physical mutilation, medical or scientific experiments or removal of tissue organs for transplantation. Is it claimed in any way that any civilised nation would engage in those practices and that we could condone it? Article 85 (3) defines further `grave breaches'. They include acts which:
. . . when committed wilfully, in violation of the relevant provisions of this Protocol, and causing death or serious injury to body or health.
These include:
(a) making the civilian population or individual civilians the object of attack-

that is, the intended object of attack-not the words, collateral damage, that are used so neutrally on the Cable News Network, but the intended object of attack; the wilful attack on innocent civilians. They also include:

(b) launching an indiscriminate attack affecting the civilian population or civilian objects in the knowledge that such attack will cause excessive loss of life, injury to civilians or damage to civilian objects, as defined in Article 57 . . .
Article 57 talks about important cultural and historical buildings and the like. The breaches also include:
(c) launching an attack against works or installations containing dangerous forces-
for example, a nuclear power plant or something else that contains explosives or other such materials-
in the knowledge that such attack will cause excessive loss of life, injury to civilians or damage to civilian objects . . .
(d) making non-defended localities and demilitarized zones the object of attack . . . making a person the object of attack in the knowledge that he is hors de combat-
in other words, deliberately attacking a person who has been taken from the battlefield-
and the perfidious use, in violation of Article 37, of the distinctive emblem of the red cross, red crescent or red lion-
in other words, coming on to the battle field and using those symbols to disguise some military objectives. Neither Australia nor any other civilised nation would resort to those measures.

It is said that it is possible that some other foe not signatory to this convention might resort to such measures, and certainly that is the case. If one looks at this convention, many aspects of it already have been breached-for example, in the case of the present hostilities by Iraq. Many instances of that have been demonstrated. But does that excuse us from implementing warfare in a manner which is contrary entirely to the edicts of a civilised world and does that excuse us from accepting any responsibility for the conduct of our armed forces? It is said again in terms of argumentation that because the United States and Great Britain are not signatories yet to this convention, in some way we are excused from the exercise of our own moral judgment and moral responsibility. Plainly, that exudes a different form of morality than that of which I am cognisant. One cannot excuse one's own inability to conceive of and to stand by international standards of which all nations ought to have cognisance by saying others stand outside that regime.

If ever one had a platitudinous statement of why the United States has not yet ratified or acceded to the convention, one would only need to listen to the explanation given by the former President of the United States on 29 January 1987 where he urged the Senate not to ratify this protocol because the Department of State was of the view that the protocol would undermine humanitarian law and endanger civilians at war. Anyone reading this convention, anyone having a jot of independent judgment, would reject that as platitudinous nonsense. It is plainly untrue.

We, in terms of our responsibilities, should not be craven and set aside and simply accept what others might so hypocritically and foolishly advance. Rather, we should use the councils that we do have. We should use the standing we do have now with our allies and our friends, to say to them, `Nothing stands in the way of your accession to this convention'. That is the reality because, in practice, the United States observes those practical constraints which form this convention. Daily we see the representatives of the United States stand before the television cameras and inform us of the very strict protections and controls they have instituted on their own attacks on military targets in Iraq with the object of making certain that civilian targets are not even accidentally struck. In addition to that, we are told of the very strict rules they have to prevent the destruction of cultural objects-mosques and the like.

It is true, as the allied forces have conceded and must concede, that in any conflict there is the possibility of collateral damage, of innocent civilians being hit and affected-and that is a tragedy of all conflict. But for us to not follow through on this and say that the Australian Government repudiates utterly a policy which would allow it to inflict force on the civilian population by way of policy is simply wrong. Unfortunately, this convention arose out of a very real set of facts. It arose out of World War II. It arose out of a series of anti-colonial guerilla wars also, where civilian targets were abused.

World War II, for example, is replete with examples where the Germans firstly sought to bring Britain to its knees by indiscriminate attacks on cities such as London and Coventry. Then the allies, who generally approach warfare in a manner consistent with the Geneva Conventions, made one of the great mistakes of World War II-the bombing of Dresden. The bombing of Dresden was a tragedy for which Churchill and the allied war leaders are properly condemned. Even in the circumstances of that great conflict, that we can now look back and say that the destruction of Dresden was an act of infamy is a tribute to our own ability to reject from our own arsenal of war those measures which are no longer appropriate to civilised conflict.

There are some, I suppose, who might say that when warfare reigns, it is open slather-there are no constraints; it is the lowest common denominator. They say, `Whatever the implements of war-gas, torture, indiscriminate destruction of civilians-it is all the same; go for it'. That has not been the course of development in terms of thinking in the community of nations. It is one which we would wish to put behind us. War is a horrible enough experience as it is. Increasingly, our technology of destruction is becoming so potent that many, many thousands of persons in uniform will be exposed to extreme danger even by unseen enemies. The capacity for massive destruction of civilian targets, if that is attempted, exists on a scale never before known to this world.

The only form of restraint that the international community has to prevent us from descending into barbarism is self-restraint-self-restraint imposed by a collective acknowledgment that there are some basic principles which override our own national interest in the short term. So we come to an acceptance that, even in a time of war, we impose on ourselves some kind of limits. I reject entirely the argument that if it is convenient to disregard those limits, if it is simple to disregard those limits, those limits should be so disregarded. It is not an argument capable of being so resolved.

There are two important elements to the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill which are worthy of comment. Firstly, as I said, clause 5 makes criminal as war crimes punishable in this country those grave breaches of the protocol which I have read. There are also provisions which are very important in terms of standards for the protection of personnel who are captured. There are provisions which relate to the protections and entitlements of the Red Cross, the Red Crescent and other organisations of that nature. There are also provisions relating to the protection of prisoners of war. Importantly, in that regard, there is a provision which allows a person in detention in this country to apply to the Federal Court for a declaration that he is subject to those provisions as a prisoner of war.

Before I conclude, I might mention other provisions of a more general nature which are not set out as are those under articles 11 and 85, which define grave breaches of the protocol, but are equally important in setting out rules which we would now regard as important for all nations to adhere to.

For example, section III provides for rules for nations to notify others in relation to missing and dead persons, something that arose in the Vietnam conflict where the North Vietnamese kept back information in relation to missing US soldiers, causing grave distress to their relatives and friends. This convention sets down as a rule of international law that a country which knows of the names of missing and dead personnel has an obligation to pass them on to relatives in the country of the hostile party and to return at a time when it is appropriate the remains of those deceased, if that is practicable.

It also sets out provisions for dealing with prisoners of war. Finally, article 35.3, very importantly in the context of the present hostilities in the Gulf, sets out a provision of international law, saying:
It is prohibited to employ methods or means of warfare which are intended, or may be expected, to cause widespread, long-term and severe damage to the natural environment.

Yet these very provisions are not acceded to not only by Iraq, but also by the United Nations, Great Britain and, until now, Australia. I find it absolutely hypocritical and reprehensible that people who can stand up and condemn Iraq for those kinds of actions can then turn around, sit on the opposite side of this House and refuse to accede to an international convention which prohibits such actions. It seems to me to be hypocrisy of the grossest and most outstanding kind that I have had the misfortune to hear in this House. I conclude my remarks with those observations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened with interest to the comments of the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr), and I believe that he is genuine in what he says. I also acknowledge that I agree with the majority of the points that he raised while speaking to this House. One of the problems of this debate is that we have some reservations. If the Government were to support those reservations, we would have a changed position with respect to the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened to a number of people with academic and legal backgrounds speaking on certain aspects of the Bill. I have listened to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) speak of the support that he has from the Chief of the General Staff and from the Australian Defence Force chiefs, but I must say that the comments that rang closest to home for me were those made by the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) because he was looking at the issues on the ground, the sort of issues that I intend to look at this evening in light of my military background and experience. I believe that they are the issues that are critical to this whole exercise.

One of the real problems is that it is very easy for people to put down simple solutions on a piece of paper while sitting behind a desk having a cup of coffee, but it is a darned sight different trying to put down on a piece of paper the way to deal with these situations if one is being shot at. I listened to the honourable member for Adelaide (Dr Catley) talk about the clear distinction between houses where civilians lived and obvious locations where the enemy would be and where enemy products, ordnance, would be stored. That is very clear while sitting behind a desk or standing up speaking in a place such as this, but it is a damned sight different trying to differentiate between those locations when one is out on the ground being shot at.

That is really what we are on about in this debate. Let us get away from the legalistic and academic terms of those who would like to see wars and other such types of activities placed into a very clinical situation. Quite frankly, I agree with the propositions that are being put. It would be great to put people into those situations.

In thinking of this, I am reminded of the young lieutenant in the United States who was court martialled because of the actions that his troop took in a Vietnamese village. I certainly do not condone any of those actions, and I am sure that nobody would. But the fact of the matter is that we are talking about young lieutenants in their early 20s with soldiers of around the same age who are going to have responsibilities for units in front line fighting-conflict situations-who are going to have to make split second decisions about the survival of their forces, the soldiers that they have around them, and about where they are going to move their troops on the ground. On top of that, we are going to ask them to make decisions about whether a house has only civilians in it.

I think that we have to get back to the realities of this issue. I question whether a lot of these aspects affecting front line soldiers are being thought through. Let me just refer to the schedule to the Bill. Article 39.1 reads as follows:
It is prohibited to make use in an armed conflict of the flags or military emblems, insignia or uniforms of neutral or other States not Parties to the conflict.
Article 39.2 reads as follows:
It is prohibited to make use of the flags or military emblems, insignia or uniforms of adverse Parties while engaging in attacks or in order to shield, favour, protect or impede military operations.

That is great academic stuff, but when we get down to the reality of it, in how many conflicts have people changed uniforms? In how many conflicts have people gone into a situation in civilian clothing? On how many occasions may we require our special forces to wear civilian clothing firstly to protect their identity and secondly for their safety. I do not know, but the situation could well arise where we would need our special forces to go in wearing civilian clothing, knowing that they were going to carry out military actions. As I read this, such actions would become illegal and prohibited. I defy anybody to say that that is not the case from a reading of the article. Article 44.3 reads:

In order to promote the protection of the civilian population from the effects of hostilities, combatants are obliged to distinguish themselves from the civilian population while they are engaged in an attack or in a military operation preparatory to an attack. Recognising, however, that there are situations in armed conflict where, owing to the nature of the hostilities an armed combatant cannot so distinguish himself, he shall retain his status as a combatant, provided that, in such situations, he carries his arms openly:
(a) during each military engagement, and
(b) during such time as he is visible to the adversary while he is engaged in a military deployment preceding the launching of an attack in which he is to participate.

Really, it is legal, academic jargon. Military people out in the field are expected to wave their arms around so that they can be seen. Quite frankly, the whole exercise is just laughable when we get down to talking about the nuts and bolts of it, the military soldiers on the ground in the front line. Let me refer to a further article. Article 51.4 reads:
Indiscriminate attacks are prohibited. Indiscriminate attacks are:
(a) those which are not directed at a specific military objective;
(b) those which employ a method or means of combat which cannot be directed at a specific military objective; or
(c) those which employ a method or means of combat the effects of which cannot be limited as required by this Protocol . . .

In a military situation, bearing in mind that one is being fired on, how is one going to distinguish between specific military objectives? I would suggest that one cannot. The Government is proposing that we sign these protocols. If we sign the protocols, we will in fact honour all the clauses of the protocols. If we do not, it is pointless going through the process of signing them. I just wonder what the Government's answer is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Your arguments are nonsense; that is our answer.

—That does not surprise me. The honourable member for Denison says that my arguments are nonsense. The fact is that he has not been in a military situation where he has been fired upon. Maybe if he had been, he would have thought through more seriously some of the consequences of these protocols.

SPEECH.PARA: I go on to another of the articles-legal advisers in armed forces. Article 82 states:

The High Contracting Parties at all times, and the Parties to the conflict in time of armed conflict, shall ensure that legal advisers are available, when necessary, to advise military commanders at the appropriate level on the application of the Conventions and this Protocol and on the appropriate instruction to be given to the armed forces on this subject.

When we are in a battle situation, a conflict situation, will we sit around and jeopardise our soldiers while we seek the advice of legal people, during which time our opponents will get themselves into more secure positions?

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the honourable member for Denison.

—Like the honourable member for Denison, yes, and a few of the other members who spoke a little earlier, as the honourable member for Forrest suggests. Quite frankly, we are genuinely concerned about the articles we are looking at and saying are a problem in this Bill. I understand the support that has been sought by the Minister from the chief military people, and he has indicated in this place that he has that support.
—And you are wiser.

—The honourable member for Denison says that I am wiser. Having been involved in a military conflict, I do consider myself wise enough, in going through these articles, to have major reservations about whether they should be supported. I think that the Government should have major reservations. In fact, all we are asking of the Government is the signing of the protocol with agreed reservations. I do not think we are asking too much.

SPEECH.PARA: We have said that we will support the Bill provided those reservations are put in place. The Government is not prepared to do that. I believe that, as somebody who has served in an infantry battalion and been in conflicts of the nature described in these protocols, I would have difficulty in assessing the difference between civilian houses and enemy houses. It is not easy to say that. It is also not very easy to say that, if one goes into a house where there are civilians, the right thing has been done. It is not easy to go through that process. But unless they have been in a situation where they have been hyped up and shot at, I defy anybody to be able to make a judgment in that situation.

All I am doing in this debate is trying to provide for the members of the Government and the Minister some of the problems as I see them. They are the grassroots, ground level problems for the front line of an infantry battalion. I am not talking about the commanders sitting behind that position. However, I know several of our senior military people, and I consider them to be very capable. But under the current circumstances there is no way that I can support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon The Hon W.E.

TALKER.NAME: Mr SNOWDON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to speak and participate in this debate on the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill. I will comment on some of the contributions that have been made. I will also make some reference to the contribution made by the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson). But before that I compliment my friend the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) for articulating in a very clear way the moral arguments, the very persuasive arguments, why we as a community should be supporting the Government's position on these protocols.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that it is not a question of saying that we want a reservation. After all, we are representing humanity. It is not an issue that can be discussed within the realms basically of the legal confines of this place. What sort of human beings are we that we cannot come together and agree that there are some limits to the way in which we will operate in a theatre of war? That is what this is about.

I am a little confused because it was, after all, the Opposition that brought this matter on in the first instance when it was in government. It is now taking a number of points which I believe to be in every respect factuous. I pay tribute to the honourable member for Isaacs for the way in which he put his argument. No doubt he did it with great sincerity, and I pay tribute to him for that. However, I do not agree with him, because it seems to me that the logical conclusion of what he was saying is that the chief of the Defence Force does not know what he is doing. If he respects the hierarchy of the defence forces, as I do-and he said that he did-then it seems to me that he would have to say that the hierarchy has taken account of what it believed to be the best interests of its troops.

As the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), who is sitting at the table, said, the chief of the Defence Force has essentially said that it is in Australia's interests to sign these protocols-that is important-along with 88 other countries at this time. Are all those other countries barbaric? Are all those nations taking a position where they do not understand the nuances involved in these protocols? I am sure they do.

Whilst I have a great deal of respect for the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) and, indeed, the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. BROWN), the arguments that they put this afternoon in this place had the same hollow ring about them. For example, the honourable member for Kooyong made a number of statements saying that these protocols may place too many impediments upon our armed forces and even endanger them. I find that odd. Is the honourable member for Kooyong saying that the chief of the Defence Force, someone who is charged with the responsibility of advising this Government as well as commanding the defence forces at that level, is not in a position to make a judgment about what is and what is not appropriate for the defence forces? He said that he was reluctant to give the Bill his bipartisan support and enumerated a number of clauses within the protocols. He said that he had some problem with articles 35, 42, 44, 48, 49, 53 and 56. No-one is doubting the difficulty in implementing these protocols. That is not the issue.

The honourable member for Kooyong also stated that observance of the protocols would prohibit the defence forces from prosecuting wars as they have in the past. If we prosecute wars as we have in the past, I do not believe that is appropriate. If we must have war, I would have thought that the best thing we can do for the civilians we represent and the civilians who, unfortunately, in the present instance, live in Iraq is to agree on some basic and fundamental principles on how to wage those conflicts. It is not unreasonable, I would have thought, for reasonable people-people with at least some fundamental belief in the goodness of humankind-to come to some agreement. There may well be difficulty in implementing some of these things, but that does not mean they should not be tried, nor does it mean we should not give assent to these protocols. It is worth noting that what we are doing is providing a declaration of understanding.

There is no need for reservations. If we have reservations, why would we want to even endorse the protocols? We would not want to endorse them, because we would think they were wrong. By a reservation, we are essentially saying that we do not think we have an appropriate instrument. There is no point in having reservations. People either agree with the protocol or do not agree with it. The honourable member for Kooyong came into this place and made the point that he believes reservations would be appropriate. The honourable member for Menzies came in here and said that he believes we should have these reservations.

In my mind, there is a fundamental dishonesty in that approach. As I say, it may be difficult to implement this protocol, but it is important that we at least try. I concur with the honourable member for Denison, who expressed his concern not only that Iraq is flouting these principles but also that the chief protagonists amongst the allies have not endorsed the protocols. That is a concern. I think the allies ought to endorse them. If there is any moral persuasion that we as a community can use to suggest to them that they ought to do it, we should use it.

We do not have these conflicts because we want war. It is in our own best interests, the interests of people on both sides of conflicts, to ensure that, at least as far as is possible, they are conducted in such a way as to protect the innocent. I have no truck at all with the way in which Saddam Hussein has used civilians. I condemn that sort of action and the way in which Saddam Hussein has put missiles into Israel without any thought of attacking military installations. That is not on. But the fact that he does it does not mean we have to do it, nor does it mean we should contemplate doing it. By this sort of protocol, we should be showing the world community that we are intent on disciplining ourselves and we should be trying to insist that those with whom we are allies have the same sort of discipline when they approach war.

I want to point to a couple of things mentioned in the contribution of the honourable member for Menzies. He claimed that protocol I, article 52, the general protection of civilian objects, would prevent a military attack on anything other than a military objective. Clearly he has not read, or does not understand, the full context of this protocol. Of course it is the intention of the protocol to stop attacks on civilian locations such as churches and the like. In the case of real doubt, the protocol requires the military to hold back until the doubt is erased. But the honourable member for Menzies has failed to take note of article 51 and I ask him to read it.

Similarly, the honourable member for Menzies has raised the question of whether, under article 56, military forces will be unable to attack a dam even if the dam is acting as protection for a Scud launcher nearby. Again he ought to read the protocol carefully rather than mouthing that sort of rhetoric. I suggest that he read particularly 56(2) (a). This section continues on to address other concerns expressed by the honourable member for Menzies. Contrary to what the honourable member for Menzies says, the protocol does not limit the military's ability to wage war. He and his colleagues may want us to believe that, but it does not. It seeks, rather, to offer the maximum protection in the horrifying event that people are caught in a war.

The basic principles of the Geneva Convention have been expressed in the Australian on 1 February 1991 and can be summed up as follows: the human dignity of all individuals must be respected at all times and everything possible must be done, without any kind of discrimination, to reduce the suffering of those who take no direct part in the conflict or have been put out of action through sickness, wounds or captivity. What is fundamentally wrong with that objective? Why would people have a reservation about that objective and the protocol to endorse it?

I applaud the honourable member for Isaacs for the way in which he presented his argument, but he is wrong. I would ask him to study the history of the Geneva conventions. Why might people want to control the excesses of war? As we go into the twenty-first century, with all the artillery and technology which is now available for humankind to wage war, it is important, in my view, that we ought to have some controls, we ought to exercise those controls, and we ought to recognise that technology of itself may be harmful, that the fundamental principle of our jobs in this Parliament is the preservation of human life and that we should take every possible step to ensure that we do everything to preserve the lives not only of Australians but of other people in the world community. If that means providing some constraints on the way in which we operate in the military theatre, then so be it.

I accept the difficulties that may confront the soldier in the firing line. I understand that. But we are not talking about such aspects of the argument; we are talking about minutia such as the instructions people are given to wage war and how they understand the rules within which they will wage conflicts. If 88 other nations can come to an agreement and we endorse it, it would seem to me not inappropriate to expect other people to endorse it also. At the end of the day, as we well know, there is nothing to stop any nation which is a signatory to any of these conventions ignoring them completely. Saddam Hussein has done it and he is to be condemned for it.
