But I reject the argument that we should then turn around and say that, because he has been able to do it, we should be able to do it; that would be not only simplistic but naive.

It is worth recalling that the first Geneva Convention was drafted as early as 1864. In time the Geneva Convention has been built upon by additional conventions covering different aspects of protection and humanitarian assistance. The immense value of the work undertaken by the Red Cross and Red Crescent should not be underestimated or understated. Amidst the horrors of world wars, regional conflicts, civil wars and disasters, they have done the caring for the wounded and the imprisoned. They should be applauded for that work and they should be supported. It should come as no surprise that the Red Cross is one of the major sponsoring organisations for this convention, because in its work in the battlefield it sees the sorts of horrors perpetrated by war-not only on civilians, but on people who are charged with the responsibility of fighting these conflicts and who are in uniform, whether as combatants or as prisoners of war. We have an absurd proposition where this megalomaniac in Iraq has, it seems, used prisoners of war as targets. In other cases, he has provided civilian targets. Nothing can express the horror of that situation, but it does not mean that we should act likewise.
I also want to refer briefly to protocol II which we will also be endorsing, but which does not require an Act of this Parliament. The introduction to article 1 of this protocol states that it:

. . . shall apply to all armed conflicts which are not covered by Article 1 of the Protocol Additional to the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949, and relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts (Protocol I) and which take place in the territory of a High Contracting Party between its armed forces and dissident armed forces or other organised armed groups which, under responsible command, exercise such control over a part of its territory as to enable them to carry out sustained and concerted military operations and to implement this Protocol.
I think it is also important to read from article 4, subsection 2, which states:
2. Without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing, the following acts against the persons referred to in paragraph 1 are and shall remain prohibited at any time and in any place whatsoever:
(a) violence to the life, health and physical or mental well-being of persons, in particular murder as well as cruel treatment such as torture, mutilation or any form of corporal punishment;
(b) collective punishments;
(c) taking of hostages;
(d) acts of terrorism;
(e) outrages upon personal dignity, in particular humiliating and degrading treatment, rape, enforced prostitution and any form of indecent assault;
(f) slavery and the slave trade in all their forms;
(g) pillage;
(h) threats to commit any of the foregoing acts.

Of course, there is a particular section which deals exclusively with children. I bring those to your attention, Mr Deputy Speaker, because I think they are important. We have seen a number of insurgency movements operating in the world since 1945 where these rules have not applied. In the post-war period we have seen the putting down of what, in other circumstances, one might call insurgents-the revolutionary or popular movements and liberation movements in various nations around the world. In many of those instances we have seen the most horrific abuse of civilians-of the citizens of countries-who have been subjected to the worst excesses inflicted by military means. As an example, we need only look at the outrageous way in which this person, who promotes himself as the would-be spokesman for the Middle East, treated the Kurdish people. How can anyone contemplate such barbarity?

We do not have to go too far north of Australia to see where this has taken place in recent times. I know that we cannot do anything about these events of history. However, it is of grave concern to me, if one takes into account what this protocol is supposed to do, what it identifies and how it expresses concern about the way in which we should protect civilians and people in other nation states who might be involved in some conflict with their government, that there is nothing we can physically do about it or that we have chosen not to do anything about it. In the case of Iraq, there has been a clear transgression of international law and the occupation of another country. But what happened when the Kurds were being despoiled? Very little. What happened when 200,000 Timorese out of a population of some 700,000 were lost post-1975? What did we do? What action did we take to try to stop that excessive barbarity? It seems to me that we need to take account of where we are. Whilst I appreciate and understand the intent of honourable members, particularly the honourable member for Isaacs, I reject totally the propositions put forward by the Opposition and I implore the House to endorse these recommendations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bradford Mr J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with some interest to the remarks of the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon). He asked a very poignant question: `What sort of human beings are we?'. I guess that many speakers in this debate on the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990 and in the earlier debate on the Gulf war have tried to come to grips with that particular question. I say to the honourable member and to those people who are listening that I do not know what sort of human beings we are when today we find ourselves in a world where we are tearing ourselves apart. I wish I did know the answer to that question; I wish I did know what has brought us, as a human race, to this point again and again over the centuries. Yet here we are again. I suppose the question that has been posed really is the $64,000 one. I wish we could say in some way that come 1991 we are, as a human race, somewhat civilised but, sadly, clearly we are not.

SPEECH.PARA: I was disappointed to hear in the speech of the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) earlier this evening the assertion or belief which was repeated by the honourable member for the Northern Territory that the hierarchy of the Defence Force has agreed with the sentiments of this protocol. If in fact it has-and at this point I do not accept that it has-I believe that it is severely deluded in having done so. I can only assume-and I say this advisedly-that it is toeing the Government line in doing so and I am very disappointed.

We recently witnessed the rather unusual spectacle in this House of two days of debate-20 hours of debate with 113 members speaking-on the proposition that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) put to the House which effectively committed Australians to war. In that debate there was an unusual degree of bipartisan support for that proposition. It is interesting to see the contrast which has come out in this debate tonight and earlier this afternoon. On an issue which is of a similar vein in terms of subject matter, we find ourselves, once again, poles apart. Why is that? I believe we are simply divided on this issue on the point of whether we can effectively engage in war and comply with this protocol. I believe that we, on this side of the House, have conscientiously come to the point of view that without appropriate reservations the answer to that question is that we cannot commit Australians to war and be bound by this protocol for a number of reasons, which I will deal with in a moment.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory has the whole thing back to front when he makes the point that it is not a question of being able to do what Saddam Hussein has done. Rather, we ought to turn it around and say that we should recognise that regardless of what he has done we, unfortunately, will find ourselves in a position where people like him will do what they want to do regardless of what civilised or decent people determine to do at a time of war or in any other circumstance.

Tonight we are dealing with the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990. The protocol that we are dealing with supplements the Geneva Conventions of 12 August 1949 relating to the Protection of Victims of International Armed Conflicts. I point out that in many respects what I will say has already been said, but I want to say it as well. This protocol has failed to gain the support of the world's major military nations-many of which are our allies. Earlier this afternoon the Minister read out a list of those countries which had ratified, or had indicated their intention to ratify, the protocol. The list was lacking in terms of the support of the major members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO), for example. There are many good reasons for this which I will go into in a moment.

Let me say to the Government and to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney), who is at the table, that even if the protocol were free of the questionable legalities and ambiguities, which every speaker on our side has pointed to, in a philosophical sense the sad fact remains that nothing about war is really manageable at all.

Earlier this afternoon the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) quoted Dwight Eisenhower, a famous general and American President. Maybe I could add to that by reminding people that Dwight Eisenhower also said that nothing about war should amaze us-in other words, we should never be surprised by what happens in war.

What a pity it is that tonight we cannot discuss legislation to actually ban war. It seems to me supremely ironic that in law we accept the proposition that a nation can wage war but it can do so only in a certain way. The naivety of the Government on this particular issue really is astounding. Effectively, I believe that the Minister and the Government would be prepared to see Australians sent to war, in terms of this protocol, with one hand tied behind their back.

I say to the Minister and to the Government that if we are reaching a point in history where we are really civilised, perhaps they would support a convention that requires that only rubber bullets be fired in war. Perhaps that would be being really progressive. But what meaning would it have? Perhaps the left wing of the Australian Labor Party in particular-I see that one of its prominent members will speak after me and I shall listen with interest to what he has to say-would support such a proposition unilaterally.

Perhaps we could go back to the ancient history of Israel and find a solution there-that is, select one soldier from each side to fight the battle and determine the outcome accordingly. I am not suggesting in any way other than lightly that perhaps if we put President Bush and Saddam Hussein together and let them fight it out we could determine a result with much less loss of life. Of course, the Philistines thought they had a winner with Goliath. David turned out to be something of a surprise package. Sadly, that idea of lining the armies up and facing each other across the valley and sending forth one warrior to sort it all out from each side would not work today.

The concept of civilised war-and that is, to some extent, what we are talking about here-is appealing, although I am quite certain, like my colleague the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson), that it is rather idealistic. It assumes that people who wage war are civilised. Of course, that has never been the case. I suppose we might say that in a lot of wars one side was civilised and the other was uncivilised.

I believe that everything should be done that can be done to prevent war. That is notwithstanding human nature, the human nature that the honourable member for the Northern Territory talked about. It is staggering to think that so far this century 100 million people have been killed in wars. And we still have 10 years to go.

The aims of the Geneva conventions in protecting the victims of war, the sick, wounded or shipwrecked combatants, prisoners of war (POWs) and civilians are without doubt noble and worthy. But it is debatable exactly what effect the Geneva conventions have actually had to date. This particular matter has been raised time and again in this debate. Yet, here we are discussing an additional protocol when already the outlined principles of the 1949 conventions have only been selectively adhered to.

Decent civilised people in war should be able to distinguish between right and wrong. However, the lessons of the past have taught us that an unscrupulous enemy has no regard for the rules when it is waging war. In recent years we have heard graphic accounts of the Japanese mistreating and executing prisoners of war in World War II.

Many times during this debate we have alluded to the Gulf war in which we are now engaged as yet another frightening example of how the laws of international conflict can be entirely flaunted even by those who are parties to the Geneva conventions. For example, let me remind the House once again that Iraq, in its invasion of Kuwait, has shown no regard for the fourth Geneva convention which aims to provide protection for civilians, in particular those who are in a territory occupied by another country's armed forces. Rather, in contrast, instead of providing protection to the citizens of Kuwait, as we found in Amnesty International's December report, Iraqi forces have actually tortured, raped, injured and killed civilians in Kuwait since it invaded that country on 2 August.

Let me remind the House that delegates of the International Committee of the Red Cross have visited nine prisoners of war and 61 civilian internees held by the allied forces. However, attempts to visit POWs held by Iraqi armed forces have so far been unsuccessful. Saddam Hussein seems to think of himself as exempt from Geneva conventions, because it suits him to do so, and from international law. He has gone even further. He stooped to the depths of parading obviously beaten prisoners of war on television, which is clearly in breach of article 13 of the third convention which provides against acts of violence or intimidation and insults of public curiosity. Further, his threat to use prisoners of war as human shields is also in distinct breach of article 23, which provides that POWs cannot be detained in areas exposed to fighting or used to render certain points or areas immune from military operation.

Saddam Hussein goes even further in his threat to use chemical weapons again, as he has done in the past. It is interesting that one of the earlier speakers tonight told us in effect how well the conventions had worked. As I listened to him outlining some of the wars in which gas had not been used, it occurred to me that there were some notable exceptions. The use by Saddam Hussein of gas and his threat to do so again which would conflict with the Geneva gas protocol of 1925 was certainly one.

Clearly, the potential of our adversary in this war, or in any conflict, simply to pay lip service to the Geneva conventions and any additional protocols is enormous. Unfortunately, it is more than that. It is really a reality of war. Article 35 of the protocol that we have been discussing today and into this evening states:
It is prohibited to employ methods . . . of warfare which are intended, or may be expected, to cause widespread, long-term and severe damage to the natural environment.

Can anyone really stand in this House today and say that he honestly believes that had this protocol been effective in the Gulf war situation, that article would have prevented Saddam Hussein from creating the deliberate oil spill? Of course not. In discussing the additional protocol to the Geneva conventions, we are simply creating more rules that essentially are one-sided and unenforceable. They are-in a sense, I understand where the Government is coming from here-noble ideals, albeit expressed fairly vaguely. But they are on the surface superficially appealing. There are various implications of protocol I that are clearly impractical and, most importantly, from the point of view of members on this side, not in the best interests of our nation. Article 82 states:

. . . the Parties to the conflict . . . shall ensure that legal advisers are available . . . to advise military commanders at the appropriate level on the application of the Conventions and this Protocol and on the appropriate instruction to be given to the armed forces on this subject.

The honourable member for Isaacs has already alluded to the quite ridiculous implications of this for troops actually going into battle. It is really quite an absurd suggestion that lawyers, of all people, should be on hand at the front line to give advice to military commanders on how to conduct a war. Anyone who has even been remotely close to the action would realise the pressures that are on military commanders at that time. I would have thought that the last thing that they would want to do would be to seek legal advice. One can only imagine the cries of `Before we attack, I must consult my lawyer'. What article 82 does in essence is create more work for lawyers who have already managed to complicate life unnecessarily for most of us.

Incidentally the protocol, which was finalised 14 years ago, in 1977, is a lawyer's dream. I can almost picture a courtroom debate on article 35 on the prohibition of warfare of a nature to cause `superfluous injury or unnecessary suffering'. How can we possibly define those terms in any meaningful way? It reminds me of a story told in the last war of the deserter who, when charged, said that he was merely retreating while the others were advancing. What do words mean in this situation? Article 50, which defines how to determine who a civilian is, is totally inappropriate, as has been pointed out many times, in the case of guerilla warfare. It means, in effect, that enemy soldiers can quite feasibly be hidden by the civilian population or that they can seek sanctuary in a school, church or house and be virtually untouchable. Article 48 states:

Parties to the conflict shall at all times distinguish between civilian population and combatants and between civilian objects and military objectives and accordingly shall direct their operations only against military objectives.

I would have hoped that the Government would have recognised by now that all of these are clearly unworkable and would make life extremely difficult, if not impossible, for troops when it actually came to going into action.

The United States and other allied forces in the current action have attempted to minimise what they, I suppose rather euphemistically, call collateral damage. But I believe that great credit can be paid to them for the attempts that they have made and the great lengths that they have gone to to target only military and strategic installations. However, what respect for common decency has Saddam Hussein shown by indiscriminately launching Scud missiles at Israel when Israel at this stage is not even a party to the conflict? Even if Israel were, such action contravenes the fourth Geneva conventions which prohibits indiscriminate bombing and which states that one of the underlying principles of the laws of international conflict is that civilians should be spared. It is a sad fact however that in modern wars nine out of ten people killed are civilians.

The fact is that this protocol, while it may have created a warm inner glow for those involved in drafting it-and I assume that warm inner glow is shared by Government members who have supported it-it serves no real purpose and, more importantly, it creates great problems for us as a nation in the event of our going to war. One of my main concerns is that many of our partners in both the NATO and ANZUS-Australia, New Zealand and United States-alliances have expressed serious concerns about the protocol and have refused to ratify it. Most notably, the United States takes the view that it is `fundamentally and irreconcilably flawed', and that `a number of the provisions of the protocol are militarily unacceptable'.

I believe it should be considered that the United States, whilst not infallible in its judgment, is one of our closest military allies. That presents us with some very real difficulties. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) himself has conceded in a letter to President Reagan-I think this has already been referred to-that the protocol contains a number of ambiguities and operational complexities. However, the Government is going headlong into the ratification of this protocol.

Let us hear the Government members yet to speak in this debate talk about preventing war. By all means, let us do that. Let us not kid ourselves about war. Let us not pretend we can fight a war with one hand tied behind our backs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford), I thought that the debate we had in this chamber two weeks ago indicated that honourable members on all sides of the House would seek to avoid war and would do everything in their power to prevent war breaking out. I am pleased that the Government has brought on for debate the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill. I am somewhat surprised that the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) in his contribution should have expressed surprise at the debate taking place. I would have thought it was pretty obvious why the debate should take place at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: I am particularly pleased, being neither a lawyer nor someone who has served in the military forces, except for the national service I did many years ago, to have the opportunity to make a small contribution to the debate. As honourable members who read the Notice Paper would be aware, for some time I have had on notice a series of questions on the Geneva conventions. Indeed, the latest question, dealing with the ratification of this protocol, was raised during the special sitting of the House on 21 January 1991. I did that because I felt at the time it was imperative that Australia ratify the protocol.

I have listened to the arguments of the last couple of speakers for the Opposition as to why Australia should not ratify and, interestingly, their arguments as to why Australia should not ratify are precisely the arguments used by me and other members on this side as to why Australia should. Really, I do not think there is a lot of dispute between both sides. It is unfortunate that the Opposition cannot support the Government on this measure.

Of course, recent events in the Gulf make Australia's ratification even more important. As has been pointed out, protocol I is concerned with the protection of victims of international armed conflict. It is also most appropriate for Australia to ratify protocol I because from 1 January 1991 Australia has commenced a three-year term as a member of the United Nations Commission on Human Rights. If Australia is to be fully effective and credible as a member of the Commission the Government must take the remaining steps available to it under the 1966 International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, the fundamental international instrument on human rights. If Australia expects to be allowed to scrutinise human rights in other countries it must conclude the ratifications and declarations which will allow other countries to scrutinise human rights in Australia.

Under the Geneva Conventions the protocols needed ratification by 20 international governments before a fact-finding commission could be appointed under article 90. This commission is intended to investigate various breaches. Twenty governments have now ratified the protocols, the latest being Canada in November 1990. To date, New Zealand is the only government in the Asia-Pacific region to do so. I believe that nothing is more important than having the two Houses of this Parliament give this matter speedy passage.

Ratifying protocol I could enable the Government to make a declaration of protection of victims of war and nominate a representative for the fact-finding commission. But, as I understand it, the Government at this stage will not be making a declaration under article 90. This declaration by Australia will not only establish the commission but also will give it the basis for an equitable representation of geographical areas sought under paragraph III.

I am concerned that the Opposition, which has supported the Government's motion in regard to the Gulf conflict, should now oppose this Bill. It is unfortunate that this could not go through with bipartisan support. I accept that the Opposition has said that it would accept the protocols if Australia stated reservations. I think it was either the Minister then at the table or another Government speaker who said that we either have a Bill or we do not; if we start stating reservations, there will be more reservations than there are clauses to the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—That may be your view.
—I happened to put the Opposition view, you fool.
—I listened to the honourable member for Kooyong during his contribution, and he did say that the protocol had laudable aims.
—That is right.
—I do not think there would be any disagreement with that. He then went on to say that there were too many impediments to our armed forces.
—This is right.

—This is simply not true. I put this to the honourable member for Kooyong: it would seem to me to be logical that at the very time when a country has people in the field, guidelines not only for our armed forces but for the civilians involved should be most clearly outlined.
—They already are. This is not the only convention, you know.

—Not only for the protection of the civilians, but also for personnel. As the Minister for Defence, Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) remarked in his speech, our national interest is best served by ratifying this protocol.
—Those are CDF's words.

—I was actually giving the Minister credit; but I know that he was quoting the Chief of the General Staff in saying that. I put it to Opposition members that if Canada can ratify, why should this be such a problem for Australia?
—What about the Americans, the British and the French?

—I am coming to the Americans. We keep saying that we are moving into an era of the new world order, in which it is claimed the United Nations will play a much more significant role than it has in the past. It therefore seems to me essential that all nations, however powerful, abide by a set of international standards, and if need be these standards should be monitored.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Kooyong asked me about the Americans, and a lot of Opposition speakers have listed the countries which have not ratified it. It is no surprise that some of the largest military powers, with the exception of China, have not: they are the people I feel who are most likely to be involved. I think all would agree that it is unfortunate that the US has reservations about the protocol. As late as March 1989, I think it was, in the Sydney Morning Herald, the Opposition point of view was quoted:
The Opposition believes that the effect of the treaty would be to unacceptably hamstring the co-operation of Australia and US troops while Washington remains opposed to the protocol.
That was said at a time when we were not involved in armed conflict.

I put the question again. Canada has a much more significant number of troops in the Gulf than Australia. If the US can work with Canada-and Canada not only ratified it but made the declaration under article 90-if Canada can do that and the US has no problem with that, then if Australia did it, why should this prove to be a problem to the United States?

TALK.START.PARA: —Why indeed?

—I do not think it would prove a problem for the United States at all. I must say to the Minister at the table, though, that I am very concerned at the projected delay on the declaration. One cannot see why the individual States of Australia have to be consulted on the laws of war at all, or, if it was felt that they had to be consulted, why they have not already been exhaustively consulted. If, for example, the various States were to provide holding areas for prisoners of war, I could well understand the need then for consultation, but it is most unlikely that this will happen. It would be deplorable if our obsession with consulting the States on external affairs leads to Australia missing out on election to the Commission under article 90, and I would ask the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel to urge the Attorney-General-indeed, I would urge the Attorney-General myself-to make the declaration under article 90 as soon as possible.

SPEECH.PARA: I am pleased that the Australian Red Cross has been extensively consulted in the lead up to this. The treatment of prisoners of war has attracted enormous public interest. The third Geneva convention covers the treatment of prisoners of war: a combatant who surrenders or is captured must not be killed or injured and must be treated humanely and with respect for their person and honour. Parading prisoners of war on television and threatening to place them at strategic installations is clearly in breach of article 13 of the third convention, which provides protection for prisoners of war against acts of violence or intimidation and against insults and public curiosity. Many people in Australia have been rightly horrified at the so-called confessions made on television of allied prisoners of war, and the reported threats to detain them at strategic targets.

Article 17 adds that prisoners of war must not be subjected to physical or mental torture, nor any other form of coercion. Nor can they be detained in areas exposed to the fighting, or used to render certain points or areas immune from military operation, according to article 23.

Under the convention delegates of the International Committee of the Red Cross must be allowed to visit the prisoners of war to check on conditions, to register them, and to facilitate the transmission of personal messages to their families. So far the International Committee of the Red Cross has visited seven Iraqi prisoners of war held by US armed forces, and two prisoners of war and 61 civilian internees held by the British armed forces in the United Kingdom. These were the figures as at last week; the committee may have visited some more since then. Attempts to visit prisoners of war held by the Iraqi armed forces have so far been unsuccessful.

The treatment of Kuwaiti citizens under the Iraqi armed forces has been widely publicised, including a report by Amnesty International detailing atrocities. It is reported that Kuwaiti citizens have been tortured, raped, injured and killed. The aim of the fourth Geneva convention is to provide protection of civilians, in particular those civilians who are in a territory occupied by another country's armed forces. Under article 27 those protected persons are entitled to respect for their person and honour, they must be treated humanely, and they must be protected against acts of violence.

The indiscriminate bombing of any nation is clearly in breach of the fourth Geneva convention. One of the underlying principles of the laws of armed conflict is that civilians should be spared. We have witnessed claims and counter claims regarding the specificity of targets in terms of military objectives in the current conflict. Regardless, civilians should be spared, and any deliberate attack against them is clearly illegal. One honourable member opposite made the point-and I would agree with it, although we may reach a different conclusion about it-that it is a sad fact that in modern wars nine out of 10 people killed are civilians. People say, `Why do we need this to protect civilians?', but they should bear in mind that in modern conflicts nine out of 10 people killed are civilians.

In addition, the use of poisonous gases in the current conflict has been threatened. The use of chemical weapons and poisonous gases, or bacteriological warfare, is forbidden by the Geneva gas protocol of 1925. This protocol has been ratified by all countries involved in the Gulf war, and is therefore binding. The laws of armed conflict that should apply to the Gulf war are clearly being breached, and the International Red Cross has regularly reminded all sides of their obligations.

As in other areas of international law, the enforcement of international treaties can prove difficult. There is no provision under the Geneva conventions for an international police force or justice system to enforce the laws. Of course, it is always one of the weaknesses of international law that there is no enforcing body or agency. The responsibility for enforcing them falls on the nations which are party to the Geneva conventions, which provide that people who commit grave breaches must be brought to trial for their offences. The difficulty in bringing members of the armed forces or citizens to trial is that it may be hard to prove the identity of those responsible for the offences, and it may be difficult to bring them to trial in the jurisdiction of their own domestic court system.

The immense damage to the environment caused by warfare has caused great concern not only in Australia but also internationally. The 1977 additional protocols to the Geneva conventions, created to update the Geneva conventions, provide for the protection of the environment. Article 35 prohibits the use of methods or means of warfare which can cause long term or severe damage to the environment. The deliberate creation of an oil spill is obviously a breach of this article. It is unfortunate that most of the countries involved in the Gulf war have not ratified the additional protocols, because they are therefore not binding.

All thinking people detest war, and of course when armed conflict breaks out it is a failure-a failure of diplomacy, a failure of reason, sometimes a failure of the will to prevent it. To some there is a contradiction in having laws of war, but even in war there must be an accepted behaviour, and a method to monitor that behaviour. By ratification of protocol I, Australia is demonstrating that we will abide by these humanitarian principles.

This Labor Government will continue to work tirelessly to achieve world peace. We must, unfortunately, accept that limited wars are likely to continue and take appropriate action, such as is involved in the ratification of the protocols, to promote international adherence to the humanitarian principles embodied in the Geneva conventions and in these protocols.

As has been stated, one of the arguments in favour of protocol I is the need to provide additional protection for the victims of armed conflict, especially the civilian population of states involved in the conflict. It is also worth making the point that non-ratification of protocol I by Australia would not necessarily remove the uncertainties that some Opposition members have mentioned.

I also make the point that it is possible and even, I would suggest, likely that parts of protocol I at least will come to be regarded by states, particularly those which are parties to it but also by the International Committee of the Red Cross, as representing customary international law, and therefore will be binding upon non-parties as well.
While respecting the arguments put by the Opposition speakers, I am disappointed that they will oppose the legislation. I for my part commend it to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time that Australia ratified the 1977 protocols. It is a disgrace that the additional protocols are now more than 13 years old and have not been ratified by Australia. It was a disgrace that the Menzies Government ratified the Geneva conventions nine years after they were adopted. Why the delay?

SPEECH.PARA: It would seem to most of us, on a reading of the protocols, that they really are motherhood provisions to civilised countries, and yet there is opposition-opposition in Australia that was not forthcoming in 1978 when the protocols were actually signed. Who was Minister for Foreign Affairs in 1978?

History has been somewhat distorted, and therefore the background of these proposals needs to be reviewed. The need for the protocols became obvious following the devastation in the Second World War. The protocols were developed by the International Committee of the Red Cross during the 1950s. The Swiss federal council convened a diplomatic conference that held four sessions in Geneva from 1974 to 1977 to negotiate the text to these protocols. More than 100 governments sent legal, defence and diplomatic experts to these conferences and several liberation movements were given observer status at them.

Australia attended all four sessions and played a vital role in the difficult negotiations. Australia was represented by the departments of Attorney-General, Foreign Affairs and Defence and the Australian Red Cross Society. The protocols were adopted by consensus. Australia signed the protocols on 7 December 1978, when the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) was Minister for Foreign Affairs. Australian delegations under both the Whitlam and Fraser Governments took an active part in the drafting and adoption of the protocols. It is an appropriate time now for Australia to ratify the proposals. Why? The first reason-it is pretty obvious-is that the Gulf war makes it imperative. It makes it imperative for Australia to pass the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990 permitting us to ratify protocol I and to make the declaration under article 90.

There is to be an international fact finding commission which will be established when no fewer than 20 states have accepted the competence of the commission pursuant to article 90(2) of protocol I, and in an answer recently in the Parliament it was disclosed that the Swiss department of foreign affairs has advised that Switzerland will convene a conference in June 1991 to constitute the commission. A prompt declaration by Australia will not only help to establish the commission but also give equitable representation on a geographical basis, which is required.

The Opposition seems incapable of taking an independent policy stance on any important issue. It appears that the basis of its objection is that the United States of America objects. The statements by the honourable member for Kooyong either represent the greatest conversion since Saul on the road to Damascus or perhaps are explained by the fact that he may have been rolled in the party room. The latter explanation is probably the kindest, because he has not been consistent in this regard.

Protocol I makes significant progress in the protection of a civilian population against the effect of hostilities. Article 48 of protocol I codifies, for the first time, the fundamental principle of humanitarian law-that the parties to a conflict shall always distinguish between the civilian population and combatants. It is worth while reading the basic rule of article 48 onto the parliamentary record. It states:

In order to ensure respect for and protection of the civilian population and civilian objects, the Parties to the conflict shall at all times distinguish between the civilian population and combatants and between civilian objects and military objectives and accordingly shall direct their operations only against military objectives.

What is wrong with that? Is that not what we are being told is happening in the Gulf at the moment, day after day, night after night on Cable Network News (CNN) and other television networks? We are told about the precision bombing that is taking place and how every effort is being made to avoid civilian casualties. That is what these protocols are all about-that is the basic theme that runs through them.

Protocol I is concerned with the protection of victims of intentional armed conflicts. Protocol II applies to situations of non-international armed conflicts between the armed forces of a party and organised armed groups exercising some territorial control over territory of that party. To treat the rules of humanitarian law separately from the rules as to the means and methods of armed conflict is unrealistic, given the conduct of modern warfare which involves the civilian population to an unprecedented extent.

This debate shows the hypocrisy of the Opposition and the Rambo-type attitude that pervades the Opposition arguments that have been put forward in this chamber today. Opposition members are not interested in precision bombing. Misquotes have taken place in relation to the Bill before the House. The honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown) selectively quoted sections of the Bill. Article 52, which embodies the protocols, says:
Civilian objects shall not be the object of attack or of reprisals. Civilian objects are all objects which are not military objectives as defined in paragraph 2.
I want to go back and quote in full article 56 which the honourable member for Menzies quoted because basically the theme running through that article is as follows:

Works or installations containing dangerous forces, namely dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations, shall not be made the object of attack, even where these objects are military objectives-
and here is the qualification, a humanitarian qualification-

if such attack may cause the release of dangerous forces and consequent severe losses among the civilian population. Other military objectives located at or in the vicinity of these works or installations shall not be made the object of attack if such attack may cause the release of dangerous forces from the works or installations and consequent severe losses among the civilian population.

In other words, what is being said is, one would have thought, commonsense. One does not use a sledge-hammer to crack a walnut in times of war. Article 56 states that it is unacceptable for excessive civilian losses to be generated as a result of some strikes and I would have thought that that was commonsense.

Are we alone in our ratification of these protocols? Let us put the record straight. Some 164 states around the world, including Australia, are party to the four Geneva conventions of 1949. In relation to the number of states that have ratified or acceded to the protocols additional to the Geneva conventions of 1949, the figures as of 30 November 1990 are 99 in relation to protocol I and 89 in relation to protocol II.
One might be surprised to find that amongst the countries that have ratified or have acceded to the protocols are Canada, New Zealand, Sweden, Finland, Norway, Switzerland, Denmark, Austria--

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is England, France or the US?

—The whole point is that we do not have to dance to the tune of England, France and America because it is obvious that those powers wish to reserve the right to use nuclear weapons, the most horrific of all weapons. Let us get fair dinkum, because the United States did sign the protocols way back then; they were signatories to the protocols. So let us not confuse or misquote history in that regard.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the multinational forces engaged in the Gulf, Argentina, Bangladesh, Bahrain, Belgium, Canada, Czechoslovakia, Denmark, Netherlands, New Zealand and many others have ratified both protocols. It is hypocritical of the Opposition to now come in to this Parliament and oppose these protocols.

What does the Red Cross urge? The International Committee of the Red Cross and the Australian Red Cross Society are urging this Parliament to support the adoption of the protocols before us. I quote from a document prepared by Dr Hans-Peter Gasser, the legal adviser to the Directorate of the International Committee of the Red Cross and Mr Alan McLean, Secretary General of the Australian Red Cross Society. It says:

Australia has shown its concern for the fate of the civilian population in times of war. Australia should now ratify both Protocols and thereby show to its own people, to its neighbours and to the world at large that this country is willing to accept binding obligations of a strictly humanitarian character . . . Rejection of the Protocols by Australia would not be an encouragement to other States of the region, or to potential enemies anywhere, to ratify the Protocols. All governments take into account the attitude of other countries when deciding on ratification of treaties affecting national defence. Furthermore, a treaty will only be accepted by a growing number of States if there is a certain momentum. Nonratification of the Protocols by Australia would certainly reduce that momentum . . . ``Such inaction would encourage States (who may particularly need humanitarian rules) not to ratify the Protocols. Australia's record in world affairs would be needlessly tarnished . . . The Government has introduced the Bill into Parliament. It has thereby expressed its will and determination to ratify both Protocols. If Parliament fails to approve the Bill, Australia would set a deplorable precedent: it would be the first time in history that a Red Cross humanitarian treaty was rejected by Parliament, i.e., a popularly elected body. To enter the Parliament and then to lapse would be an equally shameful world-first.

Those are not my words; those are the words of the Red Cross. That is its view of the matter. I notice that the honourable member for Kooyong has re-entered the chamber. The point needs to be made again that when the protocol was signed by Australia back in 1978, he was the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The negotiations that took place spanned the period of the Whitlam and Fraser Governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mustn't have been paying attention. I drew attention to this earlier, you fool.

—It is probably not the first and last time the honourable member for Kooyong has been rolled in the party room, so I am happy to accept that interjection from him. I can appreciate he may well be objecting under sufferance, given his history in the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Really, the Opposition is taking a Rambo-like approach in its opposition to this Bill. I think what it signifies is that there is a gulf between the Government and the Opposition. It also signifies to the peace movement in Australia and around the world and to the general population that, when it comes to running this country and adopting matters of principle, there is a vast difference between the way the Australian Labor Party handles matters and the way the conservative forces handle matters in this country.

It is a matter of record that the hypocrisy that is being shown by the conservatives in Parliament here today is in stark contrast to what they exhibited some years ago. I repeat: Australia has been an integral part of negotiations on the protocols. It is obscene that it has taken us 13 years to reach this stage. Has Canada, having ratified these proposals, been isolated by the United States? No. Are we to be the lackeys of the United States in this regard? I would submit that we should not be.

The late Peter Hastings, in an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday, 20 March 1989, recommended ratification of the protocols. Indeed, it was he who confirmed that the Chief of the Defence Force, General Peter Gration, a professional soldier of high repute and the Government's senior military adviser, was advising that the Government should sign the protocol.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I think all members of the House are well aware that this matter has been around for some time. In fact, it was in the Parliament during our previous term of office. I think it is worth reminding those who have taken part in the debate and have displayed an interest in the matter again that the purpose of the Geneva Conventions Amendment Bill 1990 is to amend the Geneva Conventions Act 1957 so as to enable Australia to ratify protocol I additional to the Geneva Conventions. As everyone has discussed tonight, protocol I is concerned with the protection of victims of international armed conflicts. When Australia ratifies protocol I, it will at the same time ratify protocol II which is concerned with the protection of victims of non-international armed conflicts. However, protocol II does not require legislative action to enable its ratification.

SPEECH.PARA: I have heard and seen most of this evening's debate in the chamber or on the television--

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it like on the television?

—I think probably that interjection should not be responded to. Today at Question Time I saw people in shirts which looked a lot better than the ones they normally wear. They actually had ties done right up to their collars. Some aspects of this must be extremely disappointing. I know that there was some criticism of the fact that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC) is not televising Question Time until five to 12 tonight. I must say, as an old supporter of the ABC, that I think it shows a lot of good judgment. But that is not the view of the Speaker, nor can I express a Government view on that matter, may I say.

SPEECH.PARA: Quite a few honourable members raised one matter this evening-I heard the honourable member for Isaacs (Mr Atkinson) and I think the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) before him put the point. No-one is questioning the goodwill of the view they have expressed, but I just think they were wrong when they said that the academics and lawyers involved in this exercise do not understand `what is going on on the ground'-I think was how the honourable member for Isaacs termed it.

I think it is worth just coming back to the role that the Australian defence forces played in relation to the decision to ratify. The Australian defence forces have been actively involved in the whole process leading to the Australian Government's decision to ratify the protocols. I think the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), as Minister for Foreign Affairs, would be aware that that had been the case when the first conferences were held on this matter. Surely no government would proceed down this track without knowing what its defence force people thought about it.

The Australian defence forces were involved in an exhaustive study of protocol I which was undertaken after the signing of the protocols back on 7 December 1978-a long while ago. There was a lot of thought given to the matter by, no doubt, the Fraser Government during that period and certainly by this Government. The Australian defence forces were also involved in the review of the operational implications-the matter which I think is causing some concern to honourable members opposite-of ratification undertaken since the announcement of the Government's decision to ratify back in 1986. Both studies have revealed no military or operational bar to the Government proceeding to ratify the protocol.

This matter was dealt with in more detail earlier today by my colleague the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney) and, therefore, I do not propose to spend any more time on it. However, it was a good starting point to indicate that, when one goes back to the studies that were undertaken in December 1978 and, again, the decision that the Government ratified in 1986, there was a very close involvement of the Australian defence forces which have been, as I said, actively involved throughout the whole process.

Secondly, there is the question of inter-operability which appears, listening to the debate this evening, to be one of the main reasons for the coalition's stance. That seems to be a matter which has caused it a certain amount of difficulty. These difficulties, I think, are caused primarily by the protocol's emphasis on the protection of civilians and civilian objects. However, it must always be borne in mind for those who have those concerns that this emphasis is not at the expense of achieving proper military objectives; there is no intention of that at all. In short, what the protocols require is that there should be no targeting of purely civilian objectives-that is, for example, no carpet bombing of cities. However, civilian targets are not always out of bounds. It is not said anywhere in the protocols that that is the case. If a civilian object is also being used for military objectives, it can be targeted.

Article 52, which was discussed at various times during the debate, defines civilian objects by reference to military objectives and military objectives, in so far as civilian objectives are concerned, are limited to those which by their nature, location, purpose or use make an effective contribution to military action and whose total or partial destruction, capture or neutralisation in the circumstances applying at the particular point in time offer a definite military advantage. Examples of that would be: should a house, normally a civilian dwelling, be destroyed simply because it is there? It may provide shelter if it is captured. If it is being used to make an effective contribution to military action, such as being used as a command post or a bunker, a tank hide or even as an observation post, then, of course, it may become a military object in those circumstances.

An assessment must also be made of the incidental loss of civilian life and of damages to civilian objects other than military objects. That always has to be weighed up against the concrete and direct military advantage anticipated. That is referred to quite clearly in article 51.

Additionally, the protocols do not require no civilian casualties. That is not in the game at all. The protocols do not say that in any clause. The protocols require the military leadership to assess whether or not civilian losses would be in proportion to the military objectives to be achieved by the attack in question. We all know that it is not always easy to get the right balance in these areas-that is accepted-but I think that it is just about being obtained here. It is certainly being done as well as it can be.

The honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) dealt in some detail with the next matter I wish to raise, but it has not been raised so much by the Opposition. It certainly was raised when this topic came before the House back in the period of the Third Hawke Government. I refer to the matter raised I think by the honourable member for Menzies (Mr N.A. Brown). I will deal more specifically later with the other matters raised by the shadow Attorney-General and honourable member for Kooyong, and the honourable member for Menzies.

One matter which concerned the honourable member for Menzies then was, as he said, that no country that had ratified this protocol was instantly identified as being our immediate ally or as being from our region. The honourable member for Banks dealt with that, but I think it is worth reiterating that of the countries that are party to the protocols a number of key Western and North Atlantic Treaty Organisation allies are party to them, including Sweden, Finland, Norway, Denmark, Austria, Italy, Belgium, Iceland, the Netherlands, Greece, Malta, Spain and Luxembourg. Whilst the Holy See is unlikely to be a military ally, it is interesting that it has also ratified the protocol. The point made by the honourable member for Banks is that, in addition to those sorts of countries, Canada and New Zealand are parties. In eastern Europe, Yugoslavia, Hungary, Bulgaria and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics are examples. China is also a party.

In relation to the current conflict in the Gulf, it is worth bringing to the attention of all honourable members that of the 29 members of the multinational task force involved, 19 are parties to protocol I and seven have signed both protocols. In the South Pacific and the South East Asian region, Samoa, Vanuatu, New Zealand, Korea, the Solomon Islands, Bangladesh, Laos, Vietnam, the Republic of Korea and the Philippines are other examples of parties to the protocol. So though it may well have been the case at some stage that what the honourable member for Menzies said was true, I think it should be made pretty clear now that it is not the case now.

One other matter which was been raised and which I would like to touch on briefly is the claim that problems would be created by military commanders having to have lawyers with them at all times. In the minds of many people, and probably justifiably in some cases, that would create a problem for anyone placed in that position. But that is not the case because the Australian Defence Force's approach to this is that it would have lawyers involved in the planning and preparation of operational materiel and that it would have them available to commanders at strategic levels. In relation to the legal matters involved, that is where they would get their advice.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have got to be joking.

—Despite the fact that those opposite make these allegations, when I answer them they think it is amusing. I think it is worthwhile for them to understand that that requirement of the protocol does not represent any difficulty for the Australian defence forces. If it does not represent any difficulty for them, I think Opposition members ought to sleep fairly well tonight and not let it worry them too much because the defence forces are the ones which have to look after the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow Attorney-General raised various matters this evening. I must say that I always listen very carefully to what he says. I can pay him the compliment of saying that what he says is always carefully thought out. No doubt he does not come in here and put stupid propositions forward. However, I must say that his speech tonight was one of his less convincing performances-and that is over a period of 10 years. He called for reservations on a number of key articles to the protocol. That was, I think, the main point he made. The Government is not making reservations, as he correctly said, but we may lodge certain declarations of understanding. We are doing this simply because what needs explanation is the meaning of certain provisions, but what we do not want is to resile from the basic principles of the protocol, which would occur if we lodged reservations to all of the articles mentioned by the honourable member for Kooyong, particularly in view of their number and scope. They are very wide ranging.

It is an essential principle of treaty interpretation under the Vienna Convention on the Law of Treaties between States and International Organisations that reservations be compatible with the objects and purpose of the treaty. This principle stands whether or not other treaty parties express their disapproval. The number and scope of reservations foreshadowed by the honourable member would in our opinion lead to an emasculation of the protocol. There were just too many proposals put forward in respect of reservations for them to be acceptable.

He called in particular for a reservation on the prohibition on reprisals contained in the protocol. A reservation on reprisals would not be accepted by some countries. A reservation would operate reciprocally between Australia and a future enemy also party to the protocol. If we did that, it would reduce the level of protection afforded by the protocol to Australian civilians and civilian objects.

None of the 99 countries which have become party to the protocol have seen the need to make such a reservation-not one of them. The prohibition on reprisals in the protocol is not a total prohibition. Reprisals are prohibited against civilians, cultural objects and places of worship, objects indispensable to the survival of the civilian population, the environment, dams, dykes and nuclear electrical generating stations containing dangerous forces. The prohibition on reprisals represents an important development in protection of civilians against the horrors of modern warfare.

The honourable member for Menzies has long had an interest in this matter. He was engaged in the debate and would have been shadow Attorney-General when the matter previously came before the House. One of the questions that he raised was how the ambiguities and operational complexities referred to in the letter from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to President Reagan had been overcome. That can be answered. There are certain ambiguities in the provisions, and this is why the Government intends to lodge declarations at the time of ratification to clarify our understanding of the provisions.

The operational complexities in combined operations which the honourable member for Menzies referred to always exist and do not merely arise by becoming a party to the protocol. They are there anyway. They are constantly addressed by liaison, training, joint exercises and manuals. This will continue.

He then raised another issue, as to how articles 52.2 and 52.3 could be interpreted so as not to put our forces at risk. The simple answer to that is that the protection of civilians and civilian objects in the protocol is not at the expense of achieving legitimate military objectives. I dealt with that in some detail earlier. Such protection is not new. It is fundamental to humanitarian law.

In short, the protocol requires that there should be no targeting of purely civilian objects. As I mentioned earlier, an example of that is carpet bombing. However, as I said, civilian targets are not always out of bounds from attack, as I discussed a little earlier this evening.

Another matter about which the honourable member for Menzies expressed some concern was whether the language in article 56.1 was not in excess of an unnecessary restriction on our military-a matter which seems to concern many members opposite and, therefore, should be answered. I come back to the point that the protection against the attack on dams, dykes and things like that is not absolute.

The honourable member for Menzies omitted to mention-and the honourable member for Banks dealt with this-article 56.2 which provides for situations where the protection ceases. An example of that is that if a dam is used for other than its normal function and in regular, significant and direct support of military operations and if an attack is the only feasible way to terminate such support, it may be attacked. That is quite clear if one looks at article 56.2 and not just at article 56.1. The decision to attack clearly involves intelligence, weapons, capability and military assessments being drawn together in much the same way as they have been for centuries.

This situation arose in Operation Rolling Thunder conducted by the US forces in Vietnam. Apparently, anti-aircraft weapons were deployed on dyke walls and, if the walls had been breached, severe loss of civilian life would have followed. At the same time, the weapons posed a severe risk to US aircraft attacking their military targets. The decision was then taken to employ a weapons system which destroyed the anti-aircraft guns in placements while leaving the dyke walls intact. That is what happened in a classic case on the ground where this sort of issue had to be faced up to in the tragic war in Vietnam in Operation Rolling Thunder.

It is disappointing that we did not get bipartisan support on this matter. I understand that there are concerns opposite, but I hoped that we would have had bipartisan support. But this matter, in my view, has been around for far too long and we had, therefore, to bring the matter forward this evening.
