INTERJECT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Duffy) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 19 September 1990, on motion by Mr Duffy:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Peacock The Hon A.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before the House now the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill 1990, which is an omnibus Bill making amendments to various Acts that relate to crime and the administration of the criminal justice system. The Bill contains amendments to a number of Acts, including the Australian Federal Police Act 1979, the Cash Transaction Reports Act 1988, the Crimes Act 1914, the Crimes (Protection of Aircraft) Act 1973, the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983, the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987 and the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition to those amendments, part 9 and schedule 2 of the Crimes Legislation Amendment Bill make amendments to some 18 pieces of Commonwealth legislation. It is fairly late and I will make most of my remarks tomorrow; I simply say by way of introduction that when this piece of legislation comes on for debate at a later day I will be confining my comments to some of the concerns that we have with only two pieces of legislation that are covered by this Bill-namely, the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Cash Transaction Reports Act.

I should say at this juncture that we will be supporting the Bill, but we will move amendments to part 3 of the Bill, dealing with the Cash Transaction Reports Act. In these few preliminary remarks before we debate the motion for the adjournment, I want to make it clear that we fully support the objectives of both of these pieces of legislation-namely, the pursuit of the money trail, which the former royal commissioner Frank Costigan, QC, described as the jugular of organised crime. The aims are, firstly, to trace the proceeds of crime and, secondly, to remove the incentive for crime by confiscating the ill-gotten gains of illegal activity.

In recent times we have seen a renewed emphasis on the need to pursue the money trail. The Chairman of the National Crime Authority, Mr Justice Phillips, has indicated that the Authority will collect, analyse and disseminate intelligence material relating to the money trail. In doing this, the Authority will liaise with various law enforcement bodies, including State police forces, the Australian Taxation Office, the Australian Customs Service, the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, the Australian Securities Commission and the Cash Transaction Reports Agency. This is a change of direction for the Authority that is most welcome from our point of view and it follows other initiatives that the new Chairman, Mr Justice Phillips, is taking in turning the Authority around. One of the primary objectives in establishing the National Crime Authority was to set up a national body that could act as a clearing house for criminal intelligence.

I fully acknowledge that both the Proceeds of Crime Act and the Cash Transaction Reports Act, as invaluable weapons in the fight against organised crime and in the work of Australia as a member of the international financial action task force on money laundering, are to be supported and encouraged. If recent press reports are anything to go by, it would seem that the strategy of pursuing the money trail is having some success in the area of tax evasion and money laundering.

However, we have real concerns as to whether both these pieces of legislation properly balance the interests of individual liberty against the interests of society as a whole. Those concerns can perhaps best be summed up when one acknowledges that the titles of these two pieces of legislation are in effect misnomers. The operation of the Proceeds of Crime Act is not limited to the proceeds or profits of crime and, by the same token, the ambit of the Cash Transaction Reports Act is not confined to the reporting of cash transactions.

I turn now to consider the Proceeds of Crime Act. The proposed amendments under part 7 of the Bill will exclude the operation of the Commonwealth Proceeds of Crime Act in relation to Australian Capital Territory (ACT) offences. They also contain a number of transitional provisions to cover situations where proceedings under the Act may have been commenced prior to the enactment of the relevant ACT legislation.

The Proceeds of Crime Act has been subject to some criticism by the judiciary and the profession. In the relatively short space of time during which the Act has been operative, the courts have had to deal with a large number of disputes relating to its application. When we resume on this matter on another day, I will cite a few of those cases. They will include Saffron v. The Director of Public Prosecutions, Brauer v. The Director of Public Prosecutions and, more recently, The Deputy Commissioner of Taxation and The Director of Public Prosecutions v. Kunz.
Mr Acting Speaker, I know you cannot propose the adjournment until 10.30 p.m. I am trying to be helpful and not go into the detail of my argument before then.

TALK.START.PARA: —We need to go on for another minute.

—If the Leader of the House wants me to go for ever and a day, I will. It would be easy talking to his side. I suppose I could play around with the Cash Transaction Reports Act, bearing in mind how some of the officials in the Australian Labor Party have played around with money in sugarbags in the past, but I will abstain from that now and do that on another day.
—You're going to do a bit of confessing, are you?

—I am talking about the party of the Leader of the House. He will remember that a very prominent member of this place who was elected by his party to a prominent position in the chamber received some money in a sugarbag, and when he passed it on there was a bit missing. Of course, as I cannot defame anybody or be against the standing orders by just generalising, I am entitled to say that and not name him. Now I think I have filled in enough time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: — Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the house do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Taylor Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —For most Australians last Sunday was just another Sunday in February. However, for others who gathered at Huskisson on the New South Wales south coast it was a very special, albeit sombre, day. February 10, 1964 saw one of the worst disasters in the peacetime history of the Royal Australian Navy. I speak of the collision between the destroyer HMAS Voyager and the aircraft carrier and flagship HMAS Melbourne off Jervis Bay, claiming 82 lives. On that fateful night it is now clear that for those involved there was a mixture of understandable fear, of disregard for personal safety, of mutual trust of shipmates, of bravery and, regrettably, of personal sacrifice and death-characteristics we have come to respect and honour in the great and proud traditions of the thousands of men and women who have served in the Australian Naval Service in peace and war, most recently exemplified in the Gulf crisis. Once again I take the opportunity to pay tribute to those who lost their lives in the service of their country that evening, to those who survived and continue about their every day lives and, very specially, to their families.

SPEECH.PARA: Regrettably, many of those survivors and their families still bear the scars of the tragedy-scars of psychological trauma; of persistent nervous shock; of domestic instability; of financial strain and, importantly in this parliamentary setting, of misplaced confidence in, and neglect by, a Government which espouses social justice but which demonstrably failed in this instance. To demonstrate this failure I refer the House in part to an editorial entitled `Justice at last' which appeared in the Brisbane Courier-Mail on 7 September last year. It stated:

The view that the Commonwealth has behaved with despicable bureaucratic self-interest in the Voyager case would result in very little argument in the general community. The High Court ruling . . . paving the way for compensation claims by the survivors of that horrific 1964 naval accident is a signal victory for social justice.

The Commonwealth long denied liability for compensation. Mr Hawke's first government lifted the statute of limitations on the case in 1985, then slammed the door when it found there might be substantial compensation claims in the offing.

About 80 survivors of the Voyager now are eligible to lodge claims to be compensated for the nightmare that began 26 years ago, among them Queenslander Bernie Verwayen, who spent all his money fighting through to Wednesday's decision.

The ruling means that the Commonwealth as the employer of people paid to defend the country cannot claim exemption from civil compensation if they come to harm in the course of normal duties. This is an important precedent. It is also elementary justice.

I am delighted that Bernie, his wife and Voyager colleagues are in the public gallery at this late hour-yet another example of their great courage and determination. Physically, Bernie suffered only back and stomach injuries, but by 1969 he had been discharged from the Navy as medically unfit, psychological problems being cited. Between 1969 and 1981 he worked for short stints in about 20 different jobs before being declared totally and permanently incapacitated. He has not worked since because of nerve problems and other ailments.

I also take the opportunity to congratulate Victorian solicitors, Jim Taylor and Mario Viccaro, for their great patience and legal counsel and wish every success to the many other compensation claimants awaiting due legal process. As Bernie Verwayen has said:
This has not only been a fight for me but for the other survivors and all who serve our country.
This is a test case which will be used again and again; that is why it has been so important.
I joined the Navy to serve my country and to have a good, long-term career . . .
When someone is injured in a normal day-to-day job, they expect some form of compensation. That was all we expected.
I hope that the legal processes are not delayed further and that the dark spectre of the Voyager tragedy can now be replaced by a sense of human dignity and finality.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Road Safety and Standards: Fairfield City Council Area

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio The Hon J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight on the adjournment debate to bring up a matter of great concern within my electorate of Prospect. According to the recent Roads and Traffic Authority report, in 1990, 24 people were killed in road accidents within the Fairfield City Council area. Along with Blacktown, this was the highest number of deaths in any local government area in New South Wales during 1990. In 1989 there were some 2,113 crashes on Fairfield roads, 27 fatalities, 211 serious injuries and 1,015 minor injuries. It must be noted that these statistics represent only 25 to 30 per cent of all accidents since the only accidents which were recorded were those reported to police, those which occurred on a public road, those which involved at least one moving vehicle and those which involved at least one person being killed or injured or at least one vehicle being towed away.

SPEECH.PARA: Fairfield City Council is in dire need of State and Federal funding to make local roads safer for drivers and pedestrians and it should be up to the New South Wales Roads and Traffic Authority to ensure that the council receives it. How many more people have to be injured and die in traffic accidents due to roads which are badly in need of upgrading before the State and Federal governments do something about it? According to a recent report by the Fairfield City Council traffic engineer to the council's public works committee, in 1988-89 the Fairfield area had 56 intersections in the top 1,000 black spot intersections-eight of which rated in the top 100 black spot intersections within New South Wales. The report also stated:

In 1988 the Fairfield Local Government Area recorded the third highest crash frequency for all category of injuries of any Local Government area in New South Wales. In 1989 it recorded the second highest.
Now, in 1990, it has recorded the highest. In view of this the report has recommended that the council should:
. . . lobby the local members both State and Federal, in an attempt to secure more funding for road safety programs.

Fairfield City Council has estimated that it will now need about $45m to keep up with, and clear, the backlog of road works that must be completed within the area. Of the $90.1m that the Federal Government has allocated to the Greiner Government for local roads for the 1990-91 financial year, Fairfield City Council will receive $662,600, plus $250,000 in retrospective funding for Lawson Street overpass-a bridge, I might add, which was opened in August last year.

The State Government is providing the council with a total of $2.352m for funding of various local road projects, which includes retrospective funding of $1.257m for the Lawson Street overpass. However, these moneys are a far cry from the $45m the council has estimated it will now need. According to the council report, the Roads and Traffic Authority was:
. . . seeking a $90,000 commitment from the Federal Government in the 1990-91 Blackspot program-

to contribute towards a part time safety officer in council, publicity and promotions in the local area and market research to monitor those promotions. However, the council recently received notice that it was not to be granted this funding.

The Greiner Government has certainly neglected its responsibilities by not allocating sufficient funds to carry out major road construction and improvements within the fastest growing local government area in New South Wales. Unfortunately, it is my constituents and their families who have to find the money to pay for both State and Federal fuel excise with no guarantee that increased local road construction works will be carried out.

In another report to the council on the state of our local roads, statistics show that 37 per cent of all fatalities which occurred in the Fairfield local government area in 1989 occurred on one of our most notorious roads, the Horsley Drive. However, of all the funds granted to Fairfield City Council, about $50,000 only will be spent on this road. There is just not enough money to go around. According to that report I have mentioned:

Traffic volumes are increasing and are likely to do so in the short to medium term. Funding for the reconstruction and development of the Horsley Drive as a major traffic route has now become critical.

The report went on to say that accidents on the Horsley Drive in 1989 alone cost the community an estimated $9.2m in fatalities and injuries. It was even recorded on 8 January in our local paper that the local engineer of Fairfield City Council stated that:
Horsley Drive is our number one priority and has been an ongoing concern for the past 25 years. It is our most dangerous road and little more than a cow track.

I bring this and other evidence before this Parliament because I believe that the road funding needs to be more adequate. In view of Fairfield City Council's problem, we certainly have to have a bigger share of the funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bailey Mrs F.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 and 28 December last year over 20,000 hectares of grassland, scrub and forest was burnt in my electorate of McEwen in the Strathbogies and around Euroa and district. The damage was horrific, especially occurring at a time when the rural sector is already struggling for survival. The financial cost was considerable. In value of insured property alone it was estimated to be around $3m. Many farmers, already experiencing financial difficulties were underinsured. They will face an even greater battle to restore their properties. Farm homes were destroyed. Wool sheds, dairy sheds and hay sheds were burnt. Thousands of kilometres of fencing were destroyed. It has been difficult to accurately estimate all stock losses but it amounted to approximately 14,000 sheep, hundreds of beef and dairy cattle, horses, goats and other stock and over three quarters of a million bales of hay.

SPEECH.PARA: It took 2 1/2 days to bring the fires under control and another four days of close attention. But it was 10 days before anyone could really relax. The fires, especially in the Strathbogie area, were burning in very rugged country. Only a handful of fire fighters knew the terrain but five graders and eight dozers worked in the dark with only hand-held torches to guide them.

One hundred and five Country Fire Authority (CFA) tankers from 96 brigades, involving over 1,000 men, gave 15,000 man-hours and fought those fires. It was a superb effort. Volunteers came from the CFA from as far away as Swan Hill, the Department of Conservation and Environment, the Victorian police, State emergency services, the Department of Agriculture, Vic Roads, the Salvation Army, the Red Cross Society, the ambulance service, St John's Ambulance Brigade, and the shires of Euroa, Violet Town, Goulburn, Yea and Mansfield. As well as these people, there were armies of ladies providing meals and moral support. All of these volunteers were tested to the limits of their endurance with little or no rest during those critical 2 1/2 days that it took to bring the fires under control.

As well as this superb volunteer effort in fighting the fires, the follow up was just fantastic. Members of local service clubs, private citizens and friends have been helping with the reconstruction of those thousands of kilometres of fencing. Fodder has been donated from all over the State, as well as money for the high cost of petrol and transport to get the fodder to where it was needed.

The State Disaster Restoration Committee Chairman, John Hill, said that there are three phases after a fire-the heroic, the honeymoon and the disillusion phase. Local Department of Agriculture personnel feel that the disillusion phase has yet to be experienced. All those affected by the fires have been wonderfully supported by their local community but the time is fast approaching when they are going to have to face and make decisions about their survival, given the current rural depression.

I fear that the third phase of disillusion could be long and deeply felt. The sense of pride and commitment in rural areas is still very strong but this Government needs, as a matter of urgency, to let rural communities know that it supports the long term future of rural industries. If this Government would show even a small percentage of the support and commitment shown by the volunteers in fighting those fires, rural residents would feel less uncertain, less fearful and less neglected about their future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wright Mr K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just after 1991 began, Rockhampton, which is the very centre of my electorate, faced a natural disaster when the Fitzroy River was totally flooded. People no doubt saw what was happening because the local television stations gave good coverage to it. But one had to have been there to understand exactly what was occurring. I was speaking to some of the members from this House who flew over the area afterwards and they just could not appreciate the extent of the flooding that took place.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to say that to start with and then get to the point of placing on record my personal appreciation for the fantastic effort of so many people, including the State Emergency Service, the special disaster emergency group that was set up under Superintendent Hornhouse, and the hundreds upon hundreds of people from the city council, the Army, the Royal Australian Air Force, the police, and the prisoners. This total community effort demonstrates something of the inner Australian-that when there is trouble people will stick together.

It was a time of devastation. It was a time when hundreds of homes were flooded and when thousands of people were dislocated. It was traumatic for so many whose lives were lost, for the old folk who sat and saw their savings washed away and their houses destroyed. Children lost toys and adults lost their cars and their trucks and their businesses.

I think we need to learn a lesson from this. We need to pay tribute to those who did so much. At the moment the State Government and the city council have come up with a plan for an overall study which will cost $250,000. I am hopeful that the Federal Government will play its part and contribute the $100,000 that is needed.

We need to try to find some reasons for all this. This devastation will cost the community around $300m. It has been put to me that we could build a dam at the gap on the Fitzroy that will cost in 1989 terms about $300m. Every day of that flood the total storage of the Sydney Harbour ran past the city of Rockhampton. Honourable members can just imagine what it was all about-the total storage of Sydney Harbor in one day. It is possible that we would be able to somehow head off these difficulties. What happened in 1988 is happening right now. The floods have risen to 7.6 metres. I am suggesting in this House that as a nation we need to use the Fitzroy base as an experiment. The flood plain is one of the biggest in the nation with 71 tributaries flowing into the Fitzroy.

I believe that there would be many other places in Australia that could gain not just by a $250,000 study but by a major flood mitigation program, whether it be the establishment of dams, whether it be the construction of levy banks or whatever. It might even mean changing the course of the river in parts but I believe we can learn from it. We really cannot put a figure on the damage to cattle and life.

I spoke to the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) about the problems that we are going to face for months and months, if not years ahead, trying to fix up bridges and sort out the damaged roads- not just main roads but the arterial and minor roads. There seems to be a need for us to take note of what has taken place and learn from what has occurred and what has been occurring since recorded times for 90-odd years.

Each time there is a problem the people of Rockhampton and district will come to the fore. There will be those who will show great courage and those who will give their all. There are so many people who have collectively given something like $360,000 to the appeal. There will always be those who will get out there and work. They will man the 24-hour emergency telephone systems, deliver the food to those in need and help with the storage of the furniture that has been shifted.

I reiterate that we need, if possible, to learn a lesson. We need to allocate the necessary funds to carry out a national study of the Fitzroy Basin in the hope that we can head off future catastrophes, as this has been, and in the hope that Australia shall learn from the problems that we have been experiencing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew Mr J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to relate to the Parliament a very interesting and valuable experience for me late last year when I accompanied the honourable member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin) to the electorate of Barker where the Minister opened the Woolpunda salt interception scheme. To appreciate the enormity and the importance of this salt interception scheme one almost has to be a South Australian, because South Australians are aware of the dependence of that State on the River Murray. Let us take, for example, the use of water by Adelaide, which in some years has been up to 90 per cent dependent on the River Murray. Of course, quite apart from this urban concentration, we also have the dependence of the rest of South Australia on this water resource, given that reticulation from the River Murray stretches from Keith in the south-east to the Iron Triangle in the north of the State.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, management of the river comes under the Murray-Darling Basin Standing Committee. But my particular interest in this scheme, and the interest I want to bring to the Parliament, lies in the enormous potential for harm to South Australians caused by salination. It is calculated that salination in the River Murray basin in terms of crop loss costs the nation $65m per annum. In damage to industrial fittings, to hot water services and to various urban facilities, the cost to the nation is $37m per annum. For that reason, the control of salinity in the River Murray is all important.

The Woolpunda salt interception scheme is quite unique. Most people imagine that salinity in the River Murray is somehow the fault of River Murray irrigators who have used too much water thus causing salination. In the case of the Woolpunda salt interception scheme this is not true at all. The Woolpunda salt interception scheme is designed to pick up saline inflows as a result of northern Victoria and southern New South Wales once having been an enormous inland sea.

It is calculated that just over the border in South Australia, in Woolpunda, as a result of this inland sea 170 tonnes of salt now enter the river daily along this particular stretch of the River Murray. In fact, 8 per cent of the River Murray's total salt load is picked up here. The salt interception scheme that I watched being opened has the capacity, when operating successfully, to reduce salinity at Morgan, the point at which the river turns to the south, by 113 EC units on average. This is a $25m scheme. I commend the Government for its role in the scheme and plead with it to generate additional resources for schemes as important as this.

I will give honourable members an impression of what the scheme is about. There are 49 boreholes each side of the river about Woolpunda. Each of these boreholes has a pump on it. Each pump has the capacity to pick up 4 litres of saline water per second. However, the saline water is moving closer to the river at the rate of 10 metres per year. I ask honourable members to consider that. The water has come all the way from northern Victoria and southern New South Wales to reach Woolpunda. It is moving closer to the river basin at the rate of 10 metres per year. This water, intercepted by each of the 49 boreholes-and in one case taken by pump under the river to an evaporation basin-is not only 10 to 20 times more saline than the River Murray water, but in addition when the water appears in the evaporation basin, never having been seen before by human eye, it is probably millions of years old. It has come all the way underground, at the rate of 10 metres per year, from New South Wales and Victoria.

The evaporation basin which is collecting the saline water is located 15 kilometres south-west of Waikerie, near that bend in the river on which Morgan is located. It is estimated that the evaporation basin there will be receiving water for at least 400 years. The site was chosen because it is an indentation in the land that allows evaporation to occur with a minimum amount of water returning to the river. It is calculated, because of the location of the basin, that it would take 50,000 years for water that has been deposited in the evaporation basin to make its way back into the river.
The Woolpunda salt interception scheme has the capacity to dramatically reduce salinity at Morgan in the River Murray. I commend the Government for its implementation of the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wonderful! I call the honourable member for Stirling and comment that he has a very hard act to follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Mr R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) has dealt with a major issue, and I commend him for it. I wish to draw the attention of the House to the fact that many businesses in Western Australia are alive and doing some very significant things in the marketplace.

SPEECH.PARA: One of those is a company currently producing chill packs that have the capacity, through the addition of water to a dry crystal substance, to produce an instant icepack that has application in sport and also in military areas where one can have a cold esky that can be transported into the field. Just by adding water one gets a significant temperature exchange that enables food to be chilled. That is just something that one company is doing. I would like to spend more on that at a future time.

I want to mention also the development of a zinc bromine battery in Western Australia which has enormous potential for the storage of electricity. It enables the taking of mains electricity and storing it in battery form, and it is able to be used in household and factory applications. It has significant application too because it changes base and peak load requirements for electricity generated through the major net.

Another matter I want to address tonight is the safe use of syringes in hospitals, as well as in the marketplace generally. Honourable members may not be aware that one of our really significant health problems at present, particularly for health care workers, concerns the use of the common syringe in hospitals. I refer to the use of syringes on patients by hospital staff. There are difficulties with the exposed needle tip such as is evident in regard to the syringe I have here. Very clearly, there are problems in relation to Aids and to Hepatitis B. The possibility of needlestick injuries is a constant problem for health care workers. There are a significant number of patients with Hepatitis B in hospitals. I emphasise Hepatitis B because although so much attention is focused on Aids, Hepatitis B is also a very serious problem for health care workers.

A company in Western Australia called Nujenko has in fact developed a safe retractable syringe. Clearly, its other area of application in the marketplace exists because with a retractable syringe we can eliminate the possibility of needle sharing, which also causes significant problems. I want to draw the attention of the House to this development. I am speaking also with Government Ministers, not with a view to trying necessarily to cosset this company called Nujenko but simply to say that there are companies such as Nujenko prepared to do the market research to enable them to get to the stage where they can produce, for example, syringes capable of being used only once.

If serum is drawn up in the syringe and used by the normal injection method, the syringe tip will then collapse inside the housing so that the syringe cannot be used again. It is significant also because of its safety application. One of the problems of hospital use is that people often try to recap the syringe. Obviously, in the pressure of hospital activity, with patients' health at risk and so on, people often injure themselves by trying to recap a syringe, just as I am doing now. In fact, the advantage of the Nujenko retractable syringe is that the needle is retracted inside the syringe housing. It has significant application for health care workers.

I am pleased to say that the Health Department of Western Australia and Dr Charles Watson will be testing the syringe this month at Fremantle Hospital. I think it is important to understand that there are many people in Australia who are prepared to do this sort of work. Another product similar to this is being developed in Queensland but the significance of the Western Australian development is that this syringe will be available at the same cost as existing syringes. I do not think we can possibly expect large hospital systems to shift from their existing syringe use to the use of syringes such as this if it is going to cost them more. However, this syringe will be available on the market at approximately the same cost as the existing syringes used in hospital systems.

I think it is significant that companies such as Nujenko are prepared to put money into the marketplace to try to develop a syringe which is timely in terms of social outcomes and which is timely also in terms of the demands of health care and hospital workers. I particularly want to draw the attention of the House to this and commend Nujenko for the work it has done in the development of this product.
House adjourned at 11 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following notices were given:
Mr Kerr to move-
That this House:
(1) expresses its deep concern about the current situation in Tibet;
(2) recognises that human rights abuses have been committed in Tibet by the People's Republic of China since 1959 and that human rights abuses are reportedly continuing;
(3) endorses Resolutions No. 1353 of 1959, No. 1723 of 1961 and No. 2079 of 1965 of the UN General Assembly and recognises that they remain relevant today;
(4) endorses the call for the cessation of practices which deprive the Tibetan people of their fundamental human rights and freedoms;

(5) commends the Dalai Lama and his representatives for consistently rejecting the use of violence and notes that this was acknowledged in the awarding of the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize to the Dalai Lama;
(6) endorses the representations made by the Australian Government and by members of this Parliament to the People's Republic of China on alleged human rights abuses, generally and in Tibet;
(7) calls on the Government of the People's Republic of China to:

(a) recognise the fundamental human rights and freedoms of the Tibetan people as set out in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Human Rights Covenants, including the right to practise their cultural and religious traditions without fear of persecution, arrest or torture;
(b) enter into earnest discussions, without preconditions, with the Dalai Lama and his representatives with a view to reducing the tensions in Tibet; and
(c) respond to representations made by the Australian Government and by members of this Parliament on allegations on human rights abuses and the human rights situation in general in Tibet; and

(8) calls on the Australian Government to continue to make representations to, and seek responses from, the Government of the People's Republic of China on allegations of human rights abuses in Tibet.
Mr Langmore to move-
That, in view of:
(1) the concentration of ownership of the press which is unprecedented in Australia's history and unparalleled in any Western democracy; and

(2) the unacceptable concentration of power, the restrictions on the diversity of information and ideas, the barriers to entry and other aspects of market failure, the diminished localism of content and accountability, the debilitating impact on journalistic culture and the conflicts of interest which this concentration of ownership involves-
this House calls for the establishment of a Royal Commission to inquire into the press including:
(a) the extent of concentration in the ownership and control and the effects of that on:
(i) the provision of accurate, fair and comprehensive news;
(ii) the diversity of opinions and the opportunities for expression; and
(iii) the practice of journalism; and
(b) the regulatory framework in Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 12 September 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Since the passage of the Reserve Bank Act 1959, have any arrangements been made by the Reserve Bank for prudential supervision of banks owned by State governments; if so, (a) what arrangements and (b) on what date was each made.

(2) On what date did the Victorian Government give the formal undertaking to the Reserve Bank, as reported in the Bank's annual report for 1989-90, that the State Bank of Victoria (SBV) would observe the Reserve Bank's supervisory requirements.
(3) Did officers of the Reserve Bank later meet with representatives of the Victorian Government and the board of the SBV to discuss supervision issues.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Reserve Bank has provided the following information in answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The early basis of the relationship between banks owned by state governments and the Reserve Bank was laid down in letters of understanding in 1959/60 (for state savings banks) and 1965 (for other state banks); in the case of South Australia, where the state bank and state savings bank merged in 1984, this understanding was reaffirmed at that time. These early exchanges of letters provided (a) for consultation between the state-owned banks and the Reserve Bank on a range of matters relating to banking trends and policy, and (b) for the Reserve Bank to act as `bankers bank' in relation to the state-owned banks. These letters did not encompass matters relating to `prudential supervision' which has developed only since the mid 1980s.

The broad framework for current prudential supervision of banks was promulgated in a Reserve Bank press release dated 4 February 1985; various aspects of the Bank's supervisory arrangements have been modified or varied since that time. While not formally required to do so, state banks have generally observed the Bank's prudential guidelines on a voluntary basis.
Major aspects of the Reserve Bank's supervisory requirements are noted below:

- Arrangements for the assessment of the capital adequacy of banks were announced in August 1988, to take effect as soon as was practicable. Banks which did not at that time already meet the newly defined minimum requirement were given a transition period (to June 1990 at the latest) during which they had to take measures to achieve the minimum. Once a bank had achieved that position, there was an exchange of letters between the relevant bank and the Reserve Bank wherein the bank gave an assurance that it would comply with the capital requirement thereafter. Obviously, the timing for such exchanges of letters varied. For the state banks, these assurances were given to the Reserve Bank as follows:
State Bank of New South Wales-December 1988
- Guidelines relating to banks' associations with non-banks were detailed to state banks in 1983 (having been given to other banks in the late 1970s) and were further elaborated in September 1988.

- During 1986, the Bank established tripartite reporting arrangements with banks and their external auditors. State banks and their auditors have participated in these arrangements in the same way as other banks.
- The most recent statement of the Bank's policy on banks' large credit exposures was issued in August 1989. All banks, including state banks, were asked to observe the policy at that time.

- The Reserve Bank has sought from all banks, including state banks, a formal commitment that they will hold at all times eligible assets sufficient to satisfy the minimum Prime Assets Requirement (PAR) ratio. The Bank most recently sought this undertaking by letter of 12 February 1990, at which time it also announced a progressive reduction in the minimum PAR ratio from 10 per cent to 6 per cent. All banks have given the required undertaking.

(2) There were exchanges of correspondence between the Reserve Bank and Victorian Government on this topic during the first half of 1990. The Victorian Treasurer gave the Reserve Bank the Government's formal undertaking to the new arrangements on 31 July 1990.

(3) In view of the subsequent proposal for the Commonwealth Bank to acquire SBV, there have since the end of July been no specific discussions about supervision issues between the Victorian Government and the Reserve Bank, in terms of the formal arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 17 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a statement by the Prime Minister at a press conference on 24 September 1990 that in relation to Qantas and Australian Airlines, general public listing would be limited and that the most effective operation would involve foreign airlines and other major transport operators.
(2) Will Qantas and Australian Airlines be listed on the stock exchange to enable the general public to purchase shares.
(3) Will any portion of (a) Qantas and (b) Australian Airlines be offered to (i) the Australian public and (ii) employees; if so, in each case (A) what portion and (B) when.
(4) Is the Government committed to privatisation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am aware of the Prime Minister's press conference statement of 24 September 1990 concerning Qantas and Australian Airlines. In fact, the news conference referred to by Mr Moore was one called jointly by the Prime Minister and myself.

The Government has yet to settle on the final arrangements for the sale of equity in the airlines. Key considerations in this process are the long term viability of the enterprises and appropriate capital structure. At the same time, the Government will be seeking to ensure that the Commonwealth realises an appropriate return on these assets.

(2) This matter will be determined when Cabinet has had an opportunity to consider private consultants' advice. The sale is being conducted by the Department of Finance. Questions should be directed to Mr Willis.

(3) The Government is aware of the benefits to be obtained from both employee ownership and general public involvement. The offering of shares in Australian Airlines and Qantas to the general public is dealt with above. The Government has announced that employees will be able to participate in the sale of equity in both airlines. Details of such participation schemes will be decided in the course of the sale process.
(4) The decisions taken to sell certain Government Business Enterprises were made on a case by case basis, taking into account the particular circumstances relevant to each enterprise.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 17 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What are the economic and other considerations involved in examining proposals to forward Australian stockpiled wool on credit terms to countries with present idle mill capacity, such as China and the USSR.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has considered options to restart the wool trade with the USSR and is considering ways to increase wool exports to China. The provision of insurance cover for credit has been considered against the need to balance Australia's overall interests in those markets and the risk of non-payment.

I am pleased to be able to say that during the course of the Wool Mission from which I have recently returned a credit arrangement has been successfully negotiated with the USSR. I am confident this arrangement will enable a substantial return by the USSR to the Australian wool market.

The credit facility provides for a Government guarantee on sales of commodities valued at up to $400 million on a 240 day roll-over basis. I expect that the majority of the credit will be used for wool purchases, but it will also assist with sales of other traditionally traded commodities. A prompt return of the USSR to the Australian wool market will provide a much needed confidence boost to the market place.

In China, commercial credit has been offered but appears unlikely to be taken up by Chinese authorities. With the improvement in the Chinese current account position the problem is now not so much lack of credit, but stagnant demand both domestically and from China's export markets. In China there remains a large stockpile of domestic wool, a legacy of the so called `wool war' between the provinces. The austerity measures in place continue to curb demand with little likelihood of substantial sales for some time.

Some relatively small amounts of wool are being made available from the AWC stockpile at the present time in conjunction with carefully selected industry and product development projects designed to generate a sustained increase in the demand for wool worldwide. These projects are being run jointly by the AWC and the International Wool Secretariat. The IWS in particular, has considerable expertise in undertaking demand building activities for wool. Any credit provided for these sales is provided through normal commercial banking arrangements.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 6 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Did the Horticultural Policy Council reject the proposed protocol for the importation of apples from New Zealand because of the potential for entry to Australia of the disease fire blight; if so, will the importation of apples from New Zealand be prevented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Griffiths The Hon A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (i) The Horticultural Policy Council report on `Proposal for the Import of Apple Fruit from Blight Free Districts of New Zealand', inter alia, concluded that:

`The Council believes that there are sufficient scientific grounds to conclude that under the draft agreement proposed by New Zealand the causal organism of fire blight disease (Erwinia amylovora) will enter Australia from imported apple fruit and that there is a real possibility, albeit low, that fire blight disease could establish itself from this source.

While it is not possible for the Council to quantify the level of risk involved under the draft agreement proposed by MAFQual for fire blight establishing itself in Australia following carriage by New Zealand apples, it is considered significant and the draft agreement should therefore not be ratified'.

(ii) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) has completed its assessment of the New Zealand proposal and has concluded that it does not provide sufficient safeguards against the entry and establishment of fire blight in Australia.

An information paper has been prepared which addresses the major issues raised in the many submissions received on the matter. New Zealand Authorities and local peak industry bodies have been invited to review the AQIS conclusions.
AQIS is prepared to reconsider its position in the light of any new scientific information which satisfactorily addresses the areas of risk identified in the assessment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 7 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does existing legislation provide for a wool tax of 20 per cent.
(2) Is wool tax being levied at 25 per cent; if so, does the Australian Wool Corporation (AWC) retain the additional five per cent.

(3) If wool tax is being levied at 25 per cent and the AWC is not retaining the additional five per cent, (a) who is holding the additional sum and (b) if the sum is lodged in an interest bearing trust account who will receive the resulting interest.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) As at 3 October 1990, the maximum rate of wool tax under the Wool Tax Acts (Nos 1-5) 1964 was 20 per cent. An operative rate of 18 per cent applied from 1 July 1990 until 3 October 1990.
The wool tax is divided into 3 components and the apportionment of the 18% rate amongst each component was: Research and Development 0.35%, Promotion 3.50% and Market Support 14.15%.

On 4 October the Government, in the light of the recommendations in the AWC Business Plan, decided that the maximum tax rate should be raised from 20 per cent to 30 per cent and the operative rate from 18 per cent to 25 per cent, from 4 October. This additional percentage in the operative rate is allocated to Market Support, to support the AWC's purchases of wool under the Reserve Price Scheme.

A legislative package comprising the Wool Legislation Amendment Bill 1990 and the Wool Tax Further Amendment Bills (Nos 1-5) 1990 was debated in Parliament in November and received Royal Assent on 29 November 1990. This legislation gives effect to the Government's decision to increase, effective from 4 October 1990, the operative and maximum rates of wool tax.
(3) Not applicable in view of answers to questions (1) and (2).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 7 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Government's recent decision to reduce the assets test threshold for Austudy and assistance for isolated children from $300 000 to $200 000 create an effective threshold of $400 000 for farmers and owners of small businesses.
(2) Will the cash limits associated with the proposed Austudy income test apply a cut-off point of $32 043 per annum, extending by $12 740 for additional children aged 16 years or more.

(3) Does the currently estimated net return from a farming venture of approximately five per cent on capital suggest an income of $20 000 per annum from a capital base of $400 000; if so, why has the Government made the assets test so much more severe than the income test.
(4) Why do the adjustments with respect to additional children which apply under the income test not apply under the assets test.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the August 1990 Budget a parental assets test threshold of $200 000 was announced for AUSTUDY and the Assistance for Isolated Children (AIC) Scheme from 1 January 1991. On 8 October 1990 the Government announced the withdrawal of that limit. The 1991 threshold will be $347 500 as a result of indexation of the 1990 threshold of $322 750.

All assets are assessed free of debt. The 50 per cent discount is retained for the assets of a farm or other business in which the owner works. This will mean that, where only business and farm assets apply, these can be worth up to $695 000 before a student's allowance is affected.

(2)-(3) There is no direct link between the assets and income tests such as an expected net return on capital. In any consideration of assets levels it is necessary to take account of factors other than income generated, such as potential capital gain, ability to negotiate short-term loans using the asset as security, and ability to sell off all or part of the asset.

(4) To avoid unnecessary complexity in the assets test the Government set a threshold well above the limits under Social Security pensions and benefits, and applied a sudden death cut-off. As a result, it was possible to avoid the introduction of abatement rates and dependent child deductions to the AUSTUDY and AIC assets tests.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walker Mr F.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 7 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Minister's attention been drawn to reports of a counterfeit operation worth up to $1 million in Melbourne involving the pressing of recordings of international artists; if so, is the Australian Federal Police investigating the matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Given the Government's foreshadowed removal of hardship provisions in taxation legislation, what provision has been made for persons affected by the closure of the Pyramid Building Society in Geelong.
(2) Will there be any means whereby the persons referred to in part (1) may apply for leniency with regard to their liability for tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Taxation Office is giving sympathetic consideration to all requests for deferment of tax payments for people who had a significant portion of their funds frozen by the closure, on 25 June 1990, of the Pyramid Building Society in Geelong. To defer payment of taxes due, these people need to inform their ATO branch offices of their situation and they would be required to provide documentary evidence (either a passbook or account statement) of their position when applying to defer their tax payments.

Generally speaking, people whose tax liabilities did not become due until 25 June or later, are able to defer their tax payments without any penalty. However, people who had failed to meet their tax liabilities before 25 June would be subject to the late payment penalty from the due date of payment until 25 June 1990.
Each persons need for a continuing deferral of tax payments is assessed on its own merits.
(2) Until the relevant amending legislation comes before the Parliament, applications for relief from payment of tax will continue to be received and heard by the Taxation Relief Board.

Although at this stage details have not been finalised, it is proposed that in cases involving hardship, alternative measures to deal with such matters, will be established. These will in no way replace the current administrative arrangements where people may make instalment arrangements with the Taxation Office to clear their tax debts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 8 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are persons who have been discharged from the Australian Defence Force (ADF) on medical grounds eligible to be retrained and employed in the Australian Public Service.
(2) How many persons who have been discharged from the ADF on medical grounds are receiving (a) full or (b) partial compensation.
(3) What is the cost to the Commonwealth of payments referred to in part (2).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) While my Department provides comprehensive rehabilitation programs for members of the Defence Force who have suffered compensable injuries, including retraining for positions in the general labour market, there is no provision in the Public Service Act which allows former Defence Force members to automatically enter the Australian Public Service. Former Defence personnel wishing to join the Australian Public Service are required to compete with all other applicants for positions in the Public Service on the basis of results obtained in an entrance examination, or compete on merit for positions advertised in the press as available to non-public servants.

(2) The Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 requires the Defence Department to report in terms of numbers of claims where weekly incapacity payments are made to former Defence Force members, not on numbers of medically discharged members receiving full or part compensation. Accordingly the Department's recording system is not designed to provide the specific information sought. However, I can advise that during the Financial Year 1989/90, the Department made weekly incapacity payments to 1061 former Defence Force members.
(3) The cost of the payments made was $13,098,764.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 12 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does Brazil, the largest producer of citrus products, receive developing country status and tariff concessions.
(2) Is he able to say whether the USA and New Zealand removed such concessions to Brazil.
(3) Do existing anti-dumping measures adequately protect Australia's horticulture.
(4) Will the 25 per cent fruit juice requirement in the sales tax concession arrangements for fruit juice products be removed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Brazil does receive developing country status which means that in trade with Australia it receives a 5% tariff concession.
(2) New Zealand has not removed the developing country tariff concession in respect of Brazilian orange juice.
Citrus juice imports into the USA are not allowed any tariff concessions, the across-the-board rate for citrus being 35 per cent ad valorem.
(3) Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing legislation is in place to protect Australian manufacturers and producers from two types of unfair import competition:
(a) dumping-where goods are imported into Australia at lower prices than the price paid for like goods in their home market
(b) subsidisation-where goods are imported into Australia which have been produced and exported with the benefit of government subsidies.

The anti dumping measures are aimed at protecting Australian industry where it is established that dumped or subsidised imports have caused, or are threatening to cause, material injury to an Australian industry producing like goods. It is Government policy that antidumping measures do not become de facto forms of assistance to industry.

When the Anti-Dumping Authority was established in 1988 for a period of five years, the government announced there would be a mid-term review of administrative arrangements introduced at that time. Any perceived problems with the current arrangements could be examined in that context.
A Senate Committee on 7 November 1990 agreed to the setting up of its own review of anti-dumping arrangements.

On 13 December 1990 I announced that Cabinet has decided that the Australian Customs Service will give urgent consideration to any anti-dumping application received against Brazilian frozen concentrated orange juice. An official will be made available to assist with the preparation of a case.

I also announced on 13 December that anti-dumping and countervailing arrangements are being reviewed and I will be holding urgent discussions on the current arrangements with the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.

(4) On 11 September 1990 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and I announced a number of Government decisions in response to the February 1988 Industries Assistance Commission (IAC) Report on Fresh Fruit and Fruit Products Industries.

We announced that the Government had decided to maintain differential sales tax arrangements where beverages containing less than 25 per cent fruit juices are subject to 20 per cent sales tax, and drinks with a higher content are subject to a lower rate of 10 per cent. We said that the implementation of the IAC recommendation to increase the tax on all juice products to 20 per cent is not justifiable.
We also announced that the local content rule, under which juice from Australian, Papua New Guinean and New Zealand fruit gained tax advantages over imported juice, will be removed from 1 July 1991.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fisher Mr P.S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 12 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many rural counsellors are funded by the Commonwealth and what sums are provided to them.
(2) Where do the rural counsellors referred to in part (1) operate.
(3) What contributions does each State government make to the rural counselling program.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are currently 24 rural counsellors funded by the Commonwealth under the Rural Counselling Program. An application for an additional rural counsellor in Western Australia has been approved but the counsellor has yet to be appointed. Funds are provided to the local community groups which employ the counsellors on a dollar for dollar basis to a maximum of $46,200 a year. $960,000 were appropriated for 1990/91 for counsellors' costs, training and support.

(2) There are currently 8 counsellors in NSW (based at Gunnedah, Moree, Griffith, Deniliquin, Gilgandra, Parkes, Forbes and Tottenham) 5 in Victoria (Horsham, Mildura, Sea Lake, Cobram and Leongatha), 6 in South Australia (Karoonda, Berri, Kapunda, Cleve, Wudinna and Ceduna), 4 in WA (Newdegate, Corrigin, Morawa and Bencubbin) and 1 in Tasmania (Westbury). There are no counsellors under the Commonwealth's Program in Queensland which has its own counselling scheme for farmers.

(3) Contributions by State Governments to the program vary between States. The Tasmanian Government provides no assistance. The NSW Government, through the Department of Agriculture, provides 25% of the costs of current groups' budgets and has announced that it will provide up to 50% of new groups' budgets for their first year of operation. The Victorian Government is providing $10,000 in cash and $30,000 `in kind' such as office space, or a car. These amounts are spread across all Victorian groups according to need. The Western Australian Government provides $1000, a car and petrol to each group through the Department of Agriculture. In addition, the Rural Adjustment and Finance Corporation has provided each group in WA with $4000 and in the past the State Lotteries Commission has provided cash to two groups but is not providing any funds this year. In SA the South Australian Government Financing Authority has provided $100,000 for the last 3 years for the use of all SA groups on a needs basis. It has announced, however, that this donation will be discontinued.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Campbell Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Australian Wool Corporation accept responsibility for the loss of value resulting from staining in bellies and pieces kept in double or triple dumped bales for lengthy periods; if so, how will woolgrowers be compensated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Bellies and pieces stored in double or triple dumped bales do not suffer a loss in value from staining or decreased processing performance. The Australian Wool Corporation has advised that this has been well demonstrated by wool that was left in vessels trapped in the Suez Canal for seven years, which subsequently processed to satisfaction. The question of the responsibility for financial loss therefore does not arise.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 13 November 1990:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Live Sheep Exports to Saudi Arabia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hawker Mr D.P.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 15 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the (a) total number of live sheep exported to Saudi Arabia by, and (b) average price paid to growers in, (i) Australia and (ii) New Zealand in each year since 1987.
(2) How many sheep do (a) Australia and (b) New Zealand expect to export to Saudi Arabia in 1990-91.

(3) Is he able to say whether New Zealand has made arrangements to ship significant numbers of live sheep to Saudi Arabia in the next twelve months; if so, what is the (a) projected number by age and (b) expected prices by category.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kerin The Hon J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Australian live sheep exports to Saudi Arabia

The values above are fob values only and not the price paid to producers. Producers receive a lower percentage of the fob price which varies significantly from shipment to shipment and from state to state.

Detailed data on New Zealand live sheep exports is not available, however traditionally New Zealand supplies the majority of the ``Haj'' sheep (approximately 300,000) on contract. The prices received by New Zealand have varied in recent years with the prices paid for the ``Haj'' lambs fluctuating from a low of $20.00 to a present high of $38.00.

The maximum number of live sheep that New Zealand could supply within exporter specification is understood to be approximately 600,000 per year, and in 1990 New Zealand exports to Saudi Arabia were in the vicinity of 450,000 head.
(2) Australia would have expected to have shipped approximately 800,000 head of live sheep to Saudi Arabia in 1990-91 but this forecast has been complicated by the rejection of the Al Gasseem.
New Zealand has also now suffered a rejection by Saudi Arabia and the implications of this development for Australia and the rejection of the Al Gasseem are still being examined.

(3) No, I am unable to say whether New Zealand has made arrangements to ship large numbers of sheep to Saudi Arabia in the next twelve months even prior to the rejection. However, I understand the maximum number exported by New Zealand would have been in the vicinity of 600,000 head over the next twelve months.
The categories of sheep that New Zealand exports to Saudi are lambs, hoggets and young wethers. The prices would be approximately $A40-45 for lambs, $A38-40 for hoggets and $A30-35 for young wethers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 15 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is his Department no longer paying accounts presented by podiatrists for the treatment of Veterans' Affairs patients within the normal trading terms period of 30 days.

(2) Have restrictions been placed on the travel allowances paid to podiatrists treating Veterans' Affairs patients; if so, (a) why, (b) on what basis are the travel allowances calculated, (c) why are they different from the standard public service rates and (d) do they have the effect of forcing podiatrists to subsidise the treatment of Veterans' Affairs patients.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Humphreys The Hon B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Since June 1990 most claims for podiatry treatment throughout Australia have been paid within 20 days from the day the claim was received by my Department. This is well within the normal commercial practice of 28 days.

A small number of claims (up to 5%) may be delayed because of the need to check that the treatment provided is consistent with the client's accepted disability and therefore payable by the Department.

A further small number of claims may be returned because of incorrect or insufficient information, failure to adhere to guidelines on provision of treatment, etc. These claims are returned to podiatrists for clarification and, if appropriate, are re-submitted for payment. Such delays are beyond the Department's control. However, educational campaigns are continually undertaken to alleviate these problems and procedures continue to be evaluated for possible streamlining.
(2) (a)-(d) In the 1989/90 Budget, mileage allowance for travel by health providers was restricted to travel undertaken beyond a provider's local area.

Normal allowances will be paid if a provider, who must travel more than 10 kilometres for each service, can justify the distance travelled. In these cases the Department will pay the distance travelled beyond the first 10 kilometres.

The rates payable for travel allowance are determined annually by the Department of Industrial Relations and apply to all Departmental staff under the Public Service Act. The rate is also applicable to podiatrists and is aligned to that for vehicles with an engine capacity of over 2000 cc but not more than 3000 cc. This rate has been endorsed by the Inter-Departmental Committee on Fees and Allowances (IDCFA).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Land Transport, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Will tax stamps be available from post office agencies, as well as official post offices, from 1 January 1991; if not, why not.
(2) Can applications for (a) tax file numbers and (b) passports be lodged with post office agencies; if not, why not.
(3) Will he review the availability of services at post office agencies outside major population centres to remove inconvenience to rural communities.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Tax stamps will not be available from post office agencies from 1 January 1991. The withdrawal of this business from post office agencies was requested by the Australian Taxation Office which intends to phase out the tax stamp system and is writing to all employers seeking their cooperation in transferring to the group payment system.

(2) Applications for tax file numbers and passports cannot be lodged with post office agencies at the present time because the agency principals, i.e. the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade respectively, prefer to use only the official post office network for reasons of confidentiality and security. I understand that with regard to passports a clause has been included in the new contract between Australia Post and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade which may result in some post office agencies gaining passport application business.
(3) As mentioned previously, it is up to agency principals to decide whether they want to use post office agencies for their transactions.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Who is responsible for the (a) planning and (b) operation during the exposition of the Australian Pavilion at Expo 92 in Seville, Spain.
(2) What progress has been made in the development of the Pavilion.
(3) What sum has been allocated to the Pavilion project (a) in total and (b) from the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

(4) Was the Australian Pavilion at Expo 88 funded from the Consolidated Revenue Fund; and if so, was it recognised subsequently that Australian pavilions at future expositions would require support from the private sector.
(5) Has support from the private sector been sought with respect to the Australian Pavilion at Expo 92; if so, to what extent has it been forthcoming.
(6) What is the (a) theme and (b) ultimate objective of the Pavilion.
(7) Has the advice of Australian industry and commerce been sought in the planning of the Pavilion and the definition of its objectives.
(8) Does Expo 92 offer an opportunity for Australia to promote trade; if so, why is the project not being administered by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Simmons The Hon D.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) The Expositions and Special Events Section of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) is responsible for co-ordinating Australia's presence. DASETT has consulted widely in developing the Expo 92 Australian Pavilion theme and exhibitry.

In November 1989 the then Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, the Hon Clyde Holding MP, appointed an external advisory committee to take key design and development decisions in relation to the Pavilion. The Expo 92 Australian Pavilion Executive Committee (PEC), as it is known, is chaired by Sir Llewellyn Edwards AC.
The Australian Construction Services (ACS) were engaged in late 1988 as the principal Expo 92 Australian Pavilion design and construction consultants.

(b) Overall operational planning and management of the project rests with DASETT. The day-to-day operation of the Expo 92 Australian Pavilion during the exposition will be managed by a Commissioner-General, to be appointed by the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories, and Pavilion staff.
(2) The main construction contract has been awarded with construction due for completion by mid November 1991.
The contract for the major film and audio-visual segment has been let, and production is proceeding.
Other elements of the Expo 92 Australian Pavilion fitout are proceeding and are scheduled for completion and installation by mid March 1992, approximately one month before the Expo opens.

(3) In the 1989/90 budget, the Government committed $A25 million, in February 1989 prices, over four financial years for the design, construction and operation of the Australian Pavilion at Expo 92. This sum is subject to adjustment for inflation and exchange rate variations.
Additional contributions received as a result of corporate sponsorship agreements are being used to enhance the basic Pavilion budget.

Following the apparent enthusiasm by the business community towards Expo 88, calls were made to review the Commonwealth's traditional approach to funding its participation in Expos, and to devise ways to involve the commercial sector more directly.

(5) Yes. Negotiations for sponsorship agreements have been completed with Qantas Airways, and are continuing with another large Australian company, and there is continuing interest from some companies in official supplier arrangements.

(6) (a) The theme of the Expo 92 Australian Pavilion is ``Australia: Discover, Explore, Experience'', which will reflect the Expo 92 theme of ``The Age of Discovery'' in a way that is designed to widen European perceptions and knowledge of this country, its lifestyle, its attractions as a tourist destination, its potential as a trading partner, its achievements and its people.
(b) The objectives for Australia's participation in Expo 92 are:
- to promote the growth of international tourism to Australia;
- to promote the growth of Australian trade, industry and investment;
- to promote awareness and understanding of Australian society and culture;
- to enhance our political and cultural ties.

(7) Advice has been sought from agencies including the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, Austrade, the Australian Tourist Commission and the CSIRO.

Input to thematic and conceptual development has included consultation with a broad cross-section of public and private sector interests including representation from Australian industry and commerce.

(8) Yes. Responsibility for coordinating Australia's presence at all international expositions sanctioned by the International Bureau of Expositions (BIE) in which Australia decides to participate rests with DASETT.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to newspaper, television and radio advertisements which imply that, despite the imposition from 1 November 1990 of a charge of $2.50 on pensioners for pharmaceuticals, pensioners would pay a maximum of $130 for pharmaceuticals which would thereafter be free.

(2) Is it a fact that (a) pharmaceuticals dispensed to outpatients of public hospitals are not covered by the Pharmaceuticals Benefits Scheme safety net of $130 and (b) some State hospitals apply their own safety net; if so, (i) is it possible that pensioners could pay up to $255 before they became eligible for free pharmaceuticals and (ii) will pharmaceuticals dispensed to outpatients of public hospitals be recognised for the purposes of the safety net.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The advertisements relate to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and reflect the commitment of the Commonwealth to protect pensioners by setting a safety net threshold for PBS expenditure and providing a pension increase to offset the introduction of the $2.50 prescription charge.

(a) It is extremely unlikely that pensioners would pay up to $255 in order to qualify for free pharmaceutical benefits using a combination of Commonwealth and State run safety net arrangements. It is understood that the majority of pensioners utilise either the PBS or public hospital outpatient clinics but not both systems concurrently except in emergencies.

(b) A working party reporting to the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council (AHMAC) is currently looking at a range of Commonwealth/State issues in the provision and funding of pharmaceutical services around Australia. I have asked this working party to consider the issue of the respective state public hospital and Commonwealth PBS safety nets as a matter of urgency.
