QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the configuration of the RAAF Boeing 707 aircraft which transported Battle of Britain veterans to London to take part in the 50th Anniversary of the Battle of Britain on 15 September 1990.
(2) What is the name of all (a) passengers, (b) personnel who flew on the aircraft and (c) passengers who were not veterans or spouses of veterans.
(3) How many veterans and their wives travelled on the aircraft.
(4) What was the itinerary of the veterans from the time they boarded the aircraft in Australia on 3 September 1990 until their return to Australia.
(5) Did a passenger on the aircraft, Air Marshall Sir Ronald Beresford Lees, return from Honolulu with RAAF medical support; if so, is he fully recovered.
(6) Did the Chief of Air Staff and his secretary travel on another aircraft at a later date; if so, (a) why, (b) who accompanied them and (c) when did the second aircraft return to Australia.
(7) Were two ground staff, recognised as veterans by the British Department of Defence and given invitations to Buckingham Palace, denied seats on the RAAF aircraft; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bilney The Hon G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The RAAF Boeing 707 (B707) aircraft which transported Battle of Britain veterans to London for the 50th Anniversary of the Battle of Britain on 15 September 1990, had a configuration of VIP 1st class seating, business class seating and economy class seating; a litter and medical facilities were set up at the rear of the aircraft.

(2) A table detailing the names of passengers on the aircraft is shown in the following table. Included in the list are Battle of Britain Veterans and their ladies, Mrs Funnell (wife of the Chief of the Air Staff (CAS)), senior RAAF officers, the RAAF Flight which marched in the UK, and RAAF administrative, medical, movements and PR support teams; several other duty personnel travelling to the Farnborough Air Show were also included.
AM Sir Ronald Lees and Mrs Lees

(3) Fifteen Battle of Britain veterans and thirteen of their ladies travelled on the aircraft. Originally, the CAS extended invitations to 26 Battle of Britain aircrew veterans and 23 ladies. Some veterans made their own way to the UK and ill health prevented a few veterans from travelling on an overseas flight.

(4) The aircraft departed Australia on 2 September 1990 and returned on 21 September 1990. In transit, the itinerary was related to the route of the aircraft which was similar to that followed by the standard RAAF European service. However, to make the legs more equidistant and comfortable for the veterans on the forward journey, the aircraft travelled via Honolulu, USA, and Winnipeg, Canada to Stanstead in the UK. The return itinerary was via Washington and Honolulu USA to RAAF Richmond. Because there was only a non-augmented crew available for the task, crew duty limitations governed the daily maximum flight time and the duration of crew rest on stopovers. All veterans were responsible for their own accommodation, meal expenses and insurance throughout the journey. Whilst in the UK the veterans organised their own personal program. Before departure from Australia veterans and their ladies obtained tickets and passes to official Battle of Britain functions from the Battle of Britain Fighter Association and the RAAF had no knowledge or responsibility for this aspect of the organisation. In the UK during the week prior to the celebrations, a group of RAAF pilots did travel by bus to the Vintage Air Show at Folkestone. A small number of veterans joined the group on that occasion.

(5) The most senior ranking officer of the veteran group, Sir Ronald Lees of Adelaide, returned on the B707 aircraft from Honolulu to RAAF Richmond. He was under constant medical attention for the duration of the journey and returned to his home in Adelaide. His precise medical condition is unknown at this time.

(6) The CAS, Air Marshal Ray Funnell, originally intended travelling on the B707 with the veterans. However, work commitments prevented him leaving Australia on 2 September 1990, and thus he had to proceed to the UK by civil air arriving in the UK on 12 September 1990 in time for the Battle of Britain celebrations. He was accompanied by his Wing Commander staff officer. Due to the conflict in the Gulf, the whole Battle of Britain detachment almost faltered forty-eight hours prior to departure. This was because of an operational requirement for the use of the B707. However, on 1 September 1990 clearance was given for the tasking of the RAAF B707 on 2 September 1990 with the proviso that the aircraft could, firstly, be diverted as the operational requirement arose and secondly, replaced if and when another RAAF B707 became available. As it transpired, the aircraft in fact remained with the detachment in the UK and another aircraft became serviceable and was put on standby for an operational requirement.

(7) When the decision was made by CAS to include the veteran group and their ladies in the RAAF Battle of Britain visit, because of space limitations and lack of information on the number of Battle of Britain ground crew veterans resident in Australia, the decision was made to exclude ground crew veterans. Subsequently, numerous requests were received through varying channels; i.e. local members, ministers, etc to take two ground crew veteran personnel with the RAAF group. The earlier decision was reviewed but upheld, as there still was no documentary evidence to prove exactly how many veteran ground crew personnel would be eligible for the flight and a common policy had to apply to all eligible ground crew. As an aside, the gentlemen in question, Mr Colson and Mr Carter, were subsequently both offered free travel by QANTAS and indeed arrived in the UK in time to participate in the Battle of Britain celebrations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 4 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Since his answer to question No. 31 (Hansard, 21 August 1990, page 1210), (a) has Western Australia legislated against racial hatred and (b) have fresh acts of incitement been directed against ethnic groups in several States; if so, has the Government accelerated its timetable for Australia (i) to withdraw its reservation to Article 4(a) of the 1965 International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination referred to in his predecessor's answer to question No. 94 (Hansard, 4 November 1987, page 2043) and (ii) to make a declaration under Article 14 of the Convention.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) I understand that the Criminal Code Amendment (Racial Harassment and Incitement to Racial Hatred) Act 1990 (WA) came into effect on 6 November 1990.
(b) I have seen recent media reports referring to acts of vandalism and violence directed at various ethnic groups.

(i) Article 4 (a) of the 1965 International Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination requires States Parties to enact as criminal offences the dissemination of ideas based on racial superiority or hatred, acts of racist violence, and acts inciting racial discrimination or violence. Australia's reservation to Article 4(a) indicates that Australia does not treat as specific offences all the matters covered in the Article. Australia would need to be in a position to observe the requirements of Article 4(a) before withdrawing the reservation. The Government has been considering the question of such legislation, recognising the complexity of finding a balance between freedom of speech and the rights of people to live without fear of racist violence or abuse. The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Inquiry into Racist Violence is due to report in early 1991 and the Government will further consider this matter in the light of the findings of that inquiry.

(ii) The question of making a declaration under Article 14 of the Convention has been discussed in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General over a number of years. At present, the Government is focussing its efforts in the Standing Committee on resolving the related issue of accession to the First Optional Protocol, and will then turn its attention to the declaration under Article 14.

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Mitsubishi Electric AWA, Rydalmere, indicated in May that it would be ceasing production by December 1990 and the company has since confirmed this.

- stable demand for larger sets, where Australian production has concentrated, and limited returns on investment in scale efficiencies in the Australian market,
- increased competition from low wage developing countries such as the Republic of Korea and Taiwan in the market for larger sets, and
- exchange rate fluctuations causing significant increases in the cost of many components having a substantial effect on the competitiveness of Australian producers.
(2) The value of imports of television receivers since 1985 according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics were:
(imports of colour television receivers in the six months to December 1987 were $36 937 516, in the six months to June 1988 imports of television receivers were $79 815 729)
$316 695 697 of consumer electronic equipment including television receivers (imports of colour television receivers alone were $61 895 776)
$269 910 630 of consumer electronic equipment including television receivers (imports of colour television receivers alone were $38 267 666)
$70 250 226 of consumer electronic equipment including television receivers (in 1984/1985 imports of colour television receivers were $89 437 000)

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 5 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the estimated cost in terms of foreign exchange of replacing the current level of Australian content of passenger motor vehicles with imported cars, components and labour.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Crean The Hon S.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

(2) No one has ever suggested the complete replacement of the Australian automotive industry with imports but rather maintaining pressure on the industry to become more internationally competitive.

The Industry Commission in its draft report on the automotive industry recommended a continued reduction in tariff protection which would bring this sector more in line with levels of Government assistance applying to the rest of manufacturing industry.

Using the ORANI model, the Commission predicted significant benefits to the Australian community of this tariff reduction. QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mack Mr E.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 5 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many taxpayers pay provisional income tax under quarterly provisional tax (QPT) arrangements.

(2) Do all Australian Taxation Office (ATO) QPT assessment notices specify (a) a uniform due date for payment in each quarter, (b) dates spread over all business days in each quarter or (c) some other dates; if so, what dates.
(3) If notices are issued on one date in each quarter, what is that date.
(4) If more than one date per quarter is set for payment, (a) what are those dates and (b) how is the decision made that a particular taxpayer will pay on a particular date.
(5) With respect to ATO operations for the collection of QPT payments, (a) how many staff are employed and (b) what is the annual cost to the ATO.

(6) Would the issue of assessments and the setting of due dates for payment in each quarter by a method of self-assessment, that is, by allowing each QPT taxpayer to advise the ATO of a regular quarterly date on which he or she receives quarterly income, cost the ATO more than the issue of assessments all on one date in each quarter, and a uniform due date for payment in each quarter; if so, by what sum.
(7) Will any element of self-assessment be introduced into the QPT payment system; if so, what form will it take.
(8) Does the Government attempt to ensure that the tax system places neither PAYE taxpayers nor other taxpayers at a disadvantage in the timing of tax payments.
(9) Is the QPT system intended to ensure that PAYE taxpayers and other income earners are treated similarly.
(10) Are QPT payers regularly issued with assessment notices requiring payment of tax instalments before receipt of income to which the instalment relates.
(11) Is the payment of tax before receipt of income required of any PAYE taxpayers.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The number of taxpayers required to pay QPT varies as their provisional tax falls below or rises above the QPT threshold which is currently $8,000 p.a. Taking the most recent issue of QPT instalment notices as an indicator, as at 22/10/90, 148,238 taxpayers were liable to pay their provisional tax under QPT arrangements.

(2) Due to ATO processing limitations on the receipt of payments and variables such as public holidays which tend to vary from state to state, the due dates specified on instalment notices tend to be spread over six days following the earliest possible due date.

(3) The date for the issue of notices in each quarter is chosen to achieve due dates for payments which are as close to the earliest possible due date specified in the law while still allowing taxpayers at least 33 days from notice issue to due date. For example, the law specifies that the first instalment cannot be due before 1 September; therefore issue of notices for this instalment will be approximately 33 days prior to 1 September.

(4) As explained in (2) above, payment dates will tend to vary among taxpayers by several days. ATO systems apply the earliest due date to the largest instalments and the latest due date to the smallest instalments.

(5) Approximately 70 ATO staff are engaged full time on QPT-related work at a salary cost of some $900,000 p.a. However, most QPT work, including payment processing, is combined with similar work from other payment systems and therefore needs to be apportioned. Overall, that is taking into account buildings, equipment, administrative costs, salaries and overheads, and so on, the annual cost of the QPT system to the ATO is estimated to be approximately $7m.

(6) Considerable economies of scale are achieved by automated issue and despatch of the bulk of QPT notices four times a year. A system of intermittent issue would eliminate these economies and incur considerable additional equipment and processing costs. It is not possible to accurately estimate the net additional outlays which would be involved if such changes were to be attempted using the ATO's present computer systems.

(7) The Income Tax Assessment Act allows taxpayers to assess and vary their provisional tax (including QPT) liability. Extension of Self- assessment concepts to QPT and the other payment systems will depend on Government decisions relating to the Consultative Document on Self-Assessment issued by the Treasurer on 13 December 1990.

(8) The Government is most concerned with equity in the tax system generally, and specifically as it relates to the timing of payments. The changes made to bring forward company tax payments closer to their year of income, and therefore more in line with PAYE individuals and the bulk of other businesses in Australia, and the imposition of provisional tax on salary and wage income where there is a shortfall in tax instalment deductions, demonstrate this concern.
(9) One of the primary aims of introducing the QPT system was to increase the equity between PAYE and provisional taxpayers.

(10) It is likely that some taxpayers may not have received all or part of the income to which the instalment of tax relates. Many of these same taxpayers will, of course, have had the opportunity to earn interest on money they will eventually pay as tax-this is an advantage which is not available to PAYE payers who have their tax withheld by their employers. The Income Tax Assessment Act does provide relief where income flow is such that significant disadvantage is likely. Taxpayers who receive more than 75% of their income after 1 December in a financial year can apply for ``seasonal status'' which will require them to pay two instalments only with due dates no earlier than 1 February and 1 June respectively. These instalments are issued manually.

(11) Not in respect of their salary and wage income tax which is withheld at source by their employers. However, many PAYE payers have additional sources of income on which they pay tax through the provisional or QPT systems.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, upon notice, on 6 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What issues have so far been agreed for inclusion on the agenda for the 1992 UN Conference on Environment and Development.
(2) What plans have been made for the conference.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kelly The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The 1992 United Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) arises from Resolution 44/228 of the 1989 United Nations General Assembly and will be held in Brazil from 1 to 12 June 1992. The agenda for the UNCED will be derived from the broad aim of Resolution 44/228 to develop a comprehensive program of international action to maintain the quality of the earth's environment through the achievement of ecologically sound and sustainable development in all countries.
More specifically, Resolution 44/228 identifies nine key issues which are to be addressed by the conference:
(a) Protection of the atmosphere by combating climate change, depletion of the ozone layer and transboundary air pollution;
(b) Protection of the quality and supply of freshwater resources;
(c) Protection of the oceans and all kinds of seas, including enclosed and semi-enclosed seas, and of their living resources;
(d) Protection and management of land resources by, inter alia, combating deforestation, desertification and drought;

(g) Environmentally sound management of wastes, particularly hazardous wastes, and of toxic chemicals, as well as prevention of illegal international traffic in toxic and dangerous products and wastes;

(h) Improvement of the living and working environment of the poor in urban slums and rural areas, through the eradication of poverty by, inter alia, implementing integrated rural and urban development programmes, as well as taking other appropriate measures at all levels necessary to stem the degradation of the environment;
(i) Protection of human health conditions and improvement of the quality of life.
Resolution 44/228 also identified cross-sectoral issues, such as technology transfer, financial assistance and education, as central to the consideration of these environmental concerns.
(2) Resolution 44/228 established a Preparatory Committee and Secretariat for the UNCED. The Preparatory Committee has three broad tasks:
(a) Draft the provisional agenda of the Conference, in accordance with the provisions of Resolution;
(b) Adopt guidelines to enable States to take a harmonised approach to their preparations and reporting;
(c) Prepare draft decisions for the Conference and submit them to the Conference for consideration and adoption.
The Preparatory Committee held its first substantive meeting in Nairobi in August 1990 and will meet a further three times in the lead up to the UNCED.

The report of the Australian delegation to the first meeting of the Preparatory Committee is a public document available on request from either my own department or from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I have arranged for a copy of the delegation's report to be sent to the honorable member.
A small Secretariat, under Secretary-General Maurice Strong, has been established in Geneva to assist the Preparatory Committee in its work.
Planning for the UNCED and related activities and events, such as a parallel conference of non government organisations, is progressing well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 6 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) (a) considering, (b) proposing or (c) recommending changes to the air traffic control systems, in particular radar coverage, of Australian airspace; if so, would the changes result in a reduction of the airspace currently surveyed by radar; if so, by how much.

(2) Is the CAA proposing an aircraft-to-aircraft location notification system which would require the operator of an aircraft flying in airspace not covered by radar to communicate the aircraft's position to all other aircraft in the immediate area.
(3) Is the CAA proposing a ``see and avoid'' system of aircraft control in airspace not covered by radar; if so, how will the system operate when visibility is poor.
(4) Will aircraft operators be required to monitor and transmit positional information on (a) operational information services, (b) common user, (c) Unicom or (d) any other, frequencies.
(5) Will aircraft without radio transmitting and receiving devices be permitted to operate in airspace not covered by radar.
(6) Is the CAA proposing to alter the operational ceiling for aircraft without radio communication devices from the current 5000 feet to 20 000 feet; if so, why.
(7) Are commercial aircraft operating in Australian airspace required to meet national airworthiness and safety regulations.

(8) If airworthiness and safety standards do not apply in all cases, (a) to whom, (b) by whom, (c) under what circumstances, (d) on how many occasions and (e) why were any dispensations or exceptions granted.
(9) Is Australia a signatory to the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) convention on standards.

(10) Does the ICAO Annexe II, Chapter 4, paragraph 42 standard regarding traffic advice outside radar controlled airspace require traffic information to be issued by an air traffic services unit to alert the pilot and to help the pilot avoid a collision.
(11) Will Australia adopt the standard referred to in part (10); if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The CAA is proposing a number of changes to its airspace management arrangements, including provision of a new radar based traffic advisory service. This service will considerably extend the radar services now provided. Under the CAA's existing Radar Sensor Procurement Program, radar coverage of Australian airspace is being significantly extended from Cairns down the east coast and across to Adelaide and around Perth.
(2) The CAA is proposing that under Class G airspace, pilots will provide their own traffic information directly to each other via common traffic frequencies.

(3) Pilots have always used the ``see and avoid'' principle of aircraft separation in weather conditions which allow them to sight conflicting traffic in time to take necessary avoidance action. The CAA is proposing to retain these procedures in all classes of airspace, and will continue to supplement them with radio and radar and flight techniques. When visibility is poor ``see and avoid'' procedures would not be applicable and pilots would need to maintain separation using other means, such as radio.

(4) The CAA is proposing that pilots monitor and transmit information relating to their position on one, or more, of the listed frequencies. Which frequency is used will depend on the pilot's requirements, the aircraft's geographic position and which leg of the flight is being undertaken.

(5) and (6) The CAA is proposing to retain the requirement for all aircraft operating above 5000ft to carry and use radio. The Authority is also considering mandatory carriage and use of radio by all aircraft operating within the vicinity of licensed aerodromes. Visual Flight Rules, non-commercial aircraft not equipped to carry radios could use hand-held radios.

(7) All Australian aircraft operating in Australian airspace must meet appropriate Australian airworthiness standards and comply with pertinent Australian operational safety requirements. Foreign aircraft operating in Australian airspace, such as overseas airlines, must meet the airworthiness requirements of the State of Registration of the aircraft, but must still comply with Australian operational rules when within Australian airspace.

(8) (a)-(e) It is the policy of the CAA that all aircraft normally located in Australia should be placed on the Australian Register; thereby becoming fully subject to Australian regulatory oversight. However, the CAA recognises that it would be unreasonable to insist that aircraft on short term service in Australia, that is, less than six months, be placed on the Register.

For this reason, the CAA permits aircraft on short term service in Australia to retain their foreign registration on condition that, in each case, a satisfactory arrangement for regulatory oversight of such aircraft be negotiated between the CAA and the regulatory authority of the country of origin.

This policy is consistent with overseas practice and allows the greatest reasonable level of Australian regulatory oversight of operations within Australia, while at the same time taking account of the commercial and developmental objectives of the Australian aviation industry.

(10) ICAO Annexe II, Chapter 4, Paragraph 42 refers to the scope of the flight information service. It does recommend that information about known aircraft which may constitute a collision hazard be passed on to other aircraft, and states further that``air traffic services units cannot assume responsibility for its issuance at all times or for its accuracy''.
(11) The CAA does intend to adopt the standard referred to in part (10).

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Are the (a) Alfred and (b) St Vincent's Hospitals in Sydney listed in the latest edition of the Medicare Benefits Schedule book as being hospitals where benefits apply in terms of magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) services; if so, are there any operational MRI facilities at either hospital and, if not, why are the hospitals so listed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. However, the book does show MRI services at the Alfred and St Vincent's Hospitals in Melbourne as attracting Medicare benefits.

An MRI unit is being installed at St Vincent's Hospital, Melbourne, and is expected to be operational within a few months. There is no operational unit at the Alfred Hospital, but it is planned to purchase and install one there.

In 1989 Victoria requested that benefits be payable if MRI units were installed at these two hospitals in order to meet current demand for MRI services. The Commonwealth agreed to this request. The hospitals were listed in the Medicare Benefits Schedule book in anticipation of installation of the units.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bailey Mrs F.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Minister authorise the implementation of CAA Class G airspace in Australia; if so, what guarantees will there be (a) that safety standards will be maintained after the implementation, and (b) under Airspace Management and Traffic Services that passenger-carrying aircraft flying in clouds, for example, are not flying blind without full traffic information on potentially conflicting aircraft.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (a) The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) proposes to introduce the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) classification of airspace, which provides for Class G to be implemented where appropriate. The CAA is consulting extensively with the industry to ensure general agreement on the extent of Class G airspace and is confident that the proposed changes will lead to greater overall safety in the airways system.
(b) Pilots flying in cloud in Class G airspace will receive information on potential conflicts by exchanging information about their movements over common traffic frequencies.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Scott Mr J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 20 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Codex Alimentarius Commission established levels for the amount of radioactive isotopes which may occur in food traded internationally; if so, (a) when were the levels established, (b) are they applicable (i) at all times or (ii) for a set period after a nuclear accident and (c) if they apply for a limited period, (i) what period and (ii) how was the period determined.
(2) Was Australia involved in setting the levels referred to in part (1); if so, whom in Australia was consulted.

(3) Is the half life (a) 458 years for americium-241, (b) 24 390 years for plutonium-239, (c) 28 years for strontium-90, (d) 8 days for iodine-131, (e) 2.05 years for caesium-134 and 30 years for caesium-137.
(4) If the half lives referred to in part (3) vary so widely and the levels referred to in part (1) apply for a set period, why do they apply for a set period.

(5) Do the levels referred to in part (1) cover only americium-241, plutonium-239, strontium-90, iodine-131, caesium-134 and caesium-137; if so, why are iodine-129, plutonium-242, americium-243 and the radioactive isotopes of beryllium, iron and cadmium not included.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) In July 1989 at its 18th Session the Codex Alimentarius Commission adopted guideline levels for radionuclides in foods following accidental nuclear contamination.

(b) &(c) The guideline levels are applicable for one year following a nuclear accident. The Commission adopted, as an interim measure, the following definition of ``guideline levels'': ``Guideline levels are intended for use in regulating foods moving in international trade. When the guideline levels are exceeded, governments should decide whether, and under which circumstances, the food should be distributed within their territory or jurisdiction.''

(2) Australia was represented by the Australian Radiation Laboratory of the Department of Community Services and Health on a working group whose report formed the basis for joint WHOFAO recommendations on which the guideline levels were based. State health departments were kept informed through their representation on the Radiation Health Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council.

(3) The currently accepted values of the half-lives of the radionuclides are (a) 432.7 years for americium-241, (b) 24 110 years for plutonium-239, (c) 28.5 years for strontium-90, (d) 8.04 days for iodine-131, (e) 2.06 years for caesium-134 and 30.0 years for caesium-137.
(4) The report of the working group referred to in part (c) above states:

``The individual radiation dose in the second and subsequent years after a nuclear accident is likely to be considerably less than that received in the first year. In this case it is not necessary to revise the intervention dose levels or derived intervention levels for successive years, since the situation in individual countries will vary. In the rare situation in which the annual radiation dose has not fallen significantly by the second or third year, it is for the competent authorities to consider the specific circumstances and decide whether additional action is needed.''

(5) No. The guideline levels are established for three ``dose per unit intake'' levels: the radionuclides mentioned in the question are included as ``representative radionuclides'' for each of these levels, but this does not exclude other radionuclides within each category. The six mentioned are, however, regarded by the WHO-FAO group as being of greatest potential significance in contamination of the food chain following a nuclear accident.

Funds are progressively available during the course of the projects up to the full amount of the offer. Where the figure shown above is equal to the offer, these projects have been completed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jull Mr D.F.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, upon notice, on 21 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Government provided funds to groups opposing the construction of a third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; if so, (a) what sum and (b) is a percentage of that sum being used to fund Coopers and Lybrand's cost-benefit study of the third runway; if so, what percentage.
(2) Has the Federal Airports Corporation undertaken such a study; if so, why is the Government funding the Coopers and Lybrand's study.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support has supplied the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Financial assistance was provided to the Marrickville Municipal Council on behalf of three community groups: the Airport Co-ordinating Taskforce; Residents Against Runway Three (RORT); and the Second Sydney Airport Coalition (SSAC).

(2) The Federal Airports Corporation, as proponent of the proposed third runway at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport, engaged Kinhill Engineers Pty Ltd to undertake an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) process for the proposal. The Draft EIS on the proposed third runway released in September 1990 includes a financial assessment of the third runway and alternatives.
